questions.text:
Match the different approaches of prostatectomy.
1. Transurethral approach  A. Young operation
2. Retropubic approach B. TURP
3. Transvesical approach C. Millin approach
4. Perineal approach D. Freyer approach
questions.solution:
The correctly matched approaches of prostatectomy are as follows: 

1. Transurethral approach  B. TURP
2. Retropubic approach C. Millin approach
3. Transvesical approach D. Freyer approach
4. Perineal approach A. Young operation

Cracking the single match that 1. Transurethral approach -> B. TURP could have helped solve the question easily. At times, a seemingly difficult question can be solved correctly by cracking just a part of the solution.

questions.text: Which of the following recommendation was made by the Kartar Singh committee?

choices.text: Development of  primary health centers in 2 stages
Constitution of an All India Health Services

questions.solution:
Kartar Singh Committee recommended the feasibility of having multipurpose workers under health and family planning in India.

Kartar Singh Committee under the ministry of health and family planning recommended the following:

  • Structure for integrated services at the peripheral and supervisory levels
  • Feasibility of having multipurpose workers in the field and their training requirements 
  • Mobile service units for integrated medical, public health, and family planning

Other options:

Option A:  The development of primary health centers in 2 stages was recommended by the Bhore committee. Along with it the integration of preventive and curative services at all administrative levels was also recommended. The inclusion of 3 months of preventive and social medicine training in medical education was another suggestion put forward.

Option B: The development of a referral services complex was recommended by the Shrivastav Committee. This committee also recommended the establishment of a medical and health education commission.

Option D: Constitution of all India health services on the pattern of an Indian administrative service was recommended by the Mudaliar committee of 1962. It is also known as the health survey and planning committee. They found the services provided by the PHC are inadequate and advised strengthening of existing PHCs. It also recommended strengthening district hospitals with specialist services.

questions.text: A young boy with a metabolic disorder has long slender fingers, tall stature, and a high arched palate. He is fair-skinned, with blue eyes and a malar flush. On ophthalmological examination, there is a bilateral inferonasal subluxation of the lens. This disorder is due to abnormal metabolism of:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with tall stature, long limbs, inferonasal subluxation of the lens, with blue eyes, fair skin, and a malar flush is suggestive of homocystinuria, which is due to the abnormal metabolism of methionine.

Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of methionine metabolism. It is due to a defect in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase whose function is to convert homocysteine to cystathionine. This leads to an abnormal accumulation of homocysteine and its metabolites (homocysteine, homocysteine-cysteine complex, and others) in blood and urine, along with low levels of cysteine in plasma. 

Clinical features:

  • Affected infants appear normal at birth. 
  • Ectopia lentis (inferonasal subluxation of the lens) is seen first, after 3 years of age. There may be severe myopia and iridodonesis (quivering iris).
  • Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders.
  • Thromboembolic episodes especially in the large and small vessels of the brain.
  • Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly (slender fingers). There may be scoliosis, a high arched palate, and crowding of teeth.
  • Fair skin, blue eyes, and a malar flush

Diagnosis is by elevated levels of methionine and homocysteine in body fluids. Additional tests include molecular analysis of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) and enzyme assay in cultured fibroblasts, lymphocytes, or liver biopsy specimens.

Treatment includes restriction of methionine intake and supplementation with cysteine, betaine, vitamins B6, and folate.

questions.text: The given blood smear shows a characteristic cell type. It is most likely  seen in infection with which of the following viruses?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is adult T cell leukemia/lymphoma caused by human T cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). The peripheral smear given above shows tumor cells with multilobulated nuclei (“cloverleaf” or “flower” cells) which is characteristic of Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma.

Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma (CD4+):

  • It is observed in adults infected by human T cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1)
  • It is characterised by skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, peripheral blood lymphocytosis, and hypercalcemia.
  • Peripheral smear shows cells with multilobulated nuclei (“cloverleaf” or “flower” cells)
  • A rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

questions.text: The IVP imaging of a 30-year-old woman is given below. What is it diagnostic of?
questions.solution:
The given intravenous pyelogram is characteristic for medullary sponge kidney. It shows ectatic distal collecting ducts containing microcalcifications, which is called bouquet of flowers appearance. Dilated contrast-filled tubules within the renal medulla are also seen, which is known as paintbrush appearance. 

This is a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of the medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts.

questions.text: During the examination of a 2-month-old infant, you have observed that the umbilical cord is still firmly attached, and there is infection of cord stump. Which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Delayed separation of umbilical cord, after 1 month is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes.

The umbilical cord usually separates by 10-14 days after birth, although in about 10% of healthy infants, it may separate at the age of 3 weeks or later.

An intact cord after 1 month of birth is called delayed separation.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes:

  • LADs are autosomal recessive disorders characterized by defects in the function of neutrophils that include adhesion, motility, and ability to phagocytose bacteria.
  • As a result, the children may have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to reduced immune response, despite increased neutrophil count.
  • There is delayed separation of the cord, which is usually associated with infection of the cord stump.

There are three types of LAD:

  • LAD 1- Defective beta 2 integrin (CD18), leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and defective tight adhesion. 
  • LAD 2- Reduced phagocyte surface expression of sialyl-Lewis X, leading to abnormal neutrophil rolling.
  • LAD 3- Defective signaling for integrin activation, leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion. (milder than type 1)

questions.text: Which of the following can lead to the abnormality given in the below image?

choices.text: Chorionic plate larger than basal plate
Chorionic plate smaller than basal plate

questions.solution:
The given image shows the circumvallate placenta. It is a type of extrachorial placentation and is caused when the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate.

Extrachorial placentation: The chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation - circummarginate and circumvallate placenta.

In the Circummarginate placenta, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage with a smooth margin.

In the Circumvallate placenta, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

Complications associated with Circumvallate placenta:

  • Preterm delivery
  • Abortions
  • Growth retardation
  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Retained placenta
  • Hydrorrhea gravidarum

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of increasing heartburn and dyspepsia for the past several months. He was prescribed PPIs for one month but he has no relief. He is diagnosed with type B gastritis. Which of the following features is not in line with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Type B gastritis predominantly affects the antrum, is commonly associated with Helicobacter pylori infection and has no HLA associations. Achlorhydria is characteristically seen in Type A gastritis.

Type B gastritis usually affects the antrum. Intestinal metaplasia associated with chronic pan-gastritis and atrophy is seen. It has greater potential for malignancy as compared to Type A gastritis. Helicobacter pylori infection is most commonly associated with Type B gastritis.

Type A gastritis affects the fundus with antral sparing. Its features can be easily remembered by 4 ‘A’s:

  • Autoimmune condition - has circulating antibodies to parietal cells
  • Atrophy of parietal cell mass
  • Achlorhydria - causes chronic hypergastrinemia and microadenomas of enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells
  • Anemia - leads to pernicious anemia, due to malabsorption of Vit B12 (as the intrinsic factor is also produced by parietal cells)

questions.text: During your labor postings, you noted the Manning score of a G2P1 woman at 35 weeks of gestation to be 8 with normal amniotic fluid volume. What would be the recommended management?
questions.solution:
Manning score of 8 (normal is 8 to 10) is suggestive of normal or less risk of fetal asphyxia and a repeat testing at weekly interval is advised to a patient in 35 weeks of gestation.

Manning score, also known as BPP(Bio-Physical Profile) Scoring system refers to an antepartum fetal assessment.

Components of Biophysical profile (BPP)/Manning score:

(Mnemonic:BATMaN)

  • B - Breathing movements of the fetus
  • A - Amniotic fluid volume
  • T - Tone of the fetus
  • M - Movements of the fetus
  • N - Non-stress test (NST)

Each of these parameters is given a score of either 0 or 2 points, where an abnormal score gets 0 while a normal score gets 2.


Interpretation:

BPP Score Interpretation Management
8-10 Normal or Less risk of fetal asphyxia Repeat testing at weekly intervals
6 Suspect chronic asphyxia If ≥ 36 weeks; deliver, but if L/S < 2.0 repeat test in 4–6 hours
4 Suspect chronic asphyxia

If ≥ 36 weeks; deliver

If < 32 weeks; repeat the test in 4–6 hours
0-2 Strongly suspect asphyxia

Test for 120 minutes and if the score is persistently ≤ 4 then deliver regardless of gestational age

 

 

Note: The modified biophysical score has only 2 components i.e NST and amniotic fluid index only. It is considered abnormal (nonreassuring) when the NST is non-reactive and/or the AFI is <5.

questions.text: Identify the stain used in the given cryostat section.
questions.solution:
The given cryostat or frozen section slide has been stained with Oil red O.

Oil-red-O stains lipids/fats and gives them a characteristic orange-red appearance. It is used in the unfixed frozen sections as the fixation of fats with other routine processes may lose the lipid content. 10% neutral buffer formaldehyde (NBF) is the preferred fixative in histopathological sections staining with Oil-red-O.

Other stains used for lipids include:

  • Nile blue sulfate. 
  • Osmic acid
  • Sudan black B

Other options: 

Alizarin red S and von Kossa stains are used for staining calcium. von Kossa stain, which uses silver nitrate, is used more commonly for the demonstration of calcium. Masson trichrome is a connective tissue stain in which collagen appears blue-green, muscle appears red and nuclei appear black.

questions.text: 40-year-old man goes on a camping vacation with his family. Two days after swimming in a freshwater lake near the campsite, he develops nausea and vomiting and starts to behave irrationally. His family takes him to the emergency department, where blood samples are taken and a spinal tap is performed. He is diagnosed with a rapidly progressing meningoencephalitis and dies shortly thereafter. Which of the following was most likely the cause of the man’s illness?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) is most likely due to the organism Naegleria fowleri, a pathogenic free-living amoeba. 

It mostly affects previously healthy young adults or children. The infection sets in acutely following swimming or diving in ponds or other warm, freshwater bodies. The incubation period varies from 2 days to 2 weeks.

They are free-living amoeba and exist in three forms - cyst, ameboid trophozoite form, and flagellate trophozoite form.

The amoeba invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges and brain to initiate acute purulent meningitis and encephalitis or primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).

Clinically, patients present with anosmia during the incubation period. Following this, the disease advances rapidly, causing fever, headache, vomiting, neck stiffness, ataxia, seizures, and coma. It is fatal in the majority of cases and death usually occurs within one week.

Microscopic analysis of CSF will reveal motile amoeboid trophozoites.

Treatment is with intravenous amphotericin B, which is the drug of choice. 

Other options-

Option B: Acanthamoeba is also a free-living amoeba. These organisms may also cause granulomatous amebic encephalitis, an infection of the brain and spinal cord. It usually occurs in immunocompromised patients and the incubation period and course of illness are typically slow. These features are in contrast to this patient's acute presentation and rapid deterioration, thereby suggesting another diagnosis.

Option C: Cryptosporidium species are implicated in causing traveler's diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. 

Option D: Entamoeba Histolytica is intestinal amoebae that are transmitted feco-orally. They are implicated in amoebic colitis and amoebic liver abscess.

questions.text: During your dermatology positing, you noticed diascopy and woods lamp test were used to differentiate vitiligo from naevus anaemicus. Which of the following options represent the findings seen in the case of vitiligo?

choices.text: Lesion remains paler on diascopy and depigmented areas  completely disappears under Wood's lamp
Lesion remains paler on diascopy and depigmented areas are exaggerated  under Wood's lamp
Both lesion and normal skin appear pale on diascopy and the pallor completely disappears under Wood's lamp
Both lesion and normal skin appear pale on diascopy and depigmented areas are exaggerated  under Wood's lamp

questions.solution:
In a case of Vitiligo, lesion remains paler on diascopy and depigmented areas are exaggerated under Wood's lamp

Diascopy and Wood's lamp are used to differentiate between naevus anaemicus and vitiligo.

Diascopy is a clinical manoeuvre performed to assess superficial erythema in dermatological conditions. It involves pressing a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colourless piece of plastic onto the skin to compress blood out of small vessels, in order to allow evaluation of other colours. Vessels can be seen to blanch and fill, by varying the amount of pressure on the skin, which is different for different conditions.

Diascopy: Nevus anemicus becomes indistinguishable from the surrounding skin with diascopy i.e. in naevus anaemicus (a localized area of vasoconstriction), since other pigments are unaltered, diascopy of adjacent skin reveals an identical color to that of the ‘depigmented’ area. But in vitiligo, in which there is loss of melanin,  the vitiligo lesion remains paler.

Wood's Lamp: In vitiligo, due to loss of melanin, the depigmented areas are exaggerated under the wood's lamp. Whereas, in naevus anaemicus, due to localized dermal vasoconstriction, the pallor completely disappears under the light.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has a report showing HCO3- = 23 mEq/L, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L. Calculate the anion gap in this patient.
questions.solution:
The anion gap in this patient is 22 mEq/L.

Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. But, a few of the anions (lactate, phosphate, and sulfate) cannot be measured and this is called an anion gap. It is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:

Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ] − [(HCO3− ) + (Cl− )]

Substituting the values = 145−23−100= 22 mEq/L

The normal anion gap ranges between 8-16 mEq/L.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who is a chronic smoker had recurrent retroareolar infections and abscesses. The condition she is suffering from is________.
questions.solution:
Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retro areolar infections and abscesses. Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition. Managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage as necessary.

Other options: 

Option A: Tietze’s Syndrome is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall.

Option D: Paget's disease of the nipple is a superficial manifestation of underlying breast carcinoma. It presents as an eczema-like condition of the nipple

questions.text: The following image shows a graph representing atrial and ventricular pressures during a cardiac cycle. Which phase of the cardiac cycle corresponds to the relaxation of the ventricular muscle with no change in its volume?
questions.solution:
The phase of the cardiac cycle labelled 3 corresponds to iso-volumetric relaxation where the ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.

Events of the Cardiac Cycle

Systole :

  • Isovolumetric Contraction
    The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed. 
    It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
  • Ventricular Ejection
    When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively. 

Diastole :

  • Protodiastole
    Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to momentum of blood.
  • Iso-volumetric Relaxation
    The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
  • Ventricular Filling
    Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
  • Atrial Systole
    During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with 'a' wave in JVP.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the OPD with fever and malaise for the past 4 weeks. On examination, the following ocular finding is noted along with hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. What is the likely causative agent for her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing Romana's sign is suggestive of Chagas disease. It is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi.

Inoculation of T. cruzi in conjunctiva causes unilateral, painless edema of periocular tissues in the eye is called Romana’s sign. This is classically seen in acute Chagas disease that lasts for 1 to 4 months.

Transmission occurs by the rubbing of the feces of the reduviid bug (Shown in the image below) into bite wounds or eye, blood transfusion, and transplacental spread.

Clinically, the infection course of Chagas disease is divided into acute and chronic phases.

In the acute phase, the majority of the patients will be asymptomatic. Fever, regional lymphadenitis, hepatosplenomegaly, chagoma (localized subcutaneous nodule at the bite site), and Romana's sign (unilateral swelling of the eyelids) may be seen.

Chronic Chagas disease is characterized by megaesophagus, megacolon, and myopathy.

Other options:

  • Trypanosoma brucei causes African Trypanosomiasis (also known as Sleeping Sickness).
  • Leishmania donovani is predominantly responsible for visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kala-azar but may also cause cutaneous leishmaniasis.
  • Leishmania tropica predominantly causes cutaneous leishmaniasis

questions.text: An ophthalmological examination of a patient presenting with blunt trauma to the eyes revealed a Vossius ring. Which of the following is true regarding its location?
questions.solution:
Vossius ring is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity, seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens. It is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.

It usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward and thus producing an impression of the iris on the lens. The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

 

Other options-

Option B: Arcus senilis (AS) is an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral cornea that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity and is usually found in the elderly where it is considered a benign condition.

Arcus senilis is shown in the image below.

Option C: Weiss or Vogt’s ring is seen in the posterior vitreous detachment as a ring around the optic disc. This appearance is caused by the attachment of the peripapillary glial tissue to the detached vitreous cortex. 

Option D: Commotio retinae or the Berlin’s oedema manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole with a ‘cherry-red spot’ in the foveal region. Given below is an image of Berlin's edema.

questions.text: While conducting animal studies, a scientist is experimenting with a drug called vesamicol that causes skeletal muscle relaxation. What is the mechanism by which the drug causes muscle relaxation?

choices.text: Breakdown of acetylcholine after its release into the synaptic cleft
Blocks the transport of acetylcholine into its storage vesicle
Inhibits the uptake of choline into nerve terminals
Prevents the release of  acetylcholine from nerve terminals.

questions.solution:
Vesamicol causes skeletal muscle relaxation by blocking the transport of acetylcholine into its storage vesicle.

It acts on the cholinergic nerve terminals and blocks the transport, thus preventing the repletion of acetylcholinesterase following transmitter release. 

Other options:

Option A: Acetylcholine esterase is involved in the breakdown of acetylcholine after it is released into the synaptic cleft to acetate and choline.

Option C: Hemicholinum inhibits the uptake of choline into nerve terminals.

Option D: Botulinum toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine from nerve terminals.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with excruciating pain in her lips, gums, and cheeks for the past 6 months. The pain is usually triggered by talking and brushing her teeth. Each pain episode lasts for 1-2 minutes. On examination, there is no sensory loss over the face. Which of the following is the first-line management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. The first-line management of this patient is carbamazepine.

Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by excruciating paroxysmal pain in the lips, gums, cheek, or chin and, rarely ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. It is also known as tic douloureux (a painful condition of the face). It is commonly seen in middle-aged and elderly women. 

The large myelinated fibers of the trigeminal nerve carry tactile stimuli from the face and do not carry pain fibers themselves. In trigeminal neuralgia, due to compression or other pathologies, the large fibers undergo demyelination. These demyelinated large fibers become hyperexcitable and electrically coupled with the surrounding smaller unmyelinated pain fibers of the trigeminal nerve. This explains why tactile stimulation of trigger zones (lips, gums, cheek, or chin) leads to pain paroxysms. Symptoms occur due to ectopic generation of action potentials in pain-sensitive afferent fibers of the trigeminal nerve root just before entering the pons.

The pain may occur spontaneously or after movements like chewing, speaking, smiling, washing the face, brushing teeth, or exposure to wind. On examination, the physician will not find any sensory loss over the area. The pain usually lasts for seconds or minutes. The intensity of pain is severe, so much so that the patient winces. Therefore it is called a 'tic'.

Carbamazepine is the first-line drug in the management of patients with trigeminal neuralgia. Lamotrigine, Phenytoin, Topiramate, or Gabapentin are other options that may be tried if Carbamazepine is ineffective. Microvascular decompression of the trigeminal nerve can be done if medical therapies fail.

Differential diagnoses of trigeminal neuralgia include:

  • Migraine and cluster headaches - They tend to have deep-seated and continuous pain while trigeminal neuralgia has more of a superficial stabbing quality pain and is episodic. 
  • Short-lasting unilateral headache with conjunctival tearing (SUNCT) - It will typically present with unilateral conjunctival congestion, tearing, and nasal stuffiness. 
  • Temporal arteritis - It will usually be accompanied by myalgias and signs of systemic inflammation. ESR and CRP will be elevated.
  • If trigeminal neuralgia develops in a young patient or is bilateral, a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis should be considered. In such cases, the cause of the pain is a demyelinating plaque near the entry point of the trigeminal nerve in the pons.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks of gestation presented with bleeding per vagina. A sample of the PV bleed is obtained and an Apt test is performed. Which of the following is false about the Apt test?

choices.text: It is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to acid denaturation
It helps in the diagnosis of vasa previa
Emergency Caesarian section is performed if apt test is positive

questions.solution:
The apt test is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation.

The Apt test is an alkali denaturation test to detect fetal hemoglobin (HbF). It is a qualitative test. It is positive in vasa previa and Rh incompatibility.

The apt test is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation, while HbA is not. It is done by taking the blood sample in a test tube containing water and adding 1% NaOH. Maternal blood turns yellow-brown, while fetal blood remains pink in the test tube.

Bleeding due to vasa previa must be managed immediately with an emergency cesarean section. Hence, the Apt test is not practically done in all cases.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy came with complaints of toothache for a few days. Oral examination revealed the presence of dental caries. The bacteria isolated from the lesion demonstrates alpha hemolysis and the growth was not inhibited by optochin. Which of the following bacteria is commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of dental caries with bacteria showing alpha hemolysis and optochin resistance is suggestive of streptococcus mutans.

Streptococcus mutans belong to the viridans group of streptococci and they are the common organism causing dental caries. Streptococcus mutans break down the dietary sucrose resulting in the production of acid and a tough adhesive dextran. The acid damages dentine while the dextrans bind together with food debris, epithelial cells, mucus, and bacteria to form dental plaques, leading to the formation of dental caries.

Viridans streptococci show alpha hemolysis on blood agar and are resistant to optochin. It includes:

  • Streptococci mitis 
  • Streptococci mutans
  • Streptococci salvarius
  • Streptococci sanguis (causes sub-acute bacterial endocarditis)

Other options:

Option B- Streptococcus pyogenes are beta-hemolytic and they mainly cause upper respiratory tract infection, pyoderma, rheumatic fever, and glomerulonephritis. 

Option C- Streptococcus bovis are gamma hemolytic and they mainly cause endocarditis. 

Option D- Streptoccoci agalacatcise are beta-hemolytic and they mainly cause neonatal meningitis, septicemia, and urinary tract infection.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, vomiting, and watery diarrhea. He gives a history of having consumed shellfish and raw seafood a day before. The causative agent showed Kanagawa phenomenon on Wagatsuma agar. Which of the following statements is true regarding the organism implicated here?

choices.text: It shows bipolar staining on microscopy
On thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose (TCBS) agar, it produces yellow colonies
Causes enteritis by producing cholera toxin

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of gastroenteritis, along with culture findings of the Kanagawa phenomenon on Wagatsuma agar, is suggestive of infection with Vibrio parahaemolyticus. It shows bipolar staining. 

Some other organisms showing bipolar staining (safety pin appearance) include:

  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei
  • Klebsiella granulomatis

V. parahaemolyticus causes food poisoning due to the consumption of contaminated seafood, after an incubation period of 12–24 hours. The common sources of infection are raw seafood like mollusks and crustaceans. No enterotoxin like cholera toxin (Option C) has been identified, it cause enteritis by invasion of the intestinal epithelium.

Clinically, patients present with nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, fever, and watery or bloody diarrhea. Fecal leukocytes are often seen in stool samples. Enteritis subsides spontaneously in 1–3 days with no specific treatment. Adequate hydration and electrolyte balance should be restored.

V. parahaemolyticus is a capsulated bacterium. It shows bipolar staining and has a tendency to pleomorphism. It is characterized by peritrichous flagella on solid media and polar flagella on liquid media and it gives a positive string test (Option D).

Pathogenic strains of V. parahemolyticus are hemolytic on Wagatsuma agar, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This is called the Kanagawa phenomenon and is due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

V. parahaemolyticus grows well on blood agar, where it is identified by its oxidase-positive growth. On thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose (TCBS) agar (Shown in the image below), it produces green colonies, unlike V. cholera colonies that are yellow in color (Option B).

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with low-grade fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea for the last two months. He also gives a history of arthralgia involving multiple joints for the last two years. An endoscopic biopsy was taken and is shown below. Which of the following is the correct treatment regimen for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhea and chronic arthralgia and the given slide showing macrophages filled with PAS-positive inclusions points to a diagnosis of Whipple's disease. Amongst the given options, the best-suited treatment regimen for Whipple's disease is ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks, followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 12 months.  Prolonged antibiotics are recommended but there is still uncertainty prevailing regarding the optimal regimen.

Whipple's disease is a multi-system disease caused by infection with gram-positive bacillus, Tropheryma whipplei. Clinical features include arthralgia and arthritis, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Arthralgias and arthritis are present for many years before the appearance of GI symptoms. CNS involvement is common and presents as psychiatric manifestations, memory problems or ophthalmoplegia. Dementia may occur in later stages. Cardiac involvement may be in the form of endocarditis, myocarditis, and pericarditis. Hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas may also be seen. Intermittent low-grade fever is present in most of the patients.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is primarily established by endoscopic biopsy and histological evaluation. Infiltration of lamina propria with PAS-positive macrophages containing the bacilli is diagnostic. The remainder of the cases are diagnosed by PCR which can be done on duodenal biopsies or fluids (such as CSF and synovial fluid) or tissues.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the demography of a village with a population of 10,000. In the total population, 1000 members were found to be below 15 years of age and 1000 members were over 65 years of age. What is the total dependency ratio of this population?
questions.solution:
The total dependency ratio in this population is 25%.

This can be calculated using the given formula:

Here, the total population below 15 years of age is = 1000

Total population above 65 years of age = 1000

So, total population between 15-64 years of age = 10,000 - (1000 + 1000) = 8,000

Hence, the dependency ratio in this population = (2,000 X 100) ÷ 8,000 = 25%

questions.text: The clinical distinction between a cavernous sinus syndrome and an orbital apex syndrome is best made by the dysfunction of which structure?
questions.solution:
The clinical distinction between a cavernous sinus syndrome and an orbital apex syndrome is made by the dysfunction of the optic nerve (marked as "A")

The optic nerve passes through the optic canal and does not enter the cavernous sinus. Patients with orbital apex syndrome manifest complete ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, decreased corneal sensation, and vision loss. They usually develop optic nerve signs such as relative afferent pupillary defect. Proptosis is often present, but patients do not always complain of pain.

Cavernous sinus syndrome (CSS) is a rare condition characterized by ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, ocular and conjunctival congestion, trigeminal sensory loss, and Horner’s syndrome. These signs and symptoms result from the involvement of the cranial nerves passing through the cavernous sinus. The cavernous sinus syndrome affects III, IV, V, and VI cranial nerves. The III, IV, V cranial nerves pass in relation to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. VI cranial nerve passes through the cavernous sinus. The cavernous sinus syndrome is a distinctive and frequently life-threatening disorder.

Orbital apex syndrome includes the following:

  • Pain, typically labelled as retro-orbital ache
  • Sensory loss/disturbances in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve
  • Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia due to the involvement of the 3rd, 4th, and 6th cranial nerve involvement
  • Ptosis, due to 3rd nerve paralysis
  • Features of optic nerve involvement, i.e., early visual loss and afferent pupillary defect.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman whose mother is a known case of breast cancer undergoes a mammography every six months. The time advantage the woman achieves by doing so if diagnosed with breast cancer is represented by which of the following intervals in the given image?
questions.solution:
The advantage gained by screening is the lead time which is represented by the time period between 1 to 3.

Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis (point 3 in the image). This ensures the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. 

The time difference between the first possible point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis is called screening time which is represented by the time interval 1 to 2 in the above image. 

The final critical point (point 2 in the image) is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man working in the smelting industry presents with lesions as seen in the following image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a smelting industry worker presenting with raindrop pigmentation as shown in the image is suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning. 

There are several types of arsenic poisoning:

  • Fulminant - When massive doses are rapidly absorbed, death occurs in 1–3 hours due to shock and peripheral vascular failure.
  • Gastrointestinal - This is the most common form of acute poisoning and resembles bacterial food poisoning. There is a constriction in the throat and difficulty in swallowing. The stools are dark-colored, stinking, and bloody initially and later take a colorless odorless watery form similar to the rice-water stools of cholera.
  • Chronic poisoning - It occurs due to repeated daily exposure. The main features include finely mottled, raindrop pigmentation that appears on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, and neck. In prolonged contact, hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles occurs along with the development of a transverse white line in the fingernails called the Aldrich-Mees lines.

Tests to detect arsenic poisoning:

  • 24-hour urinary excretion of arsenic
  • Detection of arsenic by atomic absorption spectroscopy
  • Marsh and Reinsch tests are now considered obsolete.

The preferred treatment option is freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide, which converts toxic arsenic to non-toxic ferric arsenite. DMSA (Succimer), British anti-Lewisite (BAL), and penicillamine can also be used.

questions.text: A junior radiologist performing an abdominal ultrasound of a middle aged patient was unable to find the spleen. However, his senior was able to trace some fibrous tissue in its normal location. The patient has no history of trauma or abdominal surgery. Which of the following could be the reason for the absence of the spleen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, the most likely reason is sickle cell anemia.

In patients with sickle cell anemia, the spleen is enlarged in early childhood because of red pulp congestion due to trapping of the sickled RBCs in the splenic cords and sinuses. However, with time, this stasis leads to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and shrinkage of the spleen. By adolescence, only a small fibrous remnant may be left behind in place of the normal spleen. This is known as autosplenectomy. 

The main pathology behind autosplenectomy is microvascular occlusion which occurs in patients with sickle cell anemia. In the parts of the body where the blood flow is sluggish — such as in inflamed areas, or in the cords of the spleen — there is a higher tendency for the sickled RBCs to adhere to the endothelium. This is because sickled red cells express higher amounts of adhesion molecules. Mediators released from granulocytes during an inflammatory process worsen this tendency.

Vascular occlusion due to the adhesion of the sickled RBCs to the vessel wall can cause infarcts in other tissues such as bones, brain and kidney as well. Painful bone crises due to vascular occlusion are common in children and can manifest as hand-foot syndrome (dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet), acute chest syndrome (involves the lung and presents with fever, cough, and chest pain) and priapism.

Thalassemia and hereditary spherocytosis both present with splenomegaly and not autosplenectomy.

questions.text: You notice a patient lying in the hospital compound with his attendant, to be seen by a psychiatrist. He does not react when you lend him a hand to make him stand. He doesn't move or respond to any other instruction given by the attendant. This behavior can be best described as:
questions.solution:
The behavior of not responding to instructions and external stimuli is known as negativism.

Negativism is a feature seen in catatonia. Verbal or nonverbal opposition to suggestions or advice is exhibited. There is resistance to efforts to be moved and the patient might even do the opposite of what is asked.

Catatonia is a condition seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses. It is a new diagnostic category in the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, fifth edition (DSM-5). A diagnosis of catatonia is not made if there is a primary mental disorder such as schizophrenia or psychotic depression, or if present during the course of delirium. 

Abnormal behaviors include grimacing, mutism, echolalia, stupor, and posturing. Wavy flexibility is marked by uniform resistance offered to passive positioning. Catalepsy is a passively inducted posture that is maintained against gravity by the patient. 

Some conditions that can cause catatonia include head trauma, encephalitis, and hepatic encephalopathy. Some medications such as corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, or antipsychotics can also result in the condition. It can also be seen in neuroleptic-induced parkinsonism and neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

The primary treatment for catatonia includes identifying and treating underlying medical or pharmacological causes. Any offending substances should be removed. Benzodiazepines are effective in reducing the symptoms of catatonia temporarily. Electroconvulsive therapy should be started for catatonia that is not responding to benzodiazepines and in severe cases with life-threatening conditions such as refusal to eat. 

Other options:

Option A: Mannerisms are normal movements that look odd and are involuntary. 

Option B: Stereotypy is purposeless repetitive speech or movements.

Option D: Echopraxia is characterized by mimicking an observed movement.

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

Related Pearl: Pharmacological treatment of psychosis

First-generation antipsychotics are generally not preferred due to the higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects/ tardive dyskinesia.

Second-generation antipsychotics are preferred drugs:

  • Risperidone
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Aripiprazole
  • Ziprasidone
  • Paliperidone

Benzodiazepines can be added to treat associated agitation. It is the drug of choice for catatonia.

Special situations:

  • Emergency: Use a short-acting intramuscular agent such as haloperidol, fluphenazine, olanzapine, or ziprasidone.
  • Chronic compliance: Long-acting injectable is used.
  • Treatment resistance (2 failed trials): Consider Clozapine.
  • All meds ineffective: May consider ECT.

questions.text: You are performing an autopsy on a patient with pyromania, who died due to burns sustained in a house fire. Presence of which of the following will indicate that the burns are postmortem in nature?
questions.solution:
Presence of blisters with thin, clear fluid is indicative of postmortem burns.

Blisters formed in postmortem burns are pale yellow with thin, clear fluid and dry, hard, yellow base.  Antemortem burns contain serous fluid with proteins and chlorides. Base is red and inflamed.

Option A: Marked cellular exudation and reactive tissue changes is called a vital reaction. This is characteristic of antemortem burns.

Option C: Curling's ulcer (stress ulcer) is an acute mucosal erosion resulting as a complication from severe burns commonly seen in the duodenum. They are seen in cases of antemortem burns.

Option D: In antemortem burns, a zone of hyperemia (line of redness), of variable width, is present at the edge of the burnt area. It is due to capillary dilatation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with Alzheimer's disease was brought by his daughter for a consultation. He has no difficulty in speaking and his comprehension of speech is intact. However, his daughter reports that he is unable to understand written instructions and pictures.  He also forgets the names of common objects. Which part of the cerebral cortex is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The inability to name objects and the inability to understand written instructions and pictures suggest anomic aphasia, which is seen with lesions in the angular gyrus. This is because visual information is not processed and transmitted to the Wernicke area.

 The angular gyrus processes information from words that are read in such a way that they can be converted into the auditory forms of the words in Wernicke's area. When a lesion damages the angular gyrus, without affecting Wernicke or Broca areas:

  • Speech is intact
  • Comprehension is intact
  • Repetition is intact
  • Confrontation naming impaired (there is difficulty in understanding written language or pictures)
  • Word-finding and spelling are impaired. 

The lesion sites can be anywhere within the left hemisphere language network, including the angular gyrus, middle and inferior temporal gyri. Anomic aphasia is commonly seen in the following conditions:

  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Metabolic encephalopathy
  • Head trauma

Other options:

Option B: Wernicke’s area is located at the parieto-temporal junction. A lesion here causes fluent aphasia. The speech itself is normal but it is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense. The patient also fails to comprehend the meaning of spoken or written words, so other aspects of the use of language are compromised.

Option C: Lesions at the superior temporal gyrus cause pure word deafness. Comprehension of spoken language and repetition is impaired. Naming and fluency is preserved. Most commonly due to bilateral or left-sided MCA strokes

Option D: Lesions at the right inferior temporal lobe can cause prosopagnosia, which is the inability to recognize faces. The storage and recognition of faces are strongly represented in the right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent urinary tract infections. An intravenous urogram suggested the presence of a duplicated collecting system. Which of the following rules is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The Weigert-Meyer law is applicable in the case of duplicated collecting system.

According to the Weigert-Meyer rule of congenital complete duplication of the ureter, the ureter draining the upper segment of the kidney inserts in the bladder inferior and medial to the ureter draining the lower segment of the kidney. The lower moiety of the completely duplicated system is generally normal. 

The upper ureter is considered ectopic and the lower ureter is considered orthotopic. Ectopic ureters are more prone to obstruction. Orthotopic ureters are more prone to reflux due to perpendicular entry into bladder musculature rather than oblique entry.

Other options:

Option B: The percentage of burns is calculated in a given patient according to Wallace’s rule of nine.

Option C: Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

Option D: Jenkin's rule for abdominal closure states that the length of the suture should be at least four times the length of the wound.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 presents at 30 weeks of gestation with complaints of breathlessness. On examination, her fundal height was greater than the period of gestation. The uterus felt tense, and there was difficulty palpating fetal parts. Fetal heart sounds auscultated with difficulty. USG showed a single deepest vertical pocket of 10 cm and a sign given below. Which of the following can cause the above condition?

  1. Varicella
  2. Hepatitis B
  3. Parvovirus B19
  4. HIV
  5. Cytomegalovirus
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario the history, examination findings and USG showing polyhydramnios (single deepest vertical pocket-10cm) and Buddha sign/Halo sign is suggestive of hydrops fetalis. Human immunodeficiency virus and hepatitis B are not a cause of nonimmune hydrops fetalis.

Hydrops is diagnosed by identifying two or more fetal effusions—pleural, pericardial, or ascites—or one effusion plus anasarca. Hydrops can be seen in association with red cell auto immunization, which is termed immune hydrops. Otherwise, it is nonimmune hydrops.

Pathogenesis of hydrops includes decreased colloid oncotic pressure, increased hydrostatic or central venous pressure, and enhanced vascular permeability. Sonographically measured skin thickness of >5 mm constitutes edema or anasarca. 

Etiology of hydrops fetalis

Cardiovascular

  • Structural defects:
    • Ebstein anomaly,
    • Tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve,
    • Hypoplastic left or right heart,
    • Premature closure of ductus arteriosus,
    • Arteriovenous malformation (vein of Galen aneurysm)
  • Cardiomyopathies
  • Tachyarrhythmias
  • Bradycardia

Chromosomal

  • Turner syndrome (45,X), triploidy,
  • Trisomies 21, 18, and 13

Hematological

  • Hemoglobinopathies, such as α4-thalassemia
  • Decreased erythrocyte production (myeloproliferative disorders)
  • Fetomaternal hemorrhage

Lymphatic Abnormalities

  • Cystic hygroma,
  • Systemic lymphangiectasis,
  • Pulmonary lymphangiectasis

  • Syphilis,

questions.text: All of the following favour a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Painless diarrhoea or constipation does not favour the diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). 

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterised by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. Since there is no specific diagnostic marker for IBS, the diagnosis is based on Rome IV criteria, which include the clinical manifestations of the disease. Abdominal pain is an anchor feature of IBS. It should be associated (improvement or worsening) with defecation or with a change in the frequency or form of stool. Painless diarrhoea or constipation does not fulfil the criteria to be diagnosed as IBS. The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of IBS.

The extent of the diagnostic evaluation of a patient suspected to have IBS depends on the possibility of an organic disorder in that patient. A complete blood count and a sigmoidoscopy should be done for most patients. In addition, stool samples should be examined for ova and parasites in patients who have diarrhoea-predominant IBS. The mainstay of treatment for IBS is a diet low in fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols (FODMAPs). Pharmacotherapy consists of Alosetron (5-HT3 antagonist) or Loperamide for diarrhoea-predominant IBS and psyllium husk, lactulose, Lubiprostone, and Prucalopride (5-HT4 agonist) for constipation-predominant IBS. Peppermint oil is effective in improving abdominal pain associated with IBS, but probiotics have shown no benefit.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: A fisherman presenting with the following skin lesion is suspected to have Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae infection. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A fisherman presenting with a characteristic seal finger or whale finger lesion with suspected Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae infection is suggestive of erysipeloid.

The most common E. rhusiopathiae infection in humans is called erysipeloid. It usually occurs on the fingers by direct inoculation at the site of a cut or abrasion, especially in persons handling animals, fish, or animal products like fishermen, abattoir workers, and butchers.

After 2–7 days of incubation period, severe pain and swelling of fingers occur. The lesions are painful, edematous, well-circumscribed, and violaceous in color giving a seal finger or whale finger-like appearance. Pus is usually not present at the site of infection, which helps differentiate it from staphylococcal and streptococcal skin infections. Erysipeloid can resolve without treatment after 3–4 weeks. It would resolve more rapidly with antibiotic treatment.

Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is a slender, non-sporing, non-capsulated, nonmotile, Gram-positive bacillus with a tendency to form filaments. When Erysipelothrix is grown on triple sugar iron (TSI) agar, hydrogen sulfide is produced, turning the TSI black.

Other options:

Option B: Erysipelas is a skin infection involving superficial lymphatics. It is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (β-Hemolytic Group A Streptococci). It presents with raised, erythematous sharply demarcated rapidly spreading skin lesions (Shown in the image below), along with systemic symptoms. Legs and face are the most common sites affected.

Option C: Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It presents as hemorrhagic necrosis of the skin surrounded by erythema (Shown in the image below).

Option D: Ecthyma contagiosum is a viral zoonotic disease caused by the parapox virus.The lesion develops 5–6 days after contact with an infected animal or animal carcass. A small, firm, red, or reddish-blue papule appears at the skin site of contact and enlarges into a hemorrhagic pustule or bulla (Shown in the image below).

questions.text:
The HHH syndrome is caused due to the deficiency of _______.

HHH- Hyperornithinemia, Hyperammonemia and Homocitrullinuria.
questions.solution:
The HHH syndrome is caused due to the deficiency of the ornithine transporter.

HHH syndrome is caused by a defect in the transport system of ornithine from the cytosol into the mitochondria (ORNT1 gene) resulting in the accumulation of ornithine in the cytosol and a deficiency of this amino acid in mitochondria. The accumulation of cytosolic ornithine leads to hyperammonemia and hyperornithinemia. Homocitrulline is formed from the reaction of mitochondrial carbamyl phosphate with lysine. When ornithine is deficient, it leads to homocitrullinuria.

Components of HHH syndrome:

  • Hyperammonemia
  • Hyperornithinemia
  • homocitrullinuria

Other options:

Option A: Arginase deficiency leads to hyperargininemia. Increased arginine levels are seen in blood and CSF.

Option C: Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency leads to hyperammonemia type II. Orotic aciduria occurs due to the redirection of carbamoyl phosphate into pyrimidine synthesis.

Option D: Carbamoyl phosphatase synthetase I deficiency leads to hyperammonemia type I. Presents with mental retardation.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A patient on anti-tubercular treatment presents with a tingling sensation and paresthesia in the lower limbs. Which of the following enzyme assay is used to diagnose the deficient vitamin in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of tingling sensation and paresthesias in a patient on anti-tubercular treatment are suggestive of the adverse effect of isoniazid. The vitamin deficient in this patient is pyridoxine/vitamin B6. Therefore, the RBC transaminase enzyme assay is used to diagnose vitamin B6 deficiency. 

Isoniazid is the first-line antitubercular drug that inhibits the production of mycolic acid. It is a bactericidal drug against tubercle bacilli. Important side effects of isoniazid include peripheral neuritis, hepatitis, anemia, rashes, and arthralgia.

Peripheral neuritis occurs due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Patients present with clinical features of pyridoxine/vitamin B6 deficiency, which include paresthesias, numbness, and tingling sensation.

The most widely used method to know the vitamin B6 nutritional status is by measuring the RBC transaminase activity, by adding pyridoxal phosphate in vitro. Direct measurement of the plasma concentrations of the vitamin (pyridoxal phosphate) can also be done.

Therefore, 10 mg/day of pyridoxine is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with the lesion shown below. On examination, a firm plaque with serpiginous finger-like projection with central atrophy was noted. She is a known case of tuberculosis and has completed the treatment. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario the likely diagnosis is tuberculosis verrucosa cutis. It is caused by exogenous inoculation of M. tuberculosis into the skin through open wounds or abrasions. Lesions appear at the site of inoculation. They appear as verrucous plaque which extends with a serpiginous outline with finger‐like projections. The center of the lesion may have a white atrophic scar.

It is also known as anatomist’s warts, prosector’s warts and verruca necrogenica.  It occurs in a person who is already sensitized by previous exposure to TB. Thus it is a form of post-primary TB. Patients having this condition have good immunity against TB. Because of good immunity, they are effective in clearing the TB bacilli and thus, the lesion is paucibacillary. This condition is treated with anti-tubercular drugs. 

Other options- 

Option A- Lupus vulgaris originates from an underlying focus of tuberculosis, typically in a bone, joint, or lymph node, or maybe from the hematogenous and lymphatic spread. It presents as a slowly enlarging plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy. The edges of the lesion gradually extend in some areas and heal with scarring in others. In India, the buttocks, and trunk are more frequently involved. Apple jelly nodules are demonstrated on diascopy.

The below image shows Lupus vulgaris: 

Option C- Lichen scrofulosorum is a type of tuberculid. It occurs due to hypersensitivity to the active tubercular infection. They appear as closely grouped lichenoid papules. The lesions are usually skin coloured and are often perifollicular. The papule may have an adherent crust or small pustule.

The below image shows Lichen scrofulosorum. 

Option D- Scrofuloderma results from the direct invasion of the tubercle bacillus into the skin from an underlying contiguous tuberculous focus. It commonly occurs in children. It begins as bluish-red subcutaneous swellings, which ulcerate to form discharging sinuses.

The below image shows Scrofuloderma.

questions.text: A body of a 30-year-old man is retrieved from the local river and subjected to autopsy. His family accuses his friend of murdering him by pushing him into the river after making him unconscious by hitting his head with a wooden stick. Which autopsy finding will favor the family's accusation?
questions.solution:
The finding of edema aquosum in the autopsy will favor the family's accusation. Edema aquosum occurs when the victim is alive but unconscious at the time of the drowning. This is mere flooding of the lungs with the water without the formation of froth as respiratory efforts are absent.

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth - The presence of copious amounts of fine, shaving-lather-like froth at the mouth and the nostrils is the most characteristic finding of antemortem drowning. It is caused by the vigorous agitation of the tracheal and bronchial mucous secretions, edema fluid, and alveolar surfactant during respiratory efforts. 
  • Cutis anserina - The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin. This resembles goose skin; hence, it is called cutis anserina.
  • Washerwoman’s hand - Maceration of the skin on the palms and soles gives a wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance due to submersion.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning. The material also indicates the place of submersion.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Face - It is bloated and discolored, with cyanosis.
  • Eyes - Conjunctiva are suffused and pupils dilated.
  • Tongue - It may be swollen and protruded.
  • Antemortem injuries - These may be sustained by striking objects, such as rocks, during the fall into the water body. Examination for such injuries must be performed only after the body is dry.
  • Lungs - They appear voluminous and distended show ballooning. The cut section will exude copious amounts of frothy, bloodstained fluid.
  • Larynx, trachea, and bronchioles - The presence of sand, silt, and aquatic vegetation in the trachea and lower respiratory tract are characteristic findings of antemortem drowning.
  • Heart and blood vessels- Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. 
  • Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Stomach and small intestines- These organs may contain water in some cases. Water present in the small intestine is positive evidence of death by drowning.
  • Middle ear - The presence of water in the middle ear is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Brain - It is congested, and edematous, with loss of gray-white junction.

Other options:

Option B: Hydrostatic lung, is seen in postmortem drowning. When a dead body is thrown into the water, water passes into the lungs due to hydrostatic pressure. 

Option C: Emphysema aquosum - This is seen in cases when the victim is alive and conscious. Overinflation of the lungs in drowning is known as emphysema aquosum. It is one of the most valuable positive signs of drowning. The edema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death. Hence, the lungs are held in the inspiratory position. The impression of the ribs on this overinflated lung leaves visible and palpable grooves on the lateral surface. 

Option D: Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning. In postmortem drowning, diatoms do not spread to distant organs because of the absence of circulation and are limited to the lungs.

questions.text: The X-ray of a 10-year-old boy with fever, drooling of saliva, and stridor is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and thumb sign on the x-ray is acute epiglottitis.

Causative organisms are Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus.

Clinical features include high fever, sore throat, dyspnea, drooling, and progressing respiratory obstruction. Stridor appears late and indicates near-complete respiratory obstruction. Child sits in tripod position to relieve the obstruction.

Laryngoscopy shows large, cherry-red, swollen epiglottis. X-ray of lateral view of neck shows thumb sign. Management is to give antibiotics and emergency endotracheal intubation is done as required.

Other options:

Option-A: Retropharyngeal abscess is often polymicrobial caused by streptococcus, staphylococcus, and anaerobes. Clinical features include fever, drooling, neck stiffness, muffled voice, and trismus. Management is by giving intravenous antibiotics with or without surgical drainage.

Option-B: Laryngomalacia is a congenital anomaly presenting with inspiratory stridor which is low-pitched and exacerbated by crying or feeding. Symptoms usually appear within the first two weeks of life. Most symptoms resolve spontaneously as the child and airway grow.

Option C: Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup) is a viral infection. Clinical features include low-grade fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness. Steeple sign is seen on the x-ray due to subglottic narrowing. If the child is hypoxic, immediate airway management is done.

questions.text: A young girl presented with bilateral visual loss, peripheral neuropathy, and postural tremors. The fundus examination showed optic atrophy. Pedigree chart of the disease is given below. What is the pattern of inheritance?
questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern shown above is mitochondrial inheritance.

The clinical features and inheritance pattern is suggestive of Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy, which is characterized by bilateral visual loss, severe optic atrophy, psychiatric symptoms, peripheral neuropathy, cardiac conduction abnormalities, and sometimes white matter lesions. Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy is a prototype of mitochondrial inheritance. It occurs due to a mitochondrial DNA mutation. This results in impaired mitochondrial adenosine triphosphate production, which affects the highly energy-dependent optic nerve.

Mitochondrial inheritance is caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome. Inheritance is exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperm contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization. Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease. 

Features of mitochondrial inheritance:

  • Mutation in the mitochondrial gene is either due to deletion or point mutation.
  • Mitochondrial defect in the mother can affect both the male and female gender but a father with a mitochondrial defect cannot pass it to the next generation. 
  • A cell can have both normal and abnormal mitochondrial genomes, and this phenomenon is referred to as heteroplasmy.
