questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn is referred with repetitive vomiting and diarrhea. On examination, the baby is jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Based on further evaluation, a diagnosis of classical galactosemia is made. On which of the following steps does the enzyme responsible for the condition act?
questions.solution:
Classical galactosemia is caused to deficient galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. The enzyme is responsible for the conversion of galactose 1-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate in the metabolism of galactose.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

Option A: Uridine diphosphate galactose 4-epimerase helps in the conversion of UDP galactose to UDP glucose. Features are similar to transferase deficiency with additional findings of hypotonia and nerve deafness.

Option B: Galactokinase is the enzyme responsible for the conversion of galactose to galactose 1-phosphate. Here the symptoms are milder. This is because galactose-1-phosphate is not formed and hence no toxic effects of this compound are manifested. Only cataract is seen.

questions.text: A patient presents with low-grade fever, chest pain, cough, and hemoptysis. Radiological examination of the chest reveals cavity formation with lung abscess. The culture of the specimen shows the appearance given in the image, at 37°C. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image above showing thick-walled round yeast cells with single broad-based budding depicting the figure of 8 appearance, in the culture at 37°C is suggestive of Blastomycosis dermatitidis. It causes North American blastomycosis.

Blastomycosis is a chronic infection caused by a dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. It is characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions in the lungs and skin. It is most common in North America and is also called North American Blastomycosis.

Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores in contaminated soil.

Blastomycosis can present in three forms:

  • Pulmonary infection - can be asymptomatic, focal or diffuse consolidation, miliary lesions or abscess formation. 
  • Disseminated disease - can lead to multiple abscesses and has high fatality.
  • Cutaneous disease over the skin of the face. Lesions may be a papule, around which secondary nodules develop and coalesce to form elevated ulcerative lesions. 

B. dermatitidis when cultured at 37°C shows thick-walled round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud.

Localized lesions are effectively managed with itraconazole for 6 months. Invasive or severe cases are treated with amphotericin B.

Other Options:

Option A: Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes Brazilian/South American blastomycosis.

Option C: Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis/Darling's disease.

Option D: Coccidioides immitis causes valley fever.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A patient with a  prior history of radiotherapy is now diagnosed with post-menopausal osteoporosis. Which of the following drugs cannot be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Teriparatide cannot be given to a woman diagnosed with post-menopausal osteoporosis, with a prior history of radiation. It increases the risk of osteosarcoma.

Teriparatide is a recombinant preparation of parathyroid hormone. It increases bone formation especially when given in low doses and intermittently.

The pharmacologic activity of teriparatide, which is similar to the physiologic activity of PTH, includes stimulating osteoblast function, increasing gastrointestinal calcium absorption, and increasing renal tubular reabsorption of calcium. It is administered subcutaneously every day.

Teriparatide increases the risk of osteosarcoma and it is contraindicated in conditions that cause a high risk of osteosarcoma such as:

  • Paget's disease
  • Prior h/o of radiotherapy
  • Young adults with open epiphysis
  • Unexplained elevated ALP
  • Hypercalcemia

Option A: Calcitonin decreases bone resorption and increases bone mass in patients with osteoporosis.

Option B: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator, which decreases bone resorption. It is used to prevent and treat osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.

Option C: Bisphosphonates like alendronate and etidronate decrease bone resorption.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with fever, sore throat, polyarthralgia, erythema marginatum, and chest pain. A rapid streptococcal antigen is found to be positive. Physical examination is remarkable for a loud friction rub. Which of the following is most likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. Serous pericarditis is seen in acute rheumatic fever.

  • Serous pericarditis:
    • It is seen in rheumatic fever, SLE, systemic scleroderma, tumors, uremia, viral infection, or tuberculosis
    • Mild inflammation of epicardial and pericardial surfaces: both acute and chronic inflammatory cells
    • Exudative serous fluid, usually 50–200 mL; thus, it develops slowly and rarely alters cardiac function
  • Suppurative (purulent) pericarditis:
    • Bacterial, mycotic, or parasitic invasion
    • Enter pericardial space by direct extension, seeding from blood, lymphatic spread, seeding by instrumentation
    • Inflammation may extend into surrounding mediastinum
    • Usually, results in the organization and, therefore, constrictive pericarditis with clinical sequelae
  • Hemorrhagic pericarditis:
    • Tuberculosis or malignant neoplasm (from lung or breast)
    • Can also be seen following cardiac surgery
  • Caseous pericarditis: 
    • Almost always tubercular in origin

questions.text: A 19-year-old football player was brought to the hospital after he suffered an ​injury caused by a lateral blow to the knee joint. MRI revealed the injury to the ligaments commonly referred to as the unhappy triad. Which of the following ligament is not involved in the unhappy triad?
questions.solution:
The ligaments involved in the unhappy triad of knee joint are medial meniscus, anterior cruciate ligament, and tibial collateral ligament. It is also known as O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triangle.

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

The image below shows the unhappy triad of the knee joint on MRI (PDW SPIR):

  1. Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Rupture of the medial collateral ligament
  3. Inner meniscal tear (image shows complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-month-old female child to the outpatient department. She was delivered by C-section. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios and breech presentation. On examination of the child, you notice the finding shown in the image below. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A Pavlik harness after closed reduction is the most appropriate management for this infant, with history and examination suggestive of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The image shows one knee (affected knee) at a lower level compared to the other, which is known as Galeazzi's sign.

Developmental dysplasia of the hip or congenital dysplasia of the hip is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. Risk factors for DDH include-

  • Sex of the baby - Female gender is more susceptible 
  • Intrauterine positioning - Breech position 
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Genetic predisposition 

Examination of the developmental dysplasia of the hip-

  • Tests to check instability of the hip -
    • Ortolani test: To perform this test, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. With the thumb placed over the medial thigh and the index finger on the greater trochanter, the hip is gently abducted. This reduces the femoral head into the acetabulum producing a palpable "clunk". 
    • Barlow test: This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. To perform this test, the infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. Gentle adduction results in a posterior subluxation or dislocation of an easily dislocatable femoral head, producing a palpable "clunk"
  • Galeazzi's test is shown in the above image. It is done between 3 to 8-month aged children in unilateral cases of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). To perform this test, the child is in the supine position with the hip and knee in flexion. The level of both the knee joints is noted with respect to a horizontal line. Normally both knees should be at the same level. In DDH, the affected knee is seen at a lower level indicating femoral shortening. This is also known as the Allis sign. 
  • Marked asymmetry of the inguinal, gluteal, thigh, or popliteal folds.
  • Decreased abduction on the affected side.
  • Positive tredelenburg sign
  • Limb-length discrepancy

Treatment of DDH includes early closed reduction with splinting or casts. If closed reduction cannot be achieved in long-standing dislocations, an open reduction may become necessary.

  • < 6 months: Closed reduction with Pavlik harness or Von Rosen splint is done.  
  • 6-18 months: Closed or open reduction with hip spica application is done.
  • 1.5 years- 3 years: Open reduction and pelvic or femoral osteotomies may be required
  • 3-8 years: Femoral shortening or pelvic osteotomies.
  • >8 years: Femoral and pelvic osteotomies or total hip replacement considered

Related Pearl: Age wise management of DDH

AGE OF THE PATIENT                 MANAGEMENT

6-18 months Closed or open reduction followed by hip spica after reduction
18-36 months Open reduction with femoral shortening and pelvic osteotomy (Salter's osteotomy, Pemberton osteotomy, Steel osteotomy)
3-8 year Open reduction with femoral shortening and pelvic osteotomy 
8-18 year

Open procedure with femoral shortening with pelvic osteotomy or total hip replacement

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient presents with bradykinesia and symmetrical rigidity. He also gives a history of two episodes of syncope in the past month and mentions that he often feels dizzy on getting up. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with bradykinesia and symmetrical rigidity, along with episodes of syncope and orthostatic hypotension (suggestive of autonomic dysfunction), a diagnosis of multiple system atrophy is the most likely. 

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a disease entity that comprises of autonomic dysfunction and either parkinsonism or cerebellar syndrome. The parkinsonism seen in MSA is atypical because it is symmetrical and axial. The tremor is also not prominent. Although autonomic abnormalities can be seen in advanced PD, they are more severe and generalized in MSA. Autonomic dysfunction often presents as orthostatic hypotension, which can cause symptoms ranging from dimming of vision to syncope. Syncope occurs when the drop in BP impairs cerebral perfusion. Symptomatic orthostatic hypotension occuring within 1 year of onset of parkinsonism is typically encountered in MSA.

Other options: 

Option B: The classic clinical features of Parkinson's disease (PD) include resting tremors, asymmetrical rigidity and akinesia. The rigidity is more peripheral than axial and usually involves the upper limbs first. Moreover, autonomic dysfunction is more prominent and early in MSA than in PD. 

Option C: Although progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) can also present with rigidity, it is usually symmetrical and axial in contrast to PD. The key clinical feature unique to PSP is a progressive oculomotor syndrome, beginning with square wave jerks and eventually progressing to supranuclear ophthalmoparesis. The patient develops a complete downward gaze paresis. This is not seen in PD or MSA.

Option D: Lewy body dementia (LBD) is characterized by early psychosis and well-formed visual hallucinations in addition to parkinsonism features like rigidity and bradykinesia.

questions.text: A man who was stuck inside a building that caught fire was rescued and brought to the hospital. What is the cause of his oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifting to the left?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient most likely has carbon monoxide poisoning due to smoke inhalation. In carbon monoxide poisoning, the affinity of Hb for CO is about 200 times more than that for O2, and hence, the carboxyhemoglobin releases the CO into the blood very slowly. The O2–Hb dissociation curve of the remaining hemoglobin shifts to the left.

Treatment of CO poisoning consists of ventilation with oxygen since oxygen hastens the dissociation of carboxyhemoglobin. 

The other options such as acidosis, increased pCO2 and hyperthermia will shift the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right.

questions.text: The given image shows the synthesis and release of GABA in the nerve terminal. Identify the drug that acts at site A.
questions.solution:
The drug that acts at the site 'A' is baclofen.

Baclofen is a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. It is an analog of the inhibitory transmitter GABA and acts as a selective GABAB receptor agonist. It also acts at the spinal cord where it decreases excitatory transmitter release of excitatory neurotransmitter release.

Baclofen is used for the treatment of spasticity in multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, spinal injuries, and flexor spasm. In these conditions, baclofen is the preferred drug for symptomatic relief.

It can also be administered intrathecally around the spinal cord through a catheter placed surgically. Side effects of baclofen include drowsiness, mental confusion, weakness, and ataxia.

Other options:

Option A: Benzodiazepines are allosteric modulators of the GABAA receptor that bind at the α/γ interface of the receptor. This increases the affinity of the GABAA receptor for GABA thus increasing the frequency of the opening of the chloride channel. They are selective CNS depressants that produce sedation, relieve anxiety, facilitate sleep, suppress seizures, and reduce muscle tone.

Option B: Tiagabine inhibits the GABA transporter GAT-1 and thereby reduces GABA uptake into neurons and glia and prolongs the action of GABA in the synapse. It is also used as an adjunct therapy for partial seizures with or without secondary generalization.

Option D: Gabapentin is an anti-epileptic drug that acts by binding to α2δ protein. It is used in focal onset seizures, neuropathic pains like post-herpetic neuralgia, and neuropathic pain. The most common adverse effects seen with gabapentin are increased drowsiness, ataxia, and fatigue.

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient with ascending flaccid paralysis was diagnosed to have Guillian-Barré syndrome. Which of the following clinical features would go against this diagnosis?

choices.text: Presence of fever at the onset of the weakness
Aching or throbbing pain of lower limbs

questions.solution:
In a patient with Guillian-Barré syndrome, fever and constitutional symptoms are absent at the onset of weakness. If present, alternate diagnoses should be considered. 

Guillian-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute, autoimmune polyneuropathy. The usual presentation is symmetrical, ascending paralysis evolving over hours to a few days. The legs are usually more affected than the arms. Lower cranial nerves are also frequently involved, causing bulbar weakness and difficulty in maintaining an airway and handling secretions. Almost one-third of the patients require mechanical ventilation due to weakness of the respiratory muscles. Deep tendon reflexes also attenuate or disappear within a few days of onset. 

Sensations carried by large myelinated fibers like deep tendon reflexes and proprioception are also affected. Pain and temperature sensations are relatively preserved. Pain in the neck, shoulder, back, buttocks, and thighs is a common complaint in the early phase of the disease. The pain is usually aching or throbbing in nature. Autonomic involvement is also frequent in patients with GBS and usually presents with loss of vasomotor control with wide fluctuations in blood pressure and postural hypotension.

The patient is likely to have clinical worsening during the first four weeks following the onset of weakness. After this, there's a plateauing of the symptoms and any further deterioration is unlikely.

Although fever might be present during the antecedent infection (for example, Campylobacter diarrhea) which acted as a trigger for GBS, fever and constitutional symptoms are absent at the onset of the weakness. Similarly, bladder dysfunction occurs only in severe GBS and is transient. Prominent bladder dysfunction occurring early in the disease course goes against the diagnosis of GBS.

questions.text: A 12-year-old female patient presented with complaints of chest pain, palpitations, and fatigue. On auscultation, a high-pitch diastolic heart murmur was heard over the second intercostal space to the left of the sternum. The mean-QRS axis on ECG is 150 degrees. The arterial blood oxygen content is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most-likely diagnosis is pulmonic regurgitation.

The heart murmur was heard over the 2nd left intercostal space, to the left of the sternum, which is the pulmonary area for cardiac auscultation. The high-pitch indicates regurgitation.

The mean-QRS vector is normally oriented at +59 degrees.  In the given patient, the mean-QRS axis on ECG is 150 degrees which is suggestive of right-axis deviation, indicating hypertrophy of the right side of the heart.

Among the given options, both Tetralogy of Fallot and pulmonic regurgitation are associated with a right-axis deviation. However, in tetralogy of the Fallot, the arterial oxygen concentration is low. However, in the given patient the oxygen concentration is normal, which rules out TOF.

questions.text: An obese diabetic patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. His arterial blood pH is 7.2 and his urine is positive for glucose and ketones. His blood glucose level is 130 mg/dL. Which anti-diabetic drug was the patient likely on?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis with euglycemia, which is an adverse effect of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors such as canagliflozin. 

Inhibition of SGLT2 and consequent decrease in blood glucose levels stimulates glucagon. Glucagon increases the production of glucose and ketones in the liver. SGLT2 inhibitors can cause euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) because of the increased excretion of glucose in the urine. Euglycemic DKA can occur at times of stress or when ongoing glycosuria masks the stress-induced requirements of insulin. This is why SGLT2 inhibitors should not be prescribed to patients with type I diabetes mellitus or pancreatogenic forms of diabetes mellitus which are associated with insulin deficiency.

SGLT2 is a Na+-glucose cotransporter that is located in the proximal convoluted tubule of the kidney. They reabsorb glucose and sodium from the tubular lumen back into the blood through the epithelial cells. SGLT2 inhibitors block the transport of glucose in the proximal tubule and promote glycosuria and hence lower blood glucose. The currently available SGLT2 inhibitors are canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin. Other than decreasing blood glucose they also decrease systolic blood pressure and cause weight loss. Empagliflozin and canagliflozin reduce the risk of major cardiovascular events in patients with established diabetes mellitus. All SGLT2 inhibitors have been shown to reduce the incidence of hospitalization in CHF and reduced the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

The main side effect of SGLT2 inhibitors because of their glycosuric properties is an increase in lower urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections. Dapagliflozin is associated with a possible risk of bladder cancer, while canagliflozin is associated with an increased risk of fractures.

questions.text: A 78-year-old diabetic male patient presents with a week-long history of severe pain and discharge from the right ear and pain in the jaw while chewing. Examination reveals tenderness, multiple cranial nerve palsies, and granulation tissue on the floor of the external auditory canal. Which of the following can be used for diagnosis and follow up in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly diabetic developing severe pain, discharge from the right ear associated with pain while chewing, multiple cranial nerve palsies, and the finding of granulation tissue in the inferior portion of the external auditory canal, is suggestive of malignant otitis externa. Gallium-67 scan can be used for diagnosis and follow-up in this condition.

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is an inflammatory condition seen in elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs due to pseudomonal infection. It is an infective condition and not a malignant condition. It mimics diffuse otitis externa associated with excruciating pain, discharge, and granulations on the floor of EAC. Bony erosion aids in the spread of infection. Facial paralysis is common. Multiple cranial nerve palsies can occur when the infection spreads to the skull base and jugular foramen. The infection can spread anteriorly into the temporomandibular fossa. 

Diagnosis: Severe ear pain associated with granulation tissue in the external auditory canal in a diabetic patient should raise the suspicion of malignant otitis externa. CT scan helps in detecting bony erosions and demineralization of the bones. Gallium-67 is more useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection but cannot be used to monitor the disease as the test remains positive for a year or so. (Option B)

Treatment: The treatment of malignant otitis external would include control of diabetes, ear toileting to remove the discharge, debris, or granulation tissue, antibiotic therapy against Pseudomonas with fluoroquinolones, third-generation cephalosporins, beta-lactam antibiotics with/without aminoglycosides.

Other options:

Option A: Iridium 192 radioisotope can be used in brachytherapy to treat tumors by selectively delivering a cytotoxic dose of radiation to the tumor site.

Option D: Phosphorus 32 is used to label DNA and proteins.It has been used to treat polycythemia vera and certain types of leukemia.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old girl comes for treatment of hirsutism. She has irregular periods. She is obese and has facial acne as well. Androstenedione and testosterone levels are elevated. LH levels are raised and FSH is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for the condition?

LH- Luteinizing hormone 

FSH- Follicle-stimulating hormone

OCP- Oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of hirsutism, irregular periods, acne, and obesity with elevated androgens, normal FSH, and raised LH are suggestive of polycystic ovary disease (PCOD). In PCOD, the drug used for hirsutism and acne is OCPs with cyproterone acetate. Cyproterone has an anti-androgenic effect.

Management of PCOD is individualized. Weight reduction and lifestyle changes are the first-line therapy for PCOD. In a woman who is not planning for pregnancy, the management mainly involves treatment of irregular periods and hirsutism. Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. Hirsutism and acne are managed with OCP with cyproterone acetate and topical agents such as eflornithine, clindamycin lotion 1%, erythromycin gel 2%, and isoretinoin. 

Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin and acarbose. Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical management includes laparoscopic ovarian drilling (LOD)in resistant cases and bariatric surgery in morbidly obese patients.

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)/ Polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD): It is also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome.

It is a multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. It has multifactorial causation, such as lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemic states.

Important clinical features of PCOS are:

  • Menstrual abnormalities (70%) - oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, or dysfunctional uterine bleeding. Dysmenorrhoea is absent.
  • Obesity
  • Hirsutism, acne, and alopecia due to hyperandrogenism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance
  • Infertility

Rotterdam criterion is used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Oligo/amenorrhoea, anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries (USG findings)

questions.text: Following anthropometric evaluation, a child is diagnosed to have chronic malnutrition. Decrease of which of the following measures will be most specific for it?
questions.solution:
A child with chronic malnutrition will have low height-for-age and low weight-for-age. Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition while low weight-for-age can be seen in both acute and chronic malnutrition.

The nutritional status of a child is assessed in terms of anthropometry:

The World Health Organization (WHO) has established international standards for normal child growth from birth to 5 years of age. The normalization of the anthropometric measures is done in terms of z-scores (standard deviation scores). The anthropometric indicators are marked in a growth chart which is compared with a reference curve.

The anthropometric measures used are weight for age, height for age, weight for height, BMI, and mid-upper arm circumference.

  • Low weight-for-height, or wasting, usually indicates acute malnutrition.
  • High weight-for-height indicates overweight.
  • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population. 
  • Low weight-for-age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

questions.text: Which of the following will cause the cell cycle to stop at the G1-S checkpoint?
questions.solution:
p53 accumulation in the cell causes transcription of CDKN1A gene, which produces p21 protein. p21 inhibits CDK4/cyclin D complexes, thereby maintaining RB in hypophosphorylated and active state. This blocks the cell cycle progression at G1-S checkpoint. 

G1-S checkpoint is predominantly regulated by retinoblastoma (RB) gene. During the normal progression of the cell cycle, there is an increase in the levels of CDK4/cyclin D, CDK6/cyclin D and CDK2/cyclin E. This leads to hyperphosphorylation and consequent inhibition of RB. This releases E2F transcription factors from RB, and they drive the expression of the genes which are required to progress to the S-phase of the cell cycle. While growth factors accelerate this entire process and upregulate the activity of CDK/cyclin complexes, growth inhibitors increase CDK inhibitors.

TP53, which is a tumor suppressor gene, also plays a role in cell cycle progression. Ionization radiation, carcinogens and other forms of oncogenic stressors activate TP53. p53 accumulation in the cell can bring about the following outcomes to prevent the neoplastic transformation of the cell:

  • Cell cycle arrest at G1-S can occur because of p21 protein, which blocks CDK4/cyclin D complex. This pause in the cell cycle is utilized for DNA repair.
  • Cellular senescence (permanent cell cycle arrest) can occur.
  • Apoptosis of cells with irreversible DNA damage can be induced by p53.

MDM2 protein stimulates the degradation of p53 and will thus move the cell cycle forward.

questions.text: A newly joined trainee at the gymnasium was able to lift about 8 Kilograms of weight using both his upper limbs. When two more kilograms were added, he could not resist and had dropped the weight down. Which receptor and nerve fiber are responsible for his inability to bear the weight?

choices.text: Golgi tendon organ and Ib fiber
Golgi tendon organ and Ia fiber

questions.solution:
The Golgi tendon organ and Ib fiber are responsible for his inability to bear the weight.

Here, in the scenario given, two types of physiological reflexes have happened.

  • Stretch reflex/myotatic reflex - This has been responsible for the ability to bear the initial 8 kgs of weight by the trainee.
  • Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex - When two more kgs have been added, this has brought the inhibition of motor neuron discharge to his muscles which are responsible for his inability to bear the weight.

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite of the stretch reflex.

When the tension on the muscle becomes extreme, the inhibitory effect from the Golgi tendon organ, carried by Ib afferents, leads to instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction.

It is a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone.

Note: Muscle spindles senses changes in muscle length (stretch).

questions.text: A patient presenting with fever and acute stabbing type of chest pain is suspected to have Bornholm disease. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Bornholm disease or epidemic pleurodynia is caused by Coxsackie group B viruses.

Bornholm disease is a febrile disease with sharp piercing chest pain. Onset is abrupt but sometimes can be preceded by malaise, headache, and anorexia. The chest pain may last from 2 days to 2 weeks. There might be associated abdominal pain, and this may be the chief complaint in children.

The illness is usually self-limited and recovery is complete. Relapses are common.

questions.text: A young man presented with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. Lab investigations showed leucocytosis and stool microscopy revealed gull-wing–shaped gram-negative rods with darting motility. Which of the following is a selective culture medium for this organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of diarrhea and smear showing gull-wing–shaped gram-negative rods with darting motility is suggestive of Campylobacter jejuni. The most suitable culture media for Campylobacter jejuni is Skirrow's medium.

Campylobacters are gram-negative curved, or spiral-shaped organisms having a sea gull’s wing appearance (Shown in the image below). It is microaerophilic (shows growth in 5-10% oxygen) and thermophilic (prefers higher temperatures and grows best at 42°C). It is oxidase-positive, catalase-positive, and nitrate reduction positive. They multiply at a slower rate when compared to other Gram-negative, enteric bacteria, hence require antibiotic-containing selective media such as Campy-Blood agar, and Skirrow’s media for isolation of campylobacters from stool specimens.

C. jejuni is the major pathogen and is primarily associated with febrile diarrhea. Contaminated food is the major source of infection. The loose stools may contain blood and leukocytes, as campylobacter species are invasive pathogens that can damage the small intestinal mucosa and disrupt fluid absorption. Usually, the illness is self-limited to a period of 5–8 days, but occasionally it continues for longer times. Certain serotypes of C. jejuni have been associated with post diarrheal Guillain-Barré syndrome.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with urinary frequency and copious frothy vaginal discharge. On per speculum examination, a strawberry cervix was seen. What is the first-line treatment?

choices.text: Doxycycline 100 mg capsule OD for 14 days
Clotrimazole 100 mg vaginal tablet OD for 7 days
Metronidazole 2 g tablet as a single oral dose
Ketoconazole 400 mg OD daily for 5 days

questions.solution:
The above examination finding of strawberry cervix (punctate hemorrhages over the cervix) with a history of copious frothy vaginal discharge is suggestive of trichomoniasis. The first-line treatment for this condition is metronidazole as a single oral dose of 2g. 

Trichomonas vaginalis is one of the most common causes of vaginal discharge. Trichomonas infection of the female genital tract causes the following symptoms:

  • Foul-smelling, frothy, greenish-yellow discharge per vaginum with pH > 4.5,
  • Vulval pruritis
  • Dysuria and urinary frequency

Males can have asymptomatic urethritis. 

Diagnosis in females is usually easily confirmed by the presence of motile organisms on a wet film. Culture in Feinberg–Whittington medium is the most reliable method. More sensitive tests like PCR and NAAT are now available.

Treatment:

  • Treatment with metronidazole 2 g single oral dose is prescribed and patients should also be evaluated for concurrent gonorrhea and Chlamydia infection.
  • Even though identification of the organism in partners is not necessary, all sexual partners should be treated. 
  • Patients and their recent sexual partners should be advised to abstain from intercourse or use a condom during therapy

Other options:

Option A, Option B, and Option D: Doxycycline, clotrimazole, and ketoconazole do not eradicate Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: A female patient presented to the OPD with dysuria and frequent micturition. Urinalysis showed pus cells. A culture study yields a gram-negative rod, forming non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey's agar, and shows swarming on the blood agar plate. What is the likely causative agent implicated here?
questions.solution:
A gram-negative rod, forming non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey's agar with characteristic swarming motility is suggestive of Proteus.

Swarming effect is produced on blood agar which is characterized by expanding rings (waves) of organisms over the surface of the agar. Organisms exhibiting swarming include:

  • Proteus
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Clostridium tetani

Proteus species are Gram-negative, non-capsulated, pleomorphic, motile rods. They are opportunistic pathogens, often causing nosocomial infections, infections in burns, and commonly responsible for urinary tract infections.

Proteus species are urease-positive, non-lactose fermenters. They possess the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA). This is called the PPA reaction.

Proteus species exhibit swarming on solid media such as blood agar by using their peritrichous flagella. The image below shows the swarming effect.

questions.text: A patient presenting with chronic gout has been prescribed a drug that inhibits xanthine oxidase.  Which among the following drugs is it?
questions.solution:
Febuxostat is a selective inhibitor of xanthine oxidase thereby reducing xanthine and uric acid. 

Allopurinol and febuxostat are xanthine oxidase inhibitors indicated in the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients suffering from gout. Febuxostat is more potent than allopurinol. 

The adverse effects include hepatotoxicity, diarrhea, joint pain, and rash. A flare in the gout attack can be seen during the initiation of therapy due to a decrease in serum uric acid levels that results in the mobilization of uric acid from tissue deposits.

Other options:

Option A: Colchicine is an antimitotic drug that is used in the treatment of acute gout. It acts by inhibiting microtubule and spindle formation. Side effects are nausea, vomiting, myelosuppression, aplastic anemia, and rhabdomyolysis.

Option B: Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes the excretion of uric acids by inhibiting the organic anion transporter, particularly URAT-1 in the renal tubule. It is used to decrease the body pool of urate in patients with chronic gout. It is used as an adjuvant to allopurinol in chronic gout and hyperuricemia. Plenty of fluids are given to avoid urate calculi formation.

Option C: Pegloticase and rasburicase catalyze the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin. This product is soluble and inactive. It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of anal fistula?
questions.solution:
The most common anal fistula is the intersphincteric fistula.

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin. The most common cause is a perianal abscess. Other causes include tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Symptoms:

  • Perianal pain
  • Discharge- intermittent purulent discharge (which may be bloody) 

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

Exceptions to Goodsall’s Rule

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Investigations:

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

An MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. (Option-A)

Treatment:

  • Control of constipation
  • Sitz bath
  • Fistulotomy
  • Fistulectomy
  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)
  • Setons
  • Advancement flaps

questions.text: Hyperinflation of the lungs resulting in apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension is due to which of the following physiological reflexes?
questions.solution:
Apnea followed by rapid breathing after the hyperinflation of the lungs is due to the J receptor Reflex.

C fiber endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension. This is called the J reflex or pulmonary chemoreflex. A similar response is produced by receptors in the heart (Bezold-Jarisch reflex or the coronary chemoreflex).

Other options:

Option A: Tachycardia following acute volume overload is due to the Bainbridge Reflex. The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.

Option B: Hypertension following a head injury is due to the Cushing Reflex. When the intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to RVLM neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Option C: The activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) that causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing is the Bezold Jarisch reflex.

It can be elicited by substances like capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, veratridine, myocardial ischemia and reperfusion due to increased production of oxygen radicals, radiocontrast agents used for coronary angiography.

questions.text: Which of the following thermometers is incorrectly matched with their application?

choices.text: Wet globe thermometer - Cooling capacity of the working environment
Kata thermometer - Recording minimum and maximum temperatures

questions.solution:
Kata Thermometer is used to record low air velocity.

Kata Thermometer is quite sensitive to slight air movements as low as 10 feet per minute and hence used to record low air velocity. A kata thermometer was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air. It was used to assess the indices of thermal comfort. Currently, it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities. 

Recording minimum and maximum temperatures is done using the Six's maximum and minimum thermometer.

Other options:

Option A: A dry bulb thermometer is an ordinary thermometer used to measure the air temperature. It is mounted on the Stevenson screen for accurate readings.

Option B: A globe thermometer can be used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings. It is affected by both the air temperature and radiant heat.

Option C: A wet globe thermometer is used for measuring environmental heat. It exchanges heat with the surroundings by conduction, convection, evaporation, and radiation. The equilibrium temperature of the globe provides a comprehensive measure of the cooling capacity of the work environment.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a gradual loss of visual acuity in the left eye. Her MRI head is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and MRI showing tram track sign is suggestive of optic nerve meningioma.

Primary optic nerve meningioma arises from the arachnoid sheath of the optic nerve.

CT or MRI shows tram track sign. It is defined as the relative hypoattenuation of the optic nerve on CT or reduced signal on post gadolinium MRI due to peripheral enhancement of the tumor around the nerve.

The tram-track sign is useful in the differentiation between optic nerve meningioma and optic nerve gliomas.

CT may be also useful in detecting calcification within the meningioma which is specific to optic nerve meningioma and not seen in optic nerve glioma.

questions.text: The laryngoscopic appearance of the subglottis in an infant with a history of cardiac surgery is as shown below. Based on this you would expect the infant to have _________________
questions.solution:
An infant with a history of cardiac surgery, which would have required intubation, and laryngoscopy showing narrowing points towards a diagnosis of subglottic stenosis post intubation which would be associated with biphasic stridor.

Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea. For e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis. Inspiratory stridor is heard in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx. For e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.

Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of the thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi. For e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Cotton-Myer grading is used to clinically describe the stenosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with complaints of loss of libido and weakness. Physical examination revealed coarse facial features, frontal bossing, and enlarged hands. MRI showed a pituitary mass. Which of the following screening tests would you order to diagnose the cause of the mass?
questions.solution:
The screening test to diagnose the cause of the mass would be serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels.

The clinical features (loss of libido, weakness, coarse facial features, frontal bossing, and enlarged hands) are suggestive of acromegaly caused by a growth hormone-secreting pituitary tumour. However, since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, it is not possible to test for growth hormone.

Pituitary tumours are mainly classified as functioning and non-functioning tumours. Functioning tumours secrete hormones and thus lead to specific endocrine syndromes such as:

  • Acromegaly in growth hormone-secreting tumours
  • Cushing syndrome in ACTH secreting tumours
  • Galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and infertility in prolactin-secreting tumours

Non-functioning tumours produce symptoms due to mass effects. The symptoms include headaches, and visual impairment such as bitemporal hemianopia, and hypopituitarism.

The physiological actions of the growth hormone are mostly mediated through IGF-1, which is synthesized in the liver. Since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, serum IGF-1 levels are usually measured in order to assess growth hormone activity. Serum IGF-1 level is decreased in pituitary failure, defect or blockade of GH receptor. Since the low-calorie state is associated with growth hormone resistance, IGF-1 is also decreased in conditions such as cachexia, malnutrition, and sepsis. Serum IGF-1 level is increased in acromegaly.

Other options:

24-hour urinary-free cortisol and ACTH levels are useful in screening for Cushing's disease.

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl on a vegan diet undergoes her annual checkup. The results of her laboratory studies are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

Serum ferritin: 10 μg/L 

TIBC: elevated

Serum iron: normal

Percent transferrin saturation: 40%

Peripheral smear: normocytic normochromic erythrocytes
questions.solution:
The given patient has reduced serum ferritin (normal 50-200 μg/L) and elevated TIBC, but with normal transferrin saturation (normal 30-50%) and normal RBC morphology. This indicates that she is in the stage of negative iron balance. 

The progression to iron deficiency develops in 3 stages. The first stage is the stage of negative iron balance. In this, the demand for iron exceeds the body's ability to absorb iron from the diet. This stage can result from a number of physiological mechanisms, like blood loss, pregnancy, rapid growth during adolescence, or inadequate dietary intake. Under such circumstances, the iron stores from the reticuloendothelial sites are mobilized. Thus, the body's iron stores level, which is reflected by serum ferritin, decreases during this phase. As long as the iron stores are present, the serum iron and RBC morphology remain normal.

When the iron stores become depleted, the serum iron and transferrin saturation begin to fall. Once the transferrin saturation falls below 20%, hemoglobin synthesis becomes impaired. This is termed as the stage of iron-deficient erythropoiesis. Gradually, the hemoglobin begins to fall and the erythrocytes become microcytic and hypochromic, leading to the stage of iron-deficiency anemia.

  Negative iron balance Iron-deficient erythropoiesis Iron deficiency anemia
Marrow iron stores Decreased Decreased Decreased
S. ferritin Decreased Decreased Decreased
TIBC Increased Increased Increased
S. Iron Normal Decreased Decreased
Transferrin saturation Normal Decreased Decreased
Red cell protoporphyrin Normal Increased Increased
Red cell morphology Normal Normal Microcytic hypochromic

Related Pearl: Causes of Iron Deficiency Anemia

Dietary lack

  • Infants, who are at high risk due to the very small amounts of iron in milk. Human breast milk provides only about 0.3 mg/L of iron.
  • The impoverished, who can have suboptimal diets for socioeconomic reasons at any age
  • Older adults, who often have restricted diets with little meat because of limited income or poor dentition
  • Teenagers, who subsist on junk food

Impaired absorption

  • Sprue
  • Gastrectomy (Billroth II surgery)

Increased requirement

  • Growing infants, children, and adolescents
  • Premenopausal women, particularly during pregnancy.
  • Economically deprived women having multiple, closely spaced pregnancies are at exceptionally high risk.

Chronic blood loss

  • Menorrhagia
  • Carcinoma of the cecum
  • Hookworm infestation

questions.text: A 9-year-old is brought to the OPD with episodes of motionless staring and lip-smacking over the last three days. The child complains of abdominal discomfort prior to these episodes. Following the episode, the child remains confused for 5-10 minutes. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of focal onset seizures with impaired awareness.

Focal onset seizures with impaired awareness begin with an aura (like abdominal discomfort) which is stereotypic for the patient. The beginning of the ictal phase is marked by a motionless stare. During this period, the patient has impaired awareness and is not aware of anything happening in his surroundings. The ictal phase is also characterized by automatisms, which are involuntary, automatic behaviors. These may include chewing, lip-smacking, swallowing, and picking movements of the hands. The patient is typically confused following the seizure and the transition to normal state may take a few minutes to an hour. 

A close differential, in this case, can be absence seizures (option A). Absence seizures are also characterized by brief lapses of consciousness which manifest as episodes of staring. While bilateral motor signs such as blinking and chewing can be seen in absence seizures, automatisms are more specific for focal seizures with impaired awareness. Aura is usually absent in absence seizures. There is no post-ictal confusion and the patient regains consciousness immediately after the seizure ends.

Focal onset seizures with intact awareness (option B) can have motor manifestations (such as tonic, clonic or myoclonic movements) or nonmotor manifestations (such as sensory or autonomic manifestations) but without impairment of the awareness. For example, a patient having a focal motor seizure in the motor cortex will note the onset of involuntary movements of the contralateral hand. 

Atonic seizures (option C) are characterized by a sudden loss of postural muscle tone lasting for one or two seconds. Consciousness is impaired for a short period of time, but there is no post-ictal confusion. A brief seizure may cause a head drop or nodding movement, whereas a longer seizure will cause the patient to collapse, putting the patient at risk for a significant head injury.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of the right knee and ankle joint for one week with the following lesions on his soles. He gives a history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago. Which of the following is not commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with arthritis, preceding gastrointestinal infection and the above image showing keratoderma blennorrhagica are suggestive of reactive arthritis/Reiter's syndrome. Posterior uveitis is not seen in this condition. Instead, anterior uveitis is seen. 

Reactive arthritis (ReA) comes under the spectrum of seronegative spondyloarthropathies and is an acute asymmetric nonpurulent arthritis precipitated by an antecedent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection. It usually occurs in young men and chronic ReA is associated with HLA-B27. Bacterial triggers for ReA are caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, Chlamydia trachomatis, Clostridium difficile, certain toxigenic Escherichia coli, Ureaplasma urealyticum, and Mycoplasma genitalium. There is a typical antecedent history of infection 1-4 weeks before the onset of arthritic symptoms.

Clinical features of ReA include constitutional symptoms like fever, malaise, fatigue and weight loss. There may be asymmetric arthritis with the involvement of a new joint within a few days. It involves large weight-bearing joints like knee and ankle. Dactylitis/sausage digit is a distinctive feature of reactive and psoriatic arthritis.

Extraarticular manifestations include keratoderma blennorrhagica presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions/crusting on the palms and soles, enthesitis, anterior uveitis, and conjunctivitis. Circinate balanitis which consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis can be seen. Genitourinary symptoms like urethritis and prostatitis may occur. Cardiac conduction defects and aortic regurgitation may rarely occur.

Elevated ESR and CRP can be seen during the acute phase. Joint X-rays show juxta-articular osteoporosis, marginal erosions, loss of joint space, periostitis with new bone formation, and comma-shaped syndesmophytes.

High-dose NSAIDs have been shown to have some degree of benefit. Antibiotics during the antecedent infection may prevent the emergence of ReA. Intralesional glucocorticoids have been shown to benefit tendinitis and other enthesitic lesions.

questions.text: Identify the test which is being demonstrated in the video given below:
questions.solution:
The video shows an examination being performed with the knee flexed to about 20 degrees which indicates that it is the Lachman test. The presence of free gliding indicates that it is a positive Lachman test.

Lachman test: The patient’s knee is flexed to 20 degrees.  The lower part of the thigh is grasped with one hand and the upper part of the leg with the other hand. The joint surfaces are shifted backward and forward upon each other.  If the knee is stable, there should be no gliding. The presence of gliding indicates the laxity of the anterior cruciate ligament.

Other options:

Anterior and posterior drawer test: The test is performed with the patient’s knees flexed to 90 degrees, and the feet resting on the examining bed. The examiner then grasps the upper part of the leg with both hands and rocks it forward and backward. Excessive anterior movement denotes anterior cruciate laxity (anterior drawer test) Excessive posterior movement denotes posterior cruciate laxity (posterior drawer test). 

McMurray’s test: The test is used to identify torn meniscus. The knee is flexed as far as possible and the joint is stabilized with one hand. With the other hand, the examiner rotates the leg medially and laterally. If there is a clicking sound while rotating the leg, the test is positive. The sound is produced due to the trapping of the loose tag of the torn meniscus between the articular surfaces.

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

The image below shows the unhappy triad of the knee joint on MRI (PDW SPIR):

  1. Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Rupture of the medial collateral ligament
  3. Inner meniscal tear (image shows complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: A young patient visits your psychiatric OPD with the complaint that he has been seeing a person who looks exactly like him and wears similar clothes and has been following him around for the past few days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is suffering from doppelganger syndrome.

Doppelganger syndrome is a delusion of subjective doubles, where the person feels that he/she has his/her own impostor (doppelganger). 

Other Delusional Misidentification Syndromes:

Fregoli syndrome (Option B) is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people/strangers are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Othello syndrome (Option C) is a rare psychiatric condition where a person has morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy and suspects a faithful partner of infidelity.

Capgras syndrome (Option D) is a delusion where a person believes that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Syndrome of intermetamorphosis: This is a very rare delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will.

 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: All of the following are paired dural venous sinuses except?
questions.solution:
The cavernous sinus, transverse sinus, and inferior petrosal sinus are paired dural venous sinuses while the straight sinus is an unpaired sinus.

Dural venous sinuses are a network of venous channels that drain blood from the brain and cranial bones. They receive blood through the cerebral veins and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the subarachnoid space through the arachnoid villi. The blood in the dural sinuses ultimately drains into the internal jugular veins in the neck. These sinuses may be paired or unpaired. Paired venous sinuses have one sinus each on the right and left side. They are:

  1. Cavernous sinus 
  2. Superior petrosal sinus
  3. Inferior petrosal sinus
  4. Transverse sinus
  5. Sigmoid sinus
  6. Sphenoparietal sinus
  7. Petrosquamous sinus
  8. Middle meningeal sinus/veins

Unpaired Venous Sinuses are median in position. They are:

  1. Superior sagittal sinus
  2. Inferior sagittal sinus
  3. Straight sinus
  4. Occipital sinus
  5. Anterior intercavernous sinus
  6. Posterior intercavernous sinus
  7. Basilar plexus of veins

These sinuses lack valves and their walls are devoid of muscular tissue. They usually lie between the endosteal and meningeal layers of the dura mater and are lined by endothelium. The only dural venous sinuses that lie within the meningeal layer of the dura are the inferior sagittal sinus and straight sinus.

questions.text: In the emergency department, a  patient who suddenly went into apnea, was being ventilated with the following apparatus. What does the part marked as A represent?

choices.text: Air inlet and pressure release valve

questions.solution:
The above image shows a self-inflating bag and mask and the part marked as A represents the air inlet and pressure release valve.

Bag and mask ventilation is used as the first step in airway management to provide positive pressure ventilation. It serves as a rescue technique to provide oxygenation and ventilation in patients with difficult airways until tracheal intubation is achieved. 

The bag in this apparatus is a self-inflating bag. This allows for it to be used without a pressurized gas supply and is delivered to the patient when the bag is squeezed (compressed). A patent airway and a good seal are essential to facilitate bag and mask ventilation.

The rescuer should be positioned at the patient’s head. A one-person technique involves the "E-C seal" in which your first and second digits form a "C" over the mask with your thumb pressing down by the nasal bridge, your second digit over the bottom of the mask by the mouth, and your third through fifth digits forming an "E" and applying pressure to the mandible to hold the mask tight

Effective ventilation can be confirmed by:

  • Chest rise on squeezing the bag
  • Condensation in the clear mask
  • Pulse oximetry shows improved saturation
  • Capnography shows exhaled carbon dioxide

Mask ventilation is usually contraindicated in patients with an increased risk of regurgitation. It should be used with caution in patients with severe facial trauma.

The following image shows the parts of a self-inflating bag and mask apparatus with a reservoir bag.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man complains of shortness of breath and tachypnea on post-op day 2 following emergency surgery for a ruptured appendix. He is now requiring oxygen via a face mask to keep his oxygen saturation above 94%. His chest radiograph is given below. Which of the following treatment strategies is least likely to be beneficial in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the chest radiograph point to a diagnosis of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Surfactant replacement has no role in the management of patients with ARDS. 

ARDS refers to an acute onset and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema that occurs due to endothelial injury in the pulmonary capillaries due to inflammation. The diagnostic criteria for ARDS include:

  • PaO2/FiO2 ratio < 300 mmHg
  • Acute onset (within 1 week of a clinical insult)
  • Chest radiograph shows diffuse bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema
  • Absence of any left atrial hypertension (ie, pulmonary edema is not due to a cardiac cause)

Conditions associated with direct lung injury like pneumonia, aspiration of gastric contents, pulmonary contusion, near-drowning and toxic inhalational injury are associated with ARDS. Systemic conditions causing indirect lung injury and ARDS include sepsis, severe trauma (head injury, burns, multiple bone fractures), multiple blood transfusions, and pancreatitis.

The chest radiograph of a patient with ARDS will show diffuse bilateral alveolar infiltrates with a classic ground-glass appearance consistent with pulmonary edema that can be difficult to distinguish from left ventricular failure. 

The main treatment strategy which has been shown to reduce mortality in patients is low tidal volume ventilation (option C) (6 mL/kg of predicted body weight). Conventional tidal volume ventilation leads to overdistension injury because the lung in ARDS is already consolidated and any attempt to push more air through it will lead to barotrauma. Apart from this, high PEEP(option A), prone position (option B), early neuromuscular blockade, and use of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)  may also be useful. Management strategies that have not been shown to improve the outcome in ARDS patients include glucocorticoids, surfactant replacement, anti-inflammatory therapies like NSAIDs and inhaled vasodilators. 

Related Pearl: Indications of Mechanical Ventilation

  • Direct measurement
    • Arterial oxygen tension <50 mm Hg on room air
    • Arterial CO 2 tension >50 mm Hg in the absence of metabolic alkalosis
  • Derived indices
    • Pa O 2 /F IO 2 ratio <300 mm Hg
    • PA–a o 2 gradient >350 mm Hg
    • V D /V T >0.6
  • Clinical indices
    • Respiratory rate >35 breaths/min
  • Mechanical indices
    • Tidal volume <5 mL/kg
    • Vital capacity <15 mL/kg
    • Maximum inspiratory Force > −25 cm H 2 O

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient presents to you with a rapidly increasing power of glasses. You noticed Munson's sign when the patient was asked to look with a downward gaze. Which of the following systemic conditions is not associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and lower lid bulging on the downgaze (Munson's sign) are suggestive of keratoconus. Alport syndrome is not associated with keratoconus. Alport syndrome is associated with the anterior lenticonus.

Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision.

It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often cause significant myopia and irregular astigmatism. 

Keratoconus is associated with:

  1. Marfan's syndrome
  2. Osteogenesis imperfecta
  3. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
  4. Down's syndrome
  5. Asthma
  6. Atopy
  7. Mitral valve prolapse

Investigations:

  • Corneal topography
  • Pachymetry
  • Keratometry: Steep cornea, bow tie pattern and paracentral thinning of the cornea (thinnest point) 

Treatment:

  • Spectacle correction
  • Rigid gas-permeable contact lens
  • Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) - instillation of riboflavin drops to photosensitize the eye, followed by exposure to ultraviolet-A light
  • Intra-corneal ring segments (INTACS)- small curved PMMA ring or set of rings that are implanted in the cornea to help flatten corneal curvature in an effort to improve vision
  • Corneal transplantation- Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty (DALK) and penetrating keratoplasty (PKP)

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: Which of the following test is not used to confirm live birth?
questions.solution:
Gettler's test is not used to confirm live births. It was used to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

Tests for live birth:

  • Wreden’s test – Based on changes in the middle ear after birth
  • Ploucquet’s test – Based on the ratio of the weight of lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs: Weight of lungs: the weight of body = 1:70
    • Respired lungs: Weight of lungs: the weight of body = 1:35
  • Fodere’s test – Based on an increase in weight of lung due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of unrespired lung is 30 – 40g whereas the weight of the respired lung is 60 – 66g.
  • Breslau’s second life test: It is based on the air entering the stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born foetus.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme would be deficient in a patient suffering from Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome?
questions.solution:
Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome/MPS VI is caused by the deficiency of N -Acetylgalactosamine-α-4-sulfate sulfatase.

Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome/MPS VI is caused by the deficiency of arylsulfatase B enzyme whose gene locus is on chromosome 5. Preservation of intelligence is the feature of this syndrome. It is characterized by macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, macroglossia, short stature, and contractures. 

Naglazyme is used as an enzyme replacement therapy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman was admitted for a retrosternal goiter which had been detected when she was evaluated for symptoms of chest discomfort and dyspnea. After routine investigations, fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC), and imaging studies it is decided that she is at high risk to convert from a transcervical approach to a median sternotomy by the surgical team. The presence of which of the following conditions in the patient would not warrant a median sternotomy?

choices.text: Goiter extending into the posterior mediastinum
Diameter of goiter > Diameter of thoracic inlet
Goiter extending up to the superior margin of the aortic arch

questions.solution:
A goiter extending up to the superior margin of the aortic arch is not a high risk for conversion into open sternotomy. Goiters that extend below the inferior margin of the aortic arch are at high risk of conversion to median sternotomy.

Retrosternal goiter is an extension of the multinodular goiter into the mediastinum. It receives its blood supply from the inferior thyroid arteries and venous drainage through the inferior thyroid veins. This condition is usually asymptomatic and may not require surgery. If the gland enlarges within the thoracic inlet, the pressure may lead to dysphagia, tracheal compression, and eventually airway symptoms. But the majority of retrosternal goiters are asymptomatic or show very few symptoms.

Patients considered for surgery :

  • Significant airway compression
  • Symptoms are present
  • In young patients in whom symptoms are likely to develop

Elderly patients where retrosternal goiters are incidentally found, it observed rather than treated.

>95% of retrosternal goiters can be removed through the transcervical approach.

Retrosternal goiters that are at most risk of requiring conversion to an open sternotomy approach :

  • Malignant cases
  • Revision cases
  • Goiters extending into the posterior mediastinum (Option A)
  • Diameter of the goiter exceeding that of the thoracic inlet (Option C)
  • Goiters that reach the carina
  • Goiters that extend below the inferior margin of the aortic arch

If the gland is fixed and immobile (Option B) or too large to deliver through a cervical approach, a midline sternotomy is performed and the gland can be dissected from below to achieve a safe total thyroidectomy.

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD following a suicide attempt due to a family quarrel. On examination, a laceration was found at the wrist, which has resulted in the injury of the nerve which passes through the carpal tunnel. Which of the following would not be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Loss of sensation over lateral 3 1/2 fingers
Inability to make a complete fist

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of a laceration in the lateral aspect of the wrist injuring the nerve which passes under the carpal tunnel is suggestive of median nerve injury. Lesions of the median nerve at the wrist present without benediction hand with normal wrist flexion, digital flexion, and pronation. Hence patient will be able to make a complete fist.

The patient will be unable to perform thumb abduction and thumb opposition(Options A and B). There is also a loss of sensation over the radial 3½ digits(Option C). Wasting of thenar eminence is seen in long-standing cases.

Benediction hand is the inability to make a complete fist due to loss of digital flexion of lateral 3 digits. It can be seen in median nerve injury due to forearm fractures or elbow dislocations(High lesion).

Proximal 1/3rd of the forearm All the flexor muscles of the proximal forearm, except the flexor carpi ulnaris and the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus
Distal 1/3rd of the forearm  No muscles
