questions.text: An anxious mother brings her otherwise healthy neonate with the lesion show in image. What would you do?

choices.text: Low dose broad spectrum antibiotic prophylaxis

questions.solution:
Reassure the mother that it is benign as the image shows Epstein Pearls.

Epstein Pearls

  • Are nests of epithelial cells.
  • Appear as whitish/yellowish spots on the hard palate.
  • It may also occur over the tip of Prepuce at 6 o'clock position.
  • Usually, resolve in 3 months.

 No intervention is necessary as it resolves spontaneously and is a benign condition.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A young animal rescue worker complained of an itchy rash on his abdomen. On examination, multiple creeping lesions are seen as shown in the image below. Which of the following organisms is least likely to cause his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with an image showing red, raised serpiginous lesions are suggestive of cutaneous larva migrans. Among the given organisms the least likely cause would be Ascaris lumbricoides. However, Ascaris lumbricoides can cause visceral larva migrans.

Cutaneous larva migrans is mainly caused by non-human nematodes like Ancylostoma braziliense and Ancylostoma caninum and a few human nematodes such as Strongyloides stercoralis, Necator americanus, and Loa loa. It is acquired via direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. The larvae remain confined to the outer layers of skin, as they cannot penetrate the basement membrane of the human skin.

It presents as erythematous, pruritic papules at the site of entry. This is followed by the appearance of erythematous serpiginous tracks of lesions on the skin. This is due to the migration of larvae through the dermo-epidermal junction. The lesion shifts correspond to the movement of the larva. Hence these lesions are also called creeping eruptions. Diagnosis is based mainly on clinical features.

questions.text: Mr. Raju, a 54-year-old male, complains of on and off difficulty in swallowing food. On performing an endoscopy the following finding is noted. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of a Schatzki’s ring in the lower end of the esophagus.

Schtazki’s ring is a circumferential ring present in the lower end of the esophagus near the squamocolumnar junction. The patients usually present with intermittent dysphagia during the hurried ingestion of solid foods.

Barium swallow and endoscopy will show the presence of a single ring in the distal portion of the esophagus.

Other options:

Eosinophilic esophagitis (option A) shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus.This appearance is called as the feline esophagus or ringed esophagus.

Esophageal web (option C) appears as a thin membrane. It can occur alone or as a part of Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Esophageal leiomyoma (option D) appears as an oval intramural mass arising from the wall of the esophagus.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman undergoes hip arthroplasty. The consultant advises starting the patient on dabigatran to prevent venous thromboembolism. How does this drug prevent thrombosis in this patient?

choices.text: Inhibition of  vitamin K epoxide reductase

questions.solution:
Dabigatran prevents venous thromboembolism by direct thrombin inhibition.

Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI). It belongs to a new class of anticoagulant drugs that prevent thrombin from cleaving fibrinogen to fibrin. Parenteral DTIs include bivalirudin, argatroban, and desirudin. The only oral DTI available for clinical use is dabigatran.

They are used in:

  • Prevention of embolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (without valvular heart disease)
  • Venous thromboembolic disease (VTE)
  • Postoperative thromboprophylaxis in patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty

The major adverse effect of dabigatran is bleeding. There is an additional risk for bleeding in renal impairment and concurrent use of antiplatelet agents or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Dabigatran is contraindicated for stroke prevention in patients with mechanical heart valves.

Other options:

Option A: Heparin acts by activating antithrombin III, thereby inactivating the active form of clotting factors II, IX, X, XI, XII, and XIII. Adverse effects are bleeding and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) due to the formation of antibodies against the heparin-platelet complex.

Option C: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. It catalyzes the conversion of oxidized vitamin K to the reduced form of vitamin K. The reduced vitamin K is involved in the carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X, and proteins C and S.

Options D: Rivaroxaban and apixaban are direct oral factor Xa inhibitors that inhibit the free and clot-associated factor Xa resulting in reduced thrombin generation.

questions.text: The director of a hospital wants an analysis of how the health care is being managed. He wants an estimate of how much manpower, money, materials, and other resources are used in the setup in order to completely treat the said number of patients in the estimate. This type of analysis is known as?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of input-output analysis.

The input-output analysis provides information on how much input is needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, input refers to all health service activities which consume resources (manpower, money, materials, and time); and output refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed.

Other options:

Cost-benefit analysis: Here the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to identify whether it is economically sound and to select the best one from several alternate programs. The main drawback of this technique is that the benefits of a particular program in the health field cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. Usually, the benefits are expressed in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome.

Cost-effectiveness analysis: The benefits of the health care system are expressed in terms of results achieved (Eg: the number of lives saved or the number of days free from disease). This is a more promising tool in the health field than cost-benefit analysis. But in many cases, it is not possible to use cost-effective analysis.

Network analysis: A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities that should be completed in order to reach an end objective.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with fever with chills and abdominal pain 2 days after vaginal delivery. She also has foul-smelling lochia. Parametrial tenderness is elicited on abdominal and bimanual examination. Her WBC count was 25000/ microlitre. Which among the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: Anaerobic streptococcus is the predominant pathogen involved
Risk is more with vaginal delivery when compared with caesarian section
Placental site is involved most commonly following vaginal delivery

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of puerperal sepsis. The risk of developing puerperal sepsis is more with a caesarian section when compared with vaginal delivery.

  • The most common route of spread of puerperal sepsis is direct spread.
  • The most common site of puerperal infection is the placental site in vaginal delivery and uterine incision in a cesarean section. (Option D)
  • The most common manifestation of puerperal infection is Endometritis. (Option C)
  • The most common cause of puerperal sepsis is Streptococcus. (Option A)
  • The most important risk factor for the development of puerperal sepsis is the route of delivery (Cesarean > Vaginal). (Option B)
  • The only proven way of decreasing uterine infection following a cesarean section is administrating a single dose of ampicillin or 1st generation cephalosporin at the time of cesarean delivery. None of the other steps with respect to surgical closure of the abdomen have proven benefit in decreasing puerperal infection.

questions.text: In a case of anisocoria which is greater in the light, the instillation of 1% Pilocarpine failed to produce pupillary constriction in the dilated pupil. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
1% pilocarpine fails to produce pupillary constriction due to pharmacological blockade in the dilated pupil. 

Anisocoria greater in the light indicates the large pupil to be abnormal due to poor pupillary contraction from a parasympathetic abnormality. 1% pilocarpine and 0.1% pilocarpine can be used to differentiate fixed dilated pupil. 

Option A: Mydriasis due to neurologic origin (3rd nerve palsy) responds readily to 1% pilocarpine, whereas there will be no response if the dilation is due to anticholinergic causes.

Option C: Pupillary constriction to 0.1% pilocarpine diagnoses Adie's pupil (due to denervation hypersensitivity). Application of 0.1% pilocarpine shows no response in other conditions or in the normal eye.

Option D: Cocaine and phenylephrine are used in anisocoria that is greater in the dark to diagnose Horner’s syndrome. In these patients, the small pupil fails to dilate even after the instillation of cocaine.

questions.text: An epidemiologist wants to identify missing cases of HIV-positive individuals in the community, that were not on the notified cases list. This process is known as?
questions.solution:
Sentinel surveillance is a method of identifying the missing cases that are not on the notified cases list.

Sentinel surveillance helps in identifying the missing cases, in addition to the already existing new and old cases. It is used for supplementing routine notifications. The sentinel data collected in this type of surveillance can estimate the disease prevalence (old and new cases) in the total population. This system provides more valuable and detailed information compared to what is obtained from traditional notification systems.

Monitoring is the analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes in the health status or environment of a population.

Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and ill health.

Evaluation compares results with the intended objectives, or more simply assesses how well a program is performing.

Related Pearl: Sentinel Surveillance

  • Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in surveillance of diseases.
  • It detects the total case load and is used to identify the missing cases that are not notified among the old and new cases.
  • Sentinel data from the same is extrapolated to the entire population and the prevalence can be commented on.
  • Advantages: Bias in reporting is minimized and the feedback is simplified.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining slides of renal tissue to study glomerular pathology. Which of the following will she not observe on H & E staining or electron microscopy findings?

choices.text: Spike and dome appearance on electron microscopy is seen in membranous nephropathy
Podocyte effacement on light microscopy is seen in Minimal Change disease
Crescents and necrosis are seen on light microscopy in Goodpasture syndrome
Basket-weave appearance of GBM on electron microscopy in Alport syndrome

questions.solution:
The effacement of the foot process can only be observed on electron microscopy. Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

It is also seen in other conditions such as membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Since the podocytes are affected in these diseases, they are also known as podocytopathies.

Other options:

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents to you with severe pain abdomen. On examination icterus is present and a small lump is palpable at the right hypochondriac region. An abdominal CT was done and is as shown. Choose the correct option regarding the classification of this disease.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the CT showing a central dot sign is suggestive of Caroli's disease or type V choledochal cyst according to Todani classification.

Caroli’s Disease is an autosomal recessive condition of multifocal cystic dilatation of segmental intrahepatic bile ducts. According to Todani classification, it is classified as a type V choledochal cyst. USG may show dilated intrahepatic bile ducts in these individuals which may be associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis. The beaded appearance of intrahepatic bile ducts on HIDA scan and the central dot sign on the CT are characteristic findings associated with Caroli's disease. MRCP is the investigation of choice. Malignancy may complicate the disease in longstanding cases

The arrows in the image given below are pointing to the central dot sign.

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain. 

Choledochal cyst is classified by Todani into five types:

  • Type I: is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
  • Type II: It is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD
  • Type III: They arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct and are also known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA: The cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type IVB: These choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V (Caroli’s disease): It consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Other options: The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to anatomically define bile duct injuries.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: A statistician collects data regarding life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income of the population. Which among the following is most likely being calculated by the statistician?
questions.solution:
The index that is calculated using the given indicators such as life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income is the Human Developmental Index (HDI).

Human Development Index (HDI) is defined as a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development. It assesses abilities 

  • To lead a healthy long life - measured by life expectancy at birth
  • To acquire knowledge- measured by mean years of schooling
  • To achieve a decent standard of living- measured by gross national income per capita

Hence the 3 dimension indices used to calculate the human development index are as follows life expectancy index, education index, and gross national index. 

Other options:

Option A- Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) uses three indicators which include infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy rate.

Option B- Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) is an international measure of acute multidimensional poverty by capturing the acute deprivations in health, education, and living standards that a person faces simultaneously. It is assessed using 3 dimensions and 10 indicators which are as follows:

  1. Health - Nutrition and child mortality
  2. Education- Years of schooling and school attendance
  3. Standard of living - 
    • Cooking fuel
    • Sanitation
    • Drinking water
    • Electricity
    • Housing
    • Assets

Option C- Disability-adjusted life years (DALY) is the amount of time lost due to ill health. It is expressed as the number of years lost due to ill health, disability, or early death. The components of DALY are:

  • Years of life lost due to premature death
  • Years lived with disability (YLD)
  • Years lived in a state of less than full health

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

Components

Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

questions.text: A 57-year-old female patient complains of sudden onset shortness of breath and pain on inspiration on post-op day 5 following total knee replacement. Her BP is 124/70 mmHg and echocardiography is normal. Her chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following treatment strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Low molecular weight heparin plus alteplase

questions.solution:
The given history and the chest radiograph showing Hampton's hump point to a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE). Since this patient is normotensive and there are no findings on echocardiography, it is a case of low-risk PE. The most appropriate management in this patient would be anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin.

Depending on the clinical presentation, patients with PE can be stratified as:

  • High-risk (massive) PE is characterized by systemic hypotension. Patients can have dyspnea and syncope and may present in cardiogenic shock. 
  • Intermediate-risk (submassive) PE is characterized by right ventricle (RV) dysfunction but normal blood pressure. RV dysfunction can be diagnosed with echocardiography and ECG.
  • Low-risk PE is characterized by normal blood pressure and the absence of any RV dysfunction. 

The treatment strategy for a patient with pulmonary embolism will vary according to the risk stratification. A patient with high-risk PE will primarily be treated with anticoagulation and thrombolysis or catheter/surgical embolectomy. A patient with low-risk PE will be treated with anticoagulation alone, or an IVC filter as secondary prophylaxis. Patients with intermediate-risk PE require individualized treatment. 

Anticoagulation can be done with the classical strategy of low-molecular-weight heparin followed by warfarin, or by low-molecular-weight heparin for 5 days, switched to novel oral anticoagulant like Dabigatran after that. Fibrinolysis, if indicated, is done with recombinant TPA administered over 2 hours. It can be done up to 14 days after the PE has occurred. 

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include:

  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A new drug X is in the pipeline for the treatment of Guillain Barre syndrome. In which of the following phases is its efficacy and dose range first determined?

questions.text: An Indian tourist who has come to Jamaica consumes a local unripe fruit. Following its consumption, he develops severe vomiting, confusion, and hypoglycemia. Which of the following statement is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Impaired omega oxidation of fatty acids.
Hypoglycin is the toxin responsible for this condition.
Excretion of dicarboxylic acids in the urine.

questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Jamaican vomiting sickness. This is due to impaired beta-oxidation of fatty acids, not impaired omega oxidation. Infact, some reports suggest that omega oxidation becomes prominent.

It is caused due to consumption of an unripe ackee fruit, which has the toxins hypoglycin A and B. Hypoglycin inactivates medium and short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, inhibiting β-oxidation and causes nonketotic hypoglycemia. There is the excretion of dicarboxylic acid in the urine.

Patients present with profuse vomiting altered mental status, and hypoglycemia. Treatment is primarily supportive care with intravenous fluids and dextrose.

questions.text: Homocarnosine is made up of _______.
questions.solution:
Homocarnosine, which is a major constituent of excitable tissues, brain, and skeletal muscle, is made up of histidine and GABA.

Other non–α-amino acid derivatives present in tissues are carnosine, which is made up of beta-alanine and histidine, and anserine, which is a methylated carnosine.

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient on oral contraceptives presented with abdominal pain and increasing abdominal girth for the past five days. Physical examination revealed hepatomegaly and ascites. A liver biopsy showed severe centrilobular congestion and necrosis and organized thrombi in the major hepatic veins. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and histopathological findings are suggestive of hepatic vein thrombosis or Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Obstruction of the major hepatic veins due to thrombosis leads to a condition known as Budd-Chiari syndrome. It presents with a triad of abdominal pain, hepatomegaly and ascites. The damage to the hepatic tissue is a result of increased intrahepatic blood pressure. It principally affects young women with an underlying hypercoagulable state such as deficiency of protein C, S or anti-thrombin. Oral contraceptive intake increases the risk of hepatic vein thrombosis. Hepatic vein thrombosis is also associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms like polycythemia vera, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Grossly the liver is swollen, red-purple in color and has a tense capsule. Microscopically, there may be areas of hemorrhage alternating with areas of preserved parenchyma. Centrilobular congestion and necrosis is seen. The major hepatic veins contain thrombi and they may get organized into the wall of the vessel.

Other options:

Option B: Metastatic liver disease - It typically presents with multiple liver lesions and is not associated with centrilobular congestion, organized thrombi in the major hepatic veins, or the clinical picture described in the scenario. 

Option C: Primary biliary cholangitis, previously called primary biliary cirrhosis, is an autoimmune disease associated with inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It usually presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. 

Option D: Secondary biliary cirrhosis refers to inflammation, fibrosis, and scarring, secondary to chronic obstruction of the extrahepatic bile ducts.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby boy had recurrent episodes of bacterial infection. There is also a history of bloody diarrhoea and eczema during the first month of life. Peripheral smear showed abnormally small-sized platelets. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome.

Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disease characterized by thrombocytopenia and small-sized platelets. Patients often present in infancy with bruising, bloody diarrhea, eczema, and susceptibility to recurrent infections. It occurs due to mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP).

Along with microthrombocytopenia, peripheral smear shows loss of T lymphocytes. Patients are also unable to produce antibodies to antigens, thereby making them immunocompromised. As a result, there is also an increased risk of autoimmune disorders and cancers like B-cell lymphomas.

Splenectomy improves platelet counts in these patients since increased platelet destruction in the spleen is prevented. However, the only definitive treatment is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Other options:

Option A: Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition due to a defect in IIb/IIIa leading to defective platelet aggregation.

Option B: Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is a condition characterized by low platelet count due to autoantibody-mediated destruction. Patients present with easy bruising, nosebleeds, gingival bleeding, and bleeding into the skin and soft tissues. Laboratory findings typically show isolated thrombocytopenia.

Option C: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition occurring due to defective adhesion of platelets to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. It is due to a deficiency of the glycoprotein complex Ib–IX on the platelet membrane. Patients often present with bleeding tendencies.

Related Pearl: Causes of Thrombocytopenia

I. Decreased Production of Platelets

  1. Selective impairment of platelet production
    • Drug-induced: alcohol, thiazides, cytotoxic drugs
    • Infections: measles, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  2. Nutritional deficiencies - B12, folate deficiency
  3. Bone marrow failure - aplastic anemia
  4. Bone marrow replacement - leukemia, disseminated cancer, granulomatous disease
  5. Ineffective hematopoiesis - myelodysplastic syndromes 

II. Decreased Platelet Survival

  1. Immunologic destruction
    • Primary autoimmune - chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura, acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura
    • Secondary autoimmune - systemic lupus erythematosus, B-cell lymphoid neoplasms
    • Alloimmune - posttransfusion and neonatal
    • Drug-associated - quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds
    • Infections - HIV, infectious mononucleosis (transient, mild), dengue fever
  2. Nonimmunologic destruction
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
    • Thrombotic microangiopathies
    • Giant hemangiomas

III. Sequestration - The spleen normally sequesters 30% to 35% of platelets. This can rise to 80% to 90% when the spleen is enlarged, producing moderate degrees of thrombocytopenia.

IV. Dilution - Transfusions

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient comes with swelling of the face and lips after he heard about the passing of his dog. He is diagnosed with hereditary angioedema. Name the oral plasma kallikrein inhibitor that can be given prophylactically to prevent further attacks in this patient.
questions.solution:
An oral plasma kallikrein inhibitor that can be given prophylactically in hereditary angioedema is berotralstat.

Berotralstat inhibits kallikrein which decreases the production of bradykinin which prevents the localized tissue edema that occurs during attacks of HAE. Berotralstat has been approved for prophylaxis to prevent attacks of HAE in adults and pediatric patients aged 12 years or older.

Hereditary angioedema (HAE) is due to an inherited deficiency of C1 inhibitors. Patients with HAE usually present with episodic attacks that begin during childhood that became more severe during adolescence.

There may be symptoms before the episodes occur, such as sudden mood changes, anxiety, sensory changes, or exhaustion may also occur for several hours. In one-third of patients, attacks are precipitated by trauma-like pressure. 

Symptoms are referable to 3 prominent sites:

  • Subcutaneous tissues like face, hands, arms, legs, genitals, and buttocks
  • Abdominal organs like the stomach, intestines, bladder, and kidneys. This manifests as vomiting, diarrhea, or paroxysmal colicky pain
  • The upper airway (larynx) and tongue, which results in laryngeal edema and upper airway obstruction

The swelling is usually unresponsive to antihistamines.

Icatibant is a selective bradykinin B2 receptor competitive antagonist. It is indicated for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioedema. The other drug which is approved for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioedema is ecallantide which is a synthetic plasma kallikrein inhibitor. Both icatibant and ecallantide are administered subcutaneously. A common side effect is a local reaction at the injection site (redness, bruising, swelling, burning, itching, etc.). Other side effects include fever, elevated transaminase, dizziness, nausea, headache, or rash.

Ambrisentan is an endothelin receptor antagonist and is indicated for use in pulmonary arterial hypertension. Its most common side effect is peripheral edema.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is referred by a dentist prior to a dental procedure for medical clearance. On auscultation, there is a midsystolic click and late systolic murmur, best heard over the apex. She is otherwise asymptomatic and there is no significant past history. Which of the following is the most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: No intervention required at this stage

questions.solution:
In the given patient who has a midsystolic click and a late systolic murmur on auscultation without any other clinical features, a diagnosis of mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is the most likely. Patients with MVP but no history of prior endocarditis do not require antibiotic prophylaxis before dental procedures.

Only the following cardiac lesions are considered high-risk and warrant antibiotic prophylaxis before a dental procedure:

  • Prosthetic heart valves or left ventricular assist devices
  • Prior endocarditis
  • Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart diseases
  • Completely repaired congenital heart diseases during the first 6 months following repair
  • Repaired congenital heart diseases with residual defects adjacent to prosthetic material
  • Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation

Prophylaxis is with oral Amoxicillin 1 hour before the procedure. In case the patient is unable to take oral medications, Ampicillin is given IV or IM 1 hour before the procedure. In patients allergic to Penicillins, Azithromycin, Cephalexin, and Doxycycline are alternatives. 

MVP is a disorder that occurs due to redundant mitral leaflet tissue, which is associated with myxomatous degeneration and increased deposits of certain GAGs. It more commonly occurs in women between the ages of 15 and 30. While the majority of the patients with MVP are asymptomatic and have only auscultatory findings, it can lead to the development of mitral regurgitation. MVP causes excessive stress on papillary muscles, which can cause dysfunction and ischemia of the papillary muscles and subjacent ventricular myocardium. Rupture of the chordae tendineae and progressive annular dilation lead to mitral regurgitation.  

Most patients with MVP do not require any intervention. If a patient with MVP is symptomatic because of severe mitral regurgitation left ventricular failure, surgical correction is indicated. 

Related Pearl: Cardiac conditions requiring antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis

High risk cardiac conditions for development of Infective endocarditis and require antibiotic prophylaxis are:

  • Prosthetic valves
  • History of infective endocarditis
  • Few congenital heart diseases which include:
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD, including palliative shunts and conduit
    • Completely repaired congenital heart defect with prosthetic material or device, whether placed by surgery or by catheter intervention, during the first 6 months after the procedure
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with cardiac valvular disease

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with HIV was started on ART. His CD4+ T-cell count at presentation was 38 cells/μL. Four weeks after treatment initiation, he developed a high-grade fever and cough with expectoration. His CD4+ count was 320 cells/μL and chest radiography showed mediastinal lymphadenopathy and consolidation. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a patient who was recently diagnosed with HIV and started on ART, the appearance of symptoms like high-grade fever, cough with expectoration and pulmonary infiltrates on CXR after treatment initiation point to a diagnosis of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). 

Following the initiation of effective anti-retroviral therapy, a paradoxical worsening of preexisting or untreated opportunistic infections may be seen in people living with HIV (PLHIV). This is known as immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). IRIS is seen in up to 30% of the patients who are started on ART, and is particularly common in patients with untreated mycobacterial or fungal infections, or with CD4+ T-cell counts <50 cells/μL. Other risk factors for the development of IRIS include:

  • Rapid initial fall in HIV viral load due to ART
  • Severity of TB disease
  • Male sex and younger age

The underlying pathogenesis appears to be similar to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction and reflects the immediate improvements in immune function as there is a drop in the levels of HIV RNA. IRIS related to a known pre-existing infection is called paradoxical IRIS; IRIS associated with a previously undiagnosed condition is referred to as unmasking IRIS. Signs and symptoms can appear within two weeks to two years of starting ART and can include lymphadenitis, prolonged fever, pulmonary infiltrates, hepatitis and increase intracranial pressure.

IRIS is generally self-limiting and interruption of ART is rarely indicated. In most cases, recognition and management of ongoing infection with antimicrobial therapy is sufficient. Short-term therapy with corticosteroids or NSAIDs can be given to reduce the inflammation. Temporary cessation of ART is to be considered for potentially life-threatening forms of IRIS. For the prevention of IRIS in a patient with HIV and TB co-infection, anti-tubercular treatment is started first and then ART is added two weeks later.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt abdominal trauma. He is found to have a splenic injury with a ruptured subcapsular hematoma and is hemodynamically unstable. What is the grade of injury and the best course of management?
questions.solution:
A ruptured subcapsular hematoma is suggestive of grade III splenic injury and the best course of management in a hemodynamically unstable patient is splenectomy.

Grades of splenic injury:

Grade Injury
I Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (<10% of surface area) or laceration, <1 cm of parenchymal depth
II Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (10-50% of surface area) or laceration, 1-3 cm of parenchymal depth which does not involve the trabecular vessels
III

Hematoma > 50% of surface area or expanding

  • Ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma,
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding Or
    Laceration, >3 cm parenchymal depth or involving
    trabecular vessels
IV Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels leading to major devascularization (>25% of the spleen)
V Shattered spleen
or
A hilar vascular injury that devascularizes the spleen.

Management of splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively. Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals, hematocrit, and serial CECT. If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis. If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable, then a splenorrhaphy is done. 

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense cravings for food. She eats large amounts of food, which is followed by self-induced vomiting. Her BMI is 22. What is the first line pharmacological treatment of her condition?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis in the given scenario of a 16-year-old girl with intense food cravings followed by self-induced vomiting is bulimia nervosa. Fluoxetine is the first-line pharmacological treatment for her condition. Cognitive behavioral therapy is the first-line treatment for bulimia nervosa. 

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder, often seen in young women. It is characterized by binge-eating episodes, followed by inappropriate, compensatory measures to stop weight gain, like self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics, enema, and emetic abuse. These binge-eating episodes occur at least once a week and are present for at least 3 months. The patient fears gaining weight and has a relentless drive to be thin. 

The weight is normal in most patients with bulimia nervosa. However, few patients may either be overweight or underweight. There is a risk of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. 

Treatment modalities are cognitive behavioral therapy, psychotherapy, and antidepressants such as fluoxetine, imipramine, desipramine, trazodone, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

Other options:

Option A: Cyproheptadine can be used in treatment of restrictive anorexia nervosa. Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder that is often seen between the ages of 10 and 30. Typical features are self-induced starvation, voluntary and unhealthy reduction in weight, intense drive for thinness, and fear of becoming obese. 

Option C: Mirtazapine is used in major depressive disorder. It increases appetite and causes significant weight gain.

Option D: Buspirone is used in generalized anxiety disorder or social anxiety disorder.

questions.text:
You are a supervising officer doing a quality check of vaccine storage at a PHC. You need not perform a shake test on which of the following vaccines?
  1. MMR vaccine
  2. DPT vaccine
  3. Hepatitis B vaccine
  4. OPV
  5. Rabies vaccine
questions.solution:
MMR (Measles, mumps, rubella), OPV (Oral poliovirus vaccine), and rabies vaccines are not damaged by freezing. Hence shake test is not required for these vaccines.

The shake test is used to check if the freeze-sensitive vaccines have been damaged by exposure to temperatures below 0°C. Once it has been thawed, the vial of freeze-damage vaccine no longer has the appearance of a cloudy liquid but tends to form flakes that settle down at the bottom of the vial.

Steps to perform the shake test:

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial, and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing, and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than that in the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

  • Pentavalent

Vaccines like BCG, Japanese encephalitis(live and inactivated), MMR, OPV, Rabies, and Varicella-zoster virus vaccines do not lose their potency and efficacy on freezing. Hence, these vaccines can be used again once they liquefy.

questions.text: A newborn on routine head-to-toe examination was found to have ambiguous genitalia. Following a battery of lab-investigations, it was found to be 21-hydroxylase deficient. What is clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 21-hydroxylase deficiency causes congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which is a disorder of ambiguous genitalia.

The investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) in the newborn is by the measurement of 17-hydroxyprogesterone.

The diagnosis of 21-hydroxylase deficiency is most reliably established by measuring 17-hydroxyprogesterone before and 30 or 60 min after an intravenous bolus of 0.125-0.25mg of cosyntropin (ACTH).

However, prenatal diagnosis of 21-hydroxylase is possible late in the 1st trimester by analysis of DNA obtained by chorionic villus sampling or during the 2nd trimester by amniocentesis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with difficulty in hearing. A pure-tone audiogram was obtained, which is shown below. What is the interpretation of this audiogram?
questions.solution:
The given audiogram is suggestive of left-sided mixed hearing loss. 

Interpretation of the audiogram:

  • Blue colour indicates the left ear.
  • > indicates bone conduction (BC), and the threshold is >25 dB. Hence, BC is abnormal, which implies that the abnormality is in the sensorineural pathway.
  • × indicates air conduction (AC), and the threshold is >15 dB. Hence, AC is abnormal.
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal. It indicates sensorineural hearing loss.
  • In addition, the air-bone gap is present, which implies conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence, the interpretation is left-mixed hearing loss.

A mixed type of hearing loss presents with defects in both conductive and sensorineural pathways. This type of hearing loss is seen in chronic suppurative otitis media and otosclerosis.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was started on hormone replacement therapy. The patient is a bit worried about the risk of endometrial cancer. What is the minimum duration of progesterone to be added in a month to reduce the risk?
questions.solution:
A minimum of 12 days (in a month) of progesterone added to ERT reduces the risk of endometrial cancer to 2%.

Hormone replacement therapy and Endometrial carcinoma:

  • Estrogen replacement therapy (ERT) can cause well-differentiated carcinoma.
  • Combined estrogen and progesterone provides better protection against endometrial cancer.
  • Tibolone is a safe drug and does not cause endometrial hyperplasia.
  • Raloxifene, unlike tamoxifen, exerts anti-oestrogenic action on the endometrium.
  • The risk of cancer with ERT is dose and duration dependent.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with gastroparesis and was prescribed prucalopride. The receptor on which the drug acts is_____
questions.solution:
Prucalopride is a prokinetic agent that is used in the treatment of gastroparesis. Its prokinetic action is exerted mainly through 5-HT4 agonism.

Prucalopride exerts its action across the entire intestinal tract, enhancing the movement of contents from the mouth to the cecum and promoting the passage of material through the colon. It does not impact the rate at which the stomach empties. Prucalopride is prescribed for women dealing with persistent constipation that does not respond sufficiently to laxatives. Typical side effects include nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and headaches.

Other options:

Option A: Chlorpheniramine, loratadine, and cetirizine are H1 receptor antagonists used in the treatment of allergic rhinitis and urticaria.

Option B: Drugs like ranitidine are H2 receptor blockers that are primarily used in peptic ulcers, gastroesophageal reflux, and other gastric hypersecretory states

Option D: Sumatriptan is a 5HT 1B/1D agonist used in the treatment of acute attacks of moderate to severe migraine.

questions.text: An adult sustained a burn injury involving the bilateral lower limbs, genitalia, and one palm space burn area in the chest. What is the percentage of total burns surface area?
questions.solution:
The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 38% according to Wallace’s rule of nine.

In this case, the estimation of % total burns surface area is as follows.

  • Right lower limb (18%) + Left lower limb (18%) = 36%
  • Genitalia = 1%
  • One palm space are in the chest =1%

Therefore, the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 36 + 1 + 1 = 38%

 

Estimation of burns surface area:

Wallace’s rule of nine: It is used to calculate the percentage of burn.

It divides the body into segments that are approximately 9% or multiples of 9%, with the perineum forming the remaining 1%. The values are modified in the pediatric age group owing to the difference in the body surface area in adults and children.

For calculating the % surface area affected by small burns or patches of burns, a piece of clean paper is cut into the size of the patient's whole hand. This corresponds to 1% of total burns surface area (TBSA). The area affected by small burns is matched using this cut paper.

Note: Lund and Browder's chart is the most accurate in measuring the percentage of BSA affected.

Fluid resuscitation is done based on the estimated burns surface area using the Wallace rule. The fluid resuscitation formula for thermal burns is 4ml/kg/TBSA% given IV.

One-half of the calculated fluid need is given in the first 8 hours after the burn injury, and the remaining half is given over the subsequent 16 hours.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital in an agitated state and on examination, his BP was 98/66 mm Hg and respiratory rate was 28/min. He is a chronic asthma patient who has been on theophylline for a long time. His medical history shows the addition of a few new drugs 4 weeks ago for his other ailments like chronic gout, cough and peptic ulcer disease. Identify the drug which does not seem responsible for his present condition.
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is not responsible for this patient's agitation and low blood pressure as it increases theophylline's clearance by enzyme induction.

Theophylline is mainly metabolized by CYP1A2 in the liver and these drugs- erythromycin, cimetidine, and allopurinol inhibit CYP1A2, thereby decreasing the clearance of theophylline leading to agitation and hypotension. A dose reduction of theophylline may be necessary with these drugs.

Factors that decrease the clearance of theophylline are:

  • Drugs - erythromycin, cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, allopurinol, fluvoxamine, zileuton, zafirlukast
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Liver disease
  • Pneumonia
  • Viral infection and vaccination
  • High-carbohydrate diet
  • Old age

Factors that Increase the clearance of theophylline are:

  • Enzyme induction (mainly CYP1A2) by coadministered drugs (e.g. rifampicin, barbiturates, ethanol)
  • Smoking (tobacco, marijuana) via CYP1A2 induction
  • High-protein, low-carbohydrate diet
  • Barbecued meat.

Agitation and hypotension occur at concentrations > 25 micrograms/ml, while delirium occurs when levels rise to> 30 micrograms/ml. Arrhythmias and convulsions occur at concentrations of theophylline >35 microgram/ml.

questions.text: A G2P1 lady with 37 weeks of gestation is in active labor. You assist your labor room resident in giving a pudendal block. The resident explains that you have to approach the nerve by identifying a particular surface landmark. The landmark for this nerve block is:
questions.solution:
The ischial spine is the landmark for the pudendal nerve block. This is because the pudendal nerve is accessible here as it passes below the sacrospinous ligament at the level of attachment of the ligament to the ischial spine.

Sensory nerve fibers of the pudendal nerve arise from S2, S3, and S4 nerves. Pudendal nerve blocks in combination with local anesthetic are used to provide perineal anesthesia during the second stage of labor.

Here, a special needle (Koback)  and a guide (Iowa trumpet) are used. The needle is placed transvaginally underneath the ischial spine on each side and is advanced 1 to 1.5 cm through the sacrospinous ligament. 10 mL of 1% lidocaine or 2% chloroprocaine is used for the procedure.

The pudendal nerve block can be used for:

  • Analgesia during the second stage of labor. A pudendal block is used when there are contraindications to epidural/ spinal anesthesia or if there is a need for low vaginal and perineal anesthesia.
  • Episiotomy repair
  • Minor procedures of the lower vagina and perineum.
  • Instrumental delivery.

The complications of the procedure are accidental intravascular injection, retro-psoas abscess, subgluteal abscess, and retroperitoneal hematoma.

Also, note that the pudendal block does not impact the cervix or upper vagina and is ineffective for pain relief associated with uterine manipulation.

The below image shows the technique of localizing the pudendal nerve and administering a pudendal nerve block transvaginally.

questions.text: While activated B-cells produce IgM initially, they are able to produce IgG later in the disease course. Which of the following is responsible for this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon described in the question is immunoglobulin isotype switching. 

During class switching(Also known as isotype switching, or isotypic commutation, or class switch recombination (CSR), the same assembled VH (immunoglobulin variable region genes) can associate with different CH (immunoglobulin constant region genes) so that the immunoglobulins produced later are specific for the same antigen as the original IgM but have different biological characteristics. Class switching can occur only with heavy chains. Switch recombinase is the enzyme that catalyzes the rearrangement of VDJ genes during class switching. 

IL-4 enhances the class switching to IgE whereas IL-5 increases the IgA. Moreover, the interaction of the CD40 protein on the B-cell with the CD40 ligand on the helper T-cell also enables class switching. In hyper-IgM syndrome, there is a failure in the interaction of CD40 and CD40 ligand. This leads to an overproduction of IgM and a deficiency of IgG, IgA, and IgE.

Other options:

Somatic hypermutation (option A) is a cellular response by which the immune system modifies the immune response to antigens. It is done by adding nucleotides in V gene regions of heavy and light chains, resulting in a better fit of antigen with the antibodies. This increases the affinity of antibodies to antigens. Due to this, the subset of plasma cells with improved hypervariable regions is more strongly selected by the antigen and constitutes a larger part of the population of antibody-producing cells. This process is called affinity maturation (Option C).

Allelic exclusion (option D) is the process by which a cell expresses one of the two alleles of the gene and excludes the other allele. B cells are diploid, therefore, each B cell has six gene segment pools related to antibody chains: two heavy-chain pools (one from each parent) and four light-chain pools (one κ and one λ from each parent). However, each B cell uses only two of the six gene segment pools: one out of the two heavy-chain pools (maternal and paternal) and one out of the four light-chain pools. Thus, each B cell must choose not only between its κ and λ light-chain pools but also between its maternal and paternal light-chain and heavy-chain pools. This process of choosing is by allelic exclusion.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman who was a nonsmoker came to the medicine department with complaints of cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. Bronchoscopy suggested a lung carcinoma and biopsy showed a lepidic growth pattern. Which of the following is the most likely immunohistochemical marker for this lesion?

choices.text: Thyroid transcription factor-1 and napsin A

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a non-smoker woman presenting with cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, and lung biopsy showing a lepidic pattern (butterfly on the fence) is suggestive of adenocarcinoma of the lung. Immunohistochemical markers in adenocarcinoma lung are thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) and napsin A.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer seen in women and nonsmokers. Adenocarcinomas are usually located in the periphery as compared to other lung tumors and are relatively smaller in size. Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia is a precursor lesion of adenocarcinoma. Microscopic examination shows a lepidic pattern of growth at the periphery of the tumor. The tumor cells appear to crawl along the normal-appearing alveolar septa, as shown in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option A: Calretinin and cytokeratin 5/6 positive staining are seen in malignant mesothelioma. It is difficult to differentiate epithelioid mesothelioma grossly and histologically from adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemical stains help to make this differentiation. The image below shows the epithelioid type of mesothelioma showing cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. Inset shows strong positivity for calretinin immunohistochemical stain.

 

Option C: p40 and p63 are markers of squamous cell carcinoma lung. It is the most common cancer found in smokers. Histologically it is characterized by the presence of keratinization and markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm as shown below.


Option D: Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers of small cell carcinoma lung. Due to the encrustation by DNA from the necrotic cancer cells, vascular walls in the necrotic area take up basophilic staining as shown below. This is called the Azzopardi effect.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented at term with a USG report suggesting fetus in breech position and on per vaginal examination, toes of the foot can be felt. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the fetus is in a footling breech position at term, which is an indication for the cesarean section.

In footling breech, one or both legs are extended at the hip, so that the foot is the presenting part.

A major complication of breech presentation is cord prolapse. In the cord prolapse, the umbilical cord drops down below the presenting part of the baby and becomes compressed.

Factors favoring cesarean delivery of the breech fetus:

  • Large fetus: > 3800 to 4000 g
  • Apparently healthy and viable preterm fetus either with active labor or with indicated delivery
  • Severe IUGR
  • Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse)
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Preterm breech
  • Primi with breech
  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech

questions.text: What is Maydl's hernia?

choices.text: The hernia sac containing only a portion of the circumference of the bowel
Presence of 2 small bowel loops with an intervening intra-abdominal loop in a single hernial sac
Protrusion of a Meckel’s diverticulum through an abdominal opening
Presence of both direct and indirect hernia on same side simultaneously in a patient

questions.solution:
Maydl's hernias are defined as the presence of 2 small bowel loops with an intervening intra-abdominal loop in a single hernial sac, that is, there are two efferent and two afferent loops of the bowel, forming a "W" shape.

 

Option A:

Richter’s hernia is a type of hernia where the sac contains only a portion of circumference of the bowel.

Option C:

Littre’s hernia is the protrusion of Meckel’s diverticulum through an abdominal opening.

Option D:

Pantaloon hernia is the presence of both direct and indirect hernia on same side simultaneously in a patient.

questions.text: A researcher wants to do a study on the association between high blood pressure and recurrent headaches. He noticed that the presence of association was high when the samples were taken from NCD clinics (Non-communicable diseases clinics) than when taken from the general population. This is known as:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Berkesonian bias.

Berkesonian bias applies to hospital-based case-control studies. It occurs due to differential hospital admission rates. It is a type of selection bias termed after Joseph Berkeson who described it. It can arise when the sample is taken not from the general population, but from a subpopulation. It was first recognized in case-control studies when both cases and controls are sampled from a hospital rather than from the community.

Other options:

Option A: Hawthorne bias occurs due to change in attitude or actions of the subjects when they are aware they are under observation.

Option B: Neyman bias or prevalence-incidence bias is due to selective survival in prevalent cases. It is usually seen in fatal diseases.

Option C: The interviewer's bias occurs when the person conducting the case-control study knows the hypothesis and who the cases are. This may lead to the interviewer questioning the cases more thoroughly than controls regarding the history of the causal factor.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: What is the interpretation of the abnormal sign shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Trendelenburg’s sign positive. The hip is sagging on the right side which indicates superior gluteal nerve palsy on the left side.

Trendelenburg's sign positive can be caused mainly due to the injury to gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, or superior gluteal nerve (nerve supplying the abductors), and not inferior gluteal nerve.

Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb.

Causes of positive Trendelenburg sign:

  • Paralysis of abductor's muscles: Gluteus medius and gluteus minimus (injury, polio)
  • Damage to the superior gluteal nerve
  • Dislocation of the hip
  • Destruction of the head of the femur
  • Fracture neck of the femur

Mnemonic: Sound Side Sag

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presented with abdominal pain, arthralgia, tendon xanthomas, and xanthelasma. Laboratory investigation revealed elevated total cholesterol levels. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in ABCG5 and ABCG8. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the genetic testing showing mutations in ABCG5 and ABCG8 points to the diagnosis of sitosterolemia.

It is an inherited condition in which the body absorbs an excessive amount of plant sterols. ATP-binding cassette transporter helps in the transport of sterols into the gut lumen once they enter the gastrointestinal cells. In a person with sitosterolemia, the ABC transporter is defective. Hence, the plant sterols are not transported into the gut lumen and the liver cannot excrete sterols into the bile as effectively. This results in excessive accumulation of plant sterols in the individual's blood which can lead to premature heart disease and other complications.

The genes ABCG5 and ABCG8 encode for the ABC transporter proteins. Clinical features are tendon xanthomas, corneal arcus, xanthelasma, abdominal pain, and arthralgia. Laboratory investigations show increased total cholesterol levels.

Management involves significant dietary modifications. Intake of vegetable oils, nuts, and avocados should be reduced. Ezetimibe is approved for the treatment.

Other options:

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. Clinical features of Tangier disease include hyperplastic yellow-orange tonsils, hepatosplenomegaly, and peripheral neuropathy, which may be either relapsing-remitting or chronic progressive in nature

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes hyperchylomicronemia (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk of coronary disease. Instead, patients have an increased risk of acute pancreatitis. This is due to very high triglyceride levels. It can also cause a milky appearance of plasma.

Option D: Type III hyperlipoproteinemia is also known as broad β-disease, remnant removal disease, or familial dysbetalipoproteinemia. Type III hyperlipoproteinemia is caused by a defective ApoE that mediated the removal of lipoprotein remnants. Clinical features include hypercholesterolemia, xanthomas, and atherosclerosis. There is an increase in remnant chylomicrons, remnant VLDL (i.e.Intermediate-density lipoprotein), cholesterol, and triglyceride levels. Fibrates are effective in treating patients with type III hyperlipoproteinemia.

questions.text: Your senior resident while screening for cervical cancer in a 36-year-old female, advises for a  pap smear test. She asks you regarding the prerequisites of this test. Which of the following is not required in this case?

choices.text: A vaginal examination is required before taking a pap smear
The patient should not have intercourse 24hr prior to the test

questions.solution:
Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Pap smear should be done before performing a vaginal examination because the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report.

Pap/ Papanicolaou test

  • It is a screening test only.
  • A positive test requires further evaluation - colposcopy, cervical biopsy, fractional curettage should be done.
  • It can be used for screening premalignant and malignant conditions and can also identify other local conditions.

Prerequisites:

  • Should be done prior to vaginal examination.
  • Lubricants should not be used.
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test.
  • Ideal time is around ovulation.
  • The patient should not have intercourse 24hr prior to the test.

Procedure

  • The patient is put in dorsal position & labia parted.
  • Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced.
  • The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayre’s spatula.
  • Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush.
  • Samples are spread separately on 1 or 2 glass slides.
  • The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol.
  • Stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

questions.text: A patient suffered from a myocardial infarction because of thrombosis of the coronary arteries. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to this pro-thrombotic state?
questions.solution:
ADP would have contributed to the pro-thrombotic state in this patient.

Following a traumatic vascular injury, the circulating platelets come in contact with the subendothelial connective tissue. Platelet adhesion is mediated by GpIb glycoprotein receptor present on the platelets and the von Willebrand factor (vWF) present on the exposed tissue below the vascular endothelium. Following this, the platelets rapidly change shape and release granule contents. This is known as platelet activation. ADP, which is present in dense granules, causes the activation of more platelets by binding to P2Y12 receptor. This phenomenon is called recruitment. The next step is platelet aggregation. GpIIb/IIIa undergoes a conformational change during platelet activation and allows binding to fibrinogen, leading to their aggregation. 

Local activation of the coagulation cascade occurs following the formation of the platelet plug. This leads to fibrin polymerization and cementing of the platelets into the definitive secondary hemostatic plug. However, there are certain counter-regulatory mechanisms that keep the process of coagulation limited to the site of the injury. This includes fibrinolysis, which is mediated by plasmin. Fibrin is broken down during this process and its further polymerization is stopped. Plasmin is generated by the catabolism of the precursor plasminogen by circulating plasminogen activators, such as t-PA (option A). Furthermore, thrombomodulin (option B) binds to thrombin and converts it into an anti-coagulant. Prostacyclin (option D) is PGI2. It is produced by the intact endothelium and acts as a potent vasodilator and an inhibitor of platelet aggregation.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with rigidity, tremors, and blank facial expressions. The doctor prescribes him selegiline. Which of the following statements is not true about this drug?

choices.text: When administered along with levodopa it decreases wearing-off effect.
It increases the dopamine level in the brain.
It is a selective and reversible MAO-A inhibitor.
It is contraindicated in patients with convulsion disorders.

questions.solution:
The clinical features of rigidity, tremors, and blank facial expressions are suggestive of Parkinson's disease. Selegiline is a selective and irreversible MAO-B inhibitor.

Monoamine oxidase-B (MAO-B) inhibitors like selegiline and rasagiline are used for the treatment of Parkinson's disease.

Normally, MAO-B oxidizes dopamine. Selegiline is a selective and irreversible MAO-B inhibitor. Therefore, it increases dopamine levels in the brain. It is used as an adjuvant to levodopa in Parkinson's disease. When administered with levodopa it decreases the wearing-off effect and prolongs the action of levodopa.

Adverse effects of selegiline are postural hypotension, nausea, confusion, involuntary movements, and psychosis. Selegiline is contraindicated in patients with convulsive disorders.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy complains of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever and profuse ear discharge. Clinical examination shows mastoid tenderness and perforation of the tympanic membrane. If the pus in this infection breaks through the bony wall between the antrum and external osseous meatus, it results in the formation of  a _____________
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute mastoiditis that has occurred as a complication of acute infection of the middle ear. If the pus in this infection breaks through the bony wall between the antrum and external osseous meatus, it results in the formation of Luc abscess(Meatal Abscess) and presents as a swelling in the deep part of the bony meatus

Other abscesses related to mastoid infection:

  • Post auricular abscess - Commonest abscess that forms over the mastoid. In infants and children, this presents over the MacEwen’s triangle.
  • Zygomatic abscess - infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma
  • Bezold abscess - In this case, the pus breaks through the medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck
  • Citelli’s abscess - Here, the abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone
