questions.text:
Which of the following procedure is helpful in the management of a patient with a recurrent BCC near the right eye?

MOHS- Microscopically Oriented Histographic Surgery
questions.solution:
For a case of recurrent basal cell carcinoma located near the eye, MOHS (Microscopically Oriented Histographic Surgery) is preferred. 

Mohs’ microscopic surgery/MOHS involves a process of initial surgical excision of the tumor, followed by repeated tissue sampling along lateral and deep margins. This procedure attains a high rate of local tumor control through the use of horizontal frozen sections. These tissue samples are examined immediately under frozen section control for evidence of tumor. This process is repeated until the clearance is finally obtained.

MMS is preferred in:

  • Recurrent tumors
  • High-risk tumors
  • Primaries with perineural invasion
  • Lesions with diameters >2 cm
  • Poorly differentiated lesions
  • Tumors with irregular margins
  • Tumors in anatomic areas such as the eye, nose, mouth, and ear, where tissue preservation is important.

BCC is a slow-growing, locally invasive, malignant tumor of epithelial cells arising from the basal epidermis and hair follicles. Despite its high prevalence, there is an extremely rare occurrence of metastases. Mutation in the hedgehog signaling pathway is associated with basal cell carcinoma. 

Management of BCC can be surgical or non-surgical.

  • Non-surgical
     
    • It is radiosensitive. If the lesion is away from the vital structure (like away from the eyes), then curative radiotherapy can be given. Radiotherapy is not given, once it erodes cartilage or bone. RT is not given to the BCC of the ear and is close to lacrimal canaliculi.
    • The small molecule inhibitor of the hedgehog pathway vismodegib maybe be used.

  • Surgical

    • Wide excision (1 cm clearance) with skin grafting, primary suturing, or flap (Z plasty, rhomboid flap, rotation flap) is the procedure of choice.
    • Laser surgery, photodynamic therapy, 5 fluorouracil local application.
    • Cryosurgery.
    • MOHS (Microscopically Oriented Histographic Surgery)- useful in conditions like BCC close to eyes, nose, or ear, to preserve more tissue

questions.text: The parents of a three-year-old boy are seeking a therapist for their son. He is a three-year-old with normal developmental milestones but with poor speech abilities, inability to socialize with peers, restricted and repetitive behaviour with impaired non-verbal communication. Which of the following conditions is the boy most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a 3-year-old boy having poor speech abilities and inability to socialize but has normal developmental milestones is most likely suffering from autism.

Autism spectrum disorder refers to a phenotypically heterogeneous group of neurodevelopmental syndromes, characterized by a wide range of impairments in social communication along with restricted and repetitive behaviors. It is four times more common in boys than in girls.

Prior to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Dis­orders (DSM-5), autism spectrum disorder was conceptualized as five different disorders, that included autistic disorder, Asperger's disorder, childhood disintegrative disorder, Rett syndrome, and pervasive developmental disorder not otherwise specified.

The DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for autism spectrum disorder are:
  • Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction that includes a failure to communicate, lack of empathy, abnormalities in eye contact, stereotyped or absent speech, and either hyper or hypo-arousal to the environment
  • Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities, as manifested by any two of the following: (i) Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects or speech (ii) insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines, or ritualized patterns of verbal/nonverbal behavior (iii) highly restricted and fixated interests (iv) hyper or hypoactivity to sensory input
  • Symptoms are present in the early developmental period, but may not fully manifest until later in life.
  • Symptoms cause impairment in social, occupational, and other important areas of functioning.
  • The disturbances cannot be explained by any intellectual disability.

It can be diagnosed by using the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule-Generic (ADOS-G).

Other options:

Option A: Schizophrenia is characterized by hallucinations or delusions, and childhood-onset schizophrenia has a lower incidence of seizures, intellectual disability, and poor social skills. It is rare in children younger than 5 years. 

Option C: Language Disorder is equally common in boys and girls. The child actively uses non-verbal communication like gestures and any impaired social communication, restricted and repetitive behavior is absent.

Option D: ADHD (Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder) is characterized by a poor attention span with distractibility, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.

questions.text: A female patient presented with painful swelling and watering in her left eye for a few weeks. Examination revealed the following finding. Which of the following treatment is not preferred for her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of painful swelling and watering of eyes along with the image showing a reddish swelling in the lid with edema is suggestive of hordeolum externum or stye. Intralesional injection of triamcinolone is not useful in its management. Injection of triamcinalone into and around the lesion is done for chalazion.

Hordeolum externum or stye is the staphylococcal infection of the Zeis gland or Moll gland. It presents as a collection of pus usually pointing at the base of a single cilium. The entire lid may be edamatous. Treatment is with antibiotics and a warm compress. The abscess may also be drained by pulling out the affected cilia. Incision and drainage may also be done. 

A chalazion is a sterile chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland due to retained sebaceous secretion. It is also called a tarsal or meibomian cyst. Complete spontaneous resolution occurs rarely. Oral antibiotics are only required for lesions with significant bacterial infections. Daily hot compression can help in the resolution of early lesions. Treatment includes incision and curettage, which is conventional and effective. Intralesional injection of steroid into and around the lesions give a similar resolution to incision and curettage.

An image of chalazion is shown below.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt trauma to the abdomen. He is diagnosed to have a retroperitoneal injury with a pulsatile hematoma in the zone highlighted in the image below. Which of the following is true about the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The area highlighted in the image represents Zone 2 of the retroperitoneum and an injury here with a pulsatile hematoma should be treated surgically.

The retroperitoneum is divided into 3 zones, based on the types of viscera and their differential management in blunt trauma.

Zone 1 Central Always explored, after proximo-distal vascular control
Zone 2 Lateral Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization
Zone 3 Pelvic Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization

If there is a penetrative injury in any of the zones, surgical management is done. Pelvic hematomas are difficult to control. Compression and extraperitoneal packing are preferred whenever possible.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about tuberculosis of larynx?

choices.text: Hyperaemia with impairment of adduction of vocal cords is the first sign
Affects posterior part of the larynx more commonly
Turban epiglottis can be seen on examination

questions.solution:
Tuberculosis of the larynx is a painful condition. Ulceration in the larynx gives rise to severe pain which may radiate to the ears. Swallowing is painful with marked dysphagia in later stages.

Tuberculosis of the larynx:
It occurs secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. Posterior part of the larynx is more affected than the anterior.

Parts affected in the order of involvement are:

  • Interarytenoid fold
  • Ventricular bands
  • Vocal cords
  • Epiglottis

Symptoms include weakness of voice which is the earliest symptom followed by hoarseness. Severe pain due to ulceration in the larynx which may radiate to the ears. Swallowing is painful with marked dysphagia in later stages.

Laryngeal examination:

  • Hyperemia of the vocal cord with impairment of adduction is the first sign.
  • Swelling in the inter arytenoid region giving a mamillated appearance.
  • Ulceration of vocal cord giving a mouse-nibbled appearance.
  • Superficial ragged ulceration and granulation tissue on the arytenoids and interarytenoid region.
  • Pseudoedema of the epiglottis-turban epiglottis.
  • Swelling of ventricular bands and aryepiglottic folds.
  • Marked pallor of surrounding mucosa.

It is diagnosed with the help of chest Xray, sputum examination, and biopsy of laryngeal lesion is essential to exclude carcinoma

It is treated with anti-tubercular drugs and voice rest.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 8 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic for her routine evaluation. On performing a bimanual examination, you notice regular rhythmic contractions of the uterine wall. Which early sign of pregnancy is being elicited here?
questions.solution:
The early sign of pregnancy being elicited here is the Palmer's sign.

Palmer’s sign denotes the regular, rhythmic contractions of the uterine wall during a bimanual examination. It is seen as early as 4-8 weeks of gestation.

Other options:

Option A- Hegar’s sign is an early sign of pregnancy. At 6-8 weeks of gestation, the lower part of the uterus softens and on bimanual examination, the approximation of vaginal and abdominal fingers is possible.

Option C- Osiander's sign describes the pulsations felt in the lateral fornix due to increased vascularity. It is seen around 8 weeks of gestation.

Option D- Goodell’s sign is a sign of early pregnancy which describes the marked softening of the cervix in contrast to the non-pregnant state. It is seen around 6-8 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: Which of the following respiratory sounds is correctly matched with the cause?

choices.text: Stridor - Obstruction of larynx or trachea

questions.solution:
Stridor is produced due to the obstruction of the larynx or trachea. 

Stridor is an audible respiratory noise that gets produced by turbulent airflow through an obstructed upper airway. It is an inspiratory sound that may have an expiratory component. It is distinct from stertor which is a snoring-like noise produced from an obstructed nasopharynx or oropharynx. 

The intensity and pitch of sounds originating from the respiratory system vary based on their site of origin within the respiratory tract and may be heard with or without a stethoscope. Usually, the pitch of the sound increases, and the intensity decreases as one goes lower into the respiratory tract. Extrathoracic airway obstruction produces inspiratory sounds, intrathoracic major airway produces inspiratory as well as expiratory sounds and distal airway obstruction produces predominantly expiratory sounds.

Acute stridor may be seen in the epiglottis and croup while chronic stridor may be seen in laryngomalacia.

Other options:

Option A: Snoring is caused by oropharyngeal obstruction and is a low-pitched irregular inspiratory sound. It may be accompanied by hoarseness, dyspnea, retractions of the chest during inspiration, and use of accessory muscles of respiration. 

Option B: Wheeze is a continuous high-pitched expiratory musical sound produced due to lower airway obstruction such as partial obstruction of the bronchi and bronchioles. A wheeze can be heard in bronchial asthma, bronchiolitis, and viral infection of the lower respiratory tract.

Option D: Grunting is an expiratory sound produced due to partial closure of the glottis.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

X-ray neck shows steeple sign

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign

questions.text:
Which of the following may be treated/may be achieved with the management modality demonstrated in the image below?

1 - Osteomyelitis
2 - Arthrodesis
3 - Nerve injury
4 - Limb lengthening
5 - Osteoporosis
questions.solution:
The management modality shown in the image is Ilizarov's technique. It is used in the following scenarios:

  • Limb lengthening
  • Non-union
  • Deformity correction
  • Osteomyelitis - as it offers the possibility of liberal excision of bone
  • Arthrodesis - crushing articular surfaces can stimulate union between opposing bones

Ilizarov's technique:

Distraction osteogenesis is the mechanical induction of new bone that occurs between bony surfaces that are gradually pulled apart. Ilizarov described this as “the tension stress effect.”

The most important application of the tension-stress principle is known as callus distraction (or callotaxis). A careful fracture of the bone is performed, followed by a short wait. The young callus formed is gradually distracted using a circular or unilateral external fixator. 

Osteogenesis requires a dynamic state by either a controlled distraction or a controlled compression. This dynamic force causes dormant mesenchymal cells at the non-union site to differentiate into functioning osteoblasts. This results in bone synthesis and fracture healing. The fixation system is called a ring fixator.  Distraction or compression can be applied by twisting nuts on the fixation system at the fracture or corticotomy site.  Distraction or compression is carried out at the rate of 1 mm per day. This is done in four sittings— ¼ mm, four times a day. This is used in limb lengthening or filling of large segmental defects in the bone.

questions.text: According to Casper's dictum, which of the following is correct with respect to the rate of decomposition of a body in air, water, and soil?
questions.solution:
Casper dictum states that a body decomposes in air twice as rapidly as in water, and eight times as rapidly as in earth. Therefore, the rate of decomposition is Air > Water > Soil. It is helpful in the estimation of time since death.  

Free access of air hastens putrefaction, partly because the air conveys organisms to the body. Putrefaction is rapid in a body buried in a damp, marshy or shallow grave without clothes or coffin, because the body is exposed to constant changes of temperature. Putrefaction is more rapid in warm, fresh water than in cold, salt water. It is more rapid in stagnant water than in running water.

Note: Forensic taphonomy is the study and interpretation of postmortem processes of human remains i.e. the history of a body following death.

The ratio of the time a body takes to decompose in air, water, and soil is 1:2:8. This means that the time taken by soil is greater than water and air. So, the correct order of time taken for decomposition is Soil > Water > Air. But, in this question, the rate of decomposition is asked, therefore, it is faster in air followed by water and soil i.e, Air > Water > Soil. (Note - Greater than is denoted by '>' and Less than is denoted by '<' i.e the opening is towards the higher side)

questions.text: A woman with a history of severe postpartum hemorrhage during her delivery 2 years ago has now been diagnosed with Sheehan syndrome. Which of the following is the most common hormone to be affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Prolactin is the most common hormone that is affected in the case of Sheehan syndrome. 

In the case of Sheehan syndrome prolactin secretion deficiency is the most common, followed by loss of gonadotropin and growth hormone release, loss of ACTH production, and lastly decrease in thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) secretion.

Sheehan syndrome refers to panhypopituitarism. It classically follows massive postpartum hemorrhage and associated hypotension. The abrupt, severe hypotension leads to pituitary ischemia and necrosis. Patients with the most severe form develop shock due to pituitary apoplexy. Pituitary apoplexy is characterized by a sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits, and hormonal dysfunction due to acute hemorrhage or infarction within the pituitary. In less severe forms, loss of gonadotrope activity in the pituitary leads to anovulation and subsequent amenorrhea. Damage to the other specific pituitary cell types leads to a failure to lactate, loss of sexual and axillary hair, and hypothyroidism or adrenal insufficiency symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has the following laparoscopic finding?
questions.solution:
The findings seen in the given laparoscopic image are powder burn spots over the peritoneum. This is seen in endometriosis.

  • Typically, there are small black dots, the so called "powder burns"/"gunshot appearance" seen on the uterosacral ligaments and pouch of Douglas.
  • Fibrosis and scarring in the peritoneum surrounding the implants is also a typical finding which is known as "Allen Masters syndrome".
  • Other subtle appearances are: red flame shaped areas, red polypoid areas, yellow brown patches, white peritoneal areas, circular peritoneal defects or subovarian adhesions.
  • These lesions are thought to be more active than the “powder burn” areas.

Other pathology in Endometriosis:

  • Peritoneal cavity: contains yellowish brown fluid which has prostaglandin repsonsible for the pain of endometriosis.
  • Ovary: "Chocolate cyst" (True cyst with columnar epithelium lining)

questions.text: 99mTc pertechnetate scan is not likely to be useful for:
questions.solution:
A 99mTc pertechnetate scan may be indicated in cases of vesicoureteric reflux, to identify bleeding from a Meckel's diverticulum and thyroid scintigraphy. 99mTc-pertechnetate is taken up by ectopic gastric mucosa and not ectopic pancreatic tissue.

Option A: Direct isotope cystography using 99mTc-pertechnetate is used to assess vesicoureteric reflux (VUR), particularly in girls, where urethral anatomy is usually normal. It is also used as VUR follow-up in baby boys. An indirect radionuclide cystogram (IRC) with 99mTc-MAG3 renogram is preferred in older continent cooperative children as a non-invasive means of assessing for VUR.

Option B: A 99mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan can detect gastric mucosa and is helpful in confirming bleeding from a Meckel diverticulum and diagnosing duplication cysts that present with GI bleeding.

Option D: Thyroid scintigraphy may be done using technetium-99m pertechnetate or a radiolabeled I123 or I131. It normally displays symmetric uptake bilaterally. These scans may be used to assess for an autonomous nodule in a case of nodular thyroid with suppressed TSH and in cases of suspected thyroiditis with inconclusive blood tests.

It is useful for rapid-sequence induction.
It is a method of assessment of airway.
In this technique, pressure is applied on the thyroid cartilage.

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding the BURP maneuver is that pressure is applied to the thyroid cartilage.

BURP is a technique of external laryngeal manipulation of the airway during intubation for better visualization of the larynx. This involves Backward, Upward, and Rightward Pressure on the thyroid cartilage.

The illustration shown below shows the BURP maneuver.

Other options : 

Option B: The BURP maneuver should not be confused with Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), which involves the application of pressure to the cricoid cartilage, thus occluding the esophagus. This technique is used in rapid-sequence induction to reduce the risk of aspiration.

Option C: BURP is not a method of assessment of the airway. Various methods of airway assessments are Mallampati grading, Cormack and Lehane grading, and Wilson’s scoring.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman presents with vasomotor symptoms. She underwent hysterectomy 5 years ago. The gynecologist plans to put her on hormone therapy. Which of the following would be preferred in her case?
questions.solution:
In hysterectomized patients progesterone is not needed, therefore they can be treated with estrogen-only therapy.

Hormone therapy is only indicated for the treatment of vasomotor symptoms, osteoporosis (prevention and treatment), and vaginal atrophy.

Other treatments: 

Hormonal Non-Hormonal Non-prescriptive

Estrogen therapy (Most effective)

Oestrogen+Progesterone (HRT)

Tibolone

Clonidine 

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor like Fluoxetine

Dopamine antagonist

Vitamin E

Soya 

Isoflavones

For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur after 6 months of estrogen therapy. For women without uterus just estrogen therapy is sufficient.

questions.text: A 55-year-old locomotive operator presents with complaints of worm-like swelling over his right leg. During clinical examination, a Brodie Trendelenburg test is performed. Which of the following statements is false regarding the test?

choices.text: A tourniquet can be used for occluding the saphenofemoral junction
Rapid filling  from above indicates saphenofemoral incompetence
Gradual filling  from below upwards indicates saphenopopliteal incompetence
Positive Brodie Trendelenburg test indicates a need for surgery

questions.solution:
The gradual filling of veins from below upwards indicates the perforator incompetence. Brodie Trendelenberg test is performed to test for the incompetence of the saphenofemoral valve and the communicating system.

1. Trendelenburg’s test - Lay the patient down and elevate the leg. Empty the vessels and tie a tourniquet below the SFJ. Ask the patient to stand up:

  • Trendelenburg’s test part ll - Here the tourniquet is not released. A gradual filling from below to upwards indicates perforator incompetence.
  • Trendelenburg’s test part l - Here the tourniquet is released. A rapid filling from above shows the saphenofemoral incompetence.

2. Morrisey’s cough impulse: the patient is asked to cough. A cough impulse at the saphenofemoral junction indicates SFJ incompetence.

3. Schwartz test: If a thrill is felt at SFJ on tapping over the incompetent vein, indicates SFJ incompetence.

4. Modified Perthes test: A tourniquet is tied below SFJ and the patient is asked to walk. An increase in pain and prominence of dilated veins indicate DVT.

5. Fegan’s method - Mark the places of excessive bulges within the varicosities. Ask the patient to lie down and empty the varicose vessels. Palpate along the marked area to look for gaps and pits in the deep fascia, which indicates perforator incompetence.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with low-grade fever and a characteristic slapped cheek appearance. She is suspected to have erythema infectiosum. Which of the following is true regarding the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Erythema infectiosum is caused by parvovirus B19 virus, which is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus. 

The main manifestation of symptomatic parvovirus B19 virus infection is erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease, which most commonly occurs in children of early school age or infants. Fever and mild constitutional symptoms may accompany the rash, which has a typical slapped cheek appearance.

 Pure red cell aplasia and chronic hemolytic anemia have been reported in patients with immunosuppression. Parvovirus B19V infection during pregnancy can lead to non-immune hydrops fetalis and/or fetal loss.

The given image shows the classical slapped cheek appearance of erythema infectiosum.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with multiple sclerosis was prescribed alemtuzumab. The mechanism by which the drug acts, that helps in the treatment of this condition is_______

choices.text: Binds with T-cell receptor complex and block antigen recognition
Binds to CD52 and causes lysis of the cell
Inhibiting antigen presenting cells by attaching to CD80 and CD86

questions.solution:
Alemtuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that attaches to CD52 and causes the lysis of B cells, T cells, macrophages, and natural killer cells.

It is used mainly for induction of immunosuppressive therapy and allows the avoidance of the early high dose of steroids. Also used for the treatment of multiple sclerosis and chronic lymphocytic leukemia

Other options:

Option A: Muromonab is a monoclonal antibody that attaches to CD3. It binds with the T-cell receptor complex and blocks antigen recognition.

Option C: Daclizumab and Basiliximab prevent IL-2 receptor-mediated T-cell activation.

Option D: Belatacept acts by inhibiting antigen-presenting cells by attaching to CD80 and CD86.

questions.text:
Which of the following forms the triad of West syndrome?
  1. Infantile spasm
  2. Developmental regression 
  3. Tuberous sclerosis
  4. Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)
  5. Developmental delay
questions.solution:
Infantile spasms, developmental regression, and hypsarrhythmia (on EEG) form the triad of West syndrome.

West syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy syndrome that begins in infancy. The age of onset is 3–8 months of life. The causes include hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, neurocutaneous syndromes, and idiopathic. It is characterized by a triad of

  • Infantile spasm (also called salaam spells) is a convulsive disease characterized by brief, symmetric axial muscle contraction (neck, trunk, and/or extremities)
  • Developmental regression
  • Hypsarrhythmia (Himalayan wave pattern) on EEG: Characterized by a high-voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes 

West syndrome is treated with:

  • ACTH injections
  • Vigabatrin if associated with tuberous sclerosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition. The histopathology image of the swelling is given below. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: It is associated with RET mutations
Foci of lymphatic invasion may be present
Associated with a history of exposure to ionising radiation
Metastatic calcification bodies are considered a hallmark microscopic feature

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing papillae lined by cells with overlapping nuclei and Orphan Annie eye nuclei indicate a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of thyroid (PTC). One of the microscopic hallmarks of PTC is psammoma bodies, which are an example of dystrophic calcification, not metastatic calcificaiton.

Papillary carcinoma of thyroid (PTC) presents as a painless nodule or mass in the neck or enlargement of cervical lymph nodes. It usually occurs in women between 25 to 50 years of age. PTC is the most common thyroid cancer associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation. Conventional PTCs have translocations involving RET or NTRK, and point mutations involving BRAF gene.

On microscopy, branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk covered with multiple layers of anaplastic cuboidal epithelial cells are seen. Because of fine dispersion of the chromatin, the nuclei appear optically clear and are referred to as ground-glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei. Nuclear pseudoinclusions, which occur due to inward invagination of the nuclear membrane, may also be seen. The characteristic nuclear features of PTC can be used to make the diagnosis even if the classic papillary architecture is not seen. Dystrophic calcification in the form of psammoma bodies are often seen in the core of the papillae. Lymphatic invasion may frequently be present, but the involvement of blood vessels is rare. 


PTC is associated with an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate of more than 95%.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is alirocumab approved for use?

choices.text: Cystic fibrosis patients >12 years of age

questions.solution:
Alirocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that is approved for use in familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are a new class of lipid-lowering medications that are administered as monthly or bimonthly subcutaneous injections. PCSK9 is a binding protein that is expressed in hepatocytes and on secretion, binds to the LDL receptors, and promotes their degradation. By blocking PCSK9, these drugs increase the availability of LDL receptors leading to better removal of LDL cholesterol from circulation. Another approved PCSK-9 inhibitor is evolocumab.

Other options: 

Option B: Fremanezumab and galcanezumab are anti-CGRP monoclonal antibodies approved by the FDA in 2018 for the preventive treatment of migraine in adults.

Option C: Tezacaftor/Ivacaftor is FDA approved for cystic fibrosis patients >12 years of age. It facilitates the opening of chloride channels.

Option D: Plecanatide is FDA-approved for the treatment of chronic idiopathic constipation. It activates guanylate cyclase-C on endothelial cells in the GI tract and thus draws water into the lumen, leading to stool softening.

questions.text: An elderly man presented with a painful and swollen right knee, and difficulty in walking. After examining the knee joint, aspiration is done. The following image is seen on the examination of synovial fluid using compensated polarized microscopy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image of weakly positive birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals are suggestive of pseudogout.

Pseudogout is a condition that occurs due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals (CPPD). It presents with features similar to acute gout and predominantly affects the elderly. This is attributable to the increased levels of inorganic pyrophosphate in diseased or aging cartilage which promotes CPP crystal nucleation and their deposition.

Acute attacks of CPPD presents with joint swelling and pain, affecting the knee (most common), wrist, shoulders, elbows, and hands. It also has systemic features of inflammation including fever, chills, and elevated CRP. Chronic CPPD commonly presents as polyarticular arthritis resembling osteoarthritis (pseudo-osteoarthritis). It affects atypical joints such as metacarpophalangeal, wrist, elbow, and ankle joints causing severe damage.

X-ray or ultrasonography of the joint shows chondrocalcinosis, which is punctate or linear radiodense deposits in the joint menisci or articular cartilage. Detection of rod-like or rhomboid crystals in synovial fluid or articular cartilage is diagnostic of pseudogout.

Other options :

Option A: Osteoarthritis also affects the elderly. Commonly involved joints are the hip, knee, and first metatarsal phalangeal joint (MTP). The synovial fluid in osteoarthritis is non-inflammatory. If the synovial fluid white blood cell count is >1000/μL, it is likely to be due to inflammatory arthritis, gout, or pseudogout.

Option C: Gouty arthritis is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals (MSU) crystals which are needle-shaped and negatively birefringent. They appear yellowish when observed under polarized light. Below image shows needle-shaped, monosodium urate crystal in gout.

Option D: Psoriatic arthritis usually occurs after the development of skin lesions in a patient with psoriasis. It usually presents with dactylitis (involving the distal interphalangeal joint) and enthesitis. It is diagnosed by X-ray features of pencil-in-cup deformity, marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation (whiskering) and telescoping of digits.

questions.text: During a pandemic of influenza a drug that inhibits the elution process of the virus was used. Identify this drug?
questions.solution:
Oseltamivir is a viral neuraminidase inhibitor that inhibits the elution process of the virus.

Elution is the process of reversal of hemagglutination and the release of the virus from the red cell surface. This occurs due to neuraminidase (NA) which is present on the surface of the influenza virus. (Influenza contains two surface antigens HA and NA). Neuraminidase destroys the receptor which is used for binding. Hence, it is also called a receptor destroying enzyme (RDE). Oseltamivir inhibits neuraminidase activity and leads to viral aggregation at the cell surface and reduced virus spread within the respiratory epithelium. 

Options A and D: Interference with the M2 protein of influenza virus is seen with amantadine and rimantadine.

Option C: The endonuclease inhibitor for the treatment of acute uncomplicated influenza in adults is baloxavir marboxil.

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought to the OPD with complaints of decreased response to noise stimulus and persistent nasal discharge. On examination, a saddle nose and notched upper central incisors were observed. Ocular examination revealed interstitial keratitis. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, a history of decreased response to noise stimulus (sensorineural hearing loss), notched upper central incisors(Hutchinson teeth) on examination, and interstitial keratitis on ocular examination is suggestive of Hutchinson's triad of congenital syphilis. Hennebert sign is seen in congenital syphilis.

A false-positive fistula test (i.e. positive fistula test without the presence of a fistula) is seen in congenital syphilis and in about 25% of cases of Méniére’s disease and is called the Hennebert sign. In congenital syphilis, it is due to hypermobile stapes on inflammatory fibrous bands between the stapes footplate and saccule or utricle, while in Méniére’s disease, it is due to a distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Other options

Option A-Numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal (supplied by the VII cranial nerve) is known as the Hitzelberger sign. It is due to the involvement of the VII cranial nerve in acoustic neuroma.

Option C-A pink or reddish hue seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane is called the Schwartz sign. It is seen in active otosclerosis.

Option D-The gurgling sound produced on pressing the swelling in the laryngocele is known as Bryce's sign.

Related Pearl: Hutchinson’s Triad

Hutchinson’s triad is a triad of stigmata seen characteristically in congenital syphilis.

Components are as follows:

  • Hutchinson's teeth
  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Sensorineural deafness (not conductive deafness)

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman who has been complaining of unilateral headache and jaw pain for 2 weeks, now comes with complaints of blurry vision. She also has a history of stiffness and pain in her shoulders and hips. Visual field examination shows a pale optic disc. Which of the following is the most probable pathophysiology seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical picture is suggestive of giant cell arteritis (GCA) with polymyalgia rheumatica which is most commonly associated with anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION).

AION is due to the interference in the circulation of the posterior ciliary artery supplying the anterior part of the optic nerve.

In GCA with visual changes, corticosteroid therapy should be started as soon as possible. An intravenous loading dose of 200 mg hydrocortisone or 500 mg methylprednisolone administered slowly over one hour is recommended. It is followed by high doses of oral prednisolone (1 mg/kg/day) given daily for the first week. A maintenance dose of 5–15 mg is continued for at least 6–12 months.

Other Options: 

Option A: Central retinal artery occlusion presents as a sudden painless loss of vision. It is most often caused due to an embolus from an atherosclerotic plaque. Fundus examination shows an opaque, milky-white retina with a cherry-red spot as shown below.

Option D: Posterior ischemic optic neuropathy involves the small pial vessels supplying the intraorbital portion of the optic nerve. Although it is associated with vasculitides like giant cell arteritis and systemic lupus erythematosus, it doesn't affect the fundus. There is no edema or hemorrhage on fundoscopy.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of glare and discomfort of the eyes. Findings seen on slit-lamp examination are given below. He suffers from lupus erythematosus, for which he is being treated with chloroquine. Which of the following findings would you expect to see on a fundoscopy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the slit lamp findings of cornea verticillata point to toxicity caused due to chloroquine. The fundoscopy in this patient is most likely to reveal bull’s eye maculopathy.

Prolonged administration of chloroquine leads to bull’s eye maculopathy.  

The image below shows bull’s eye maculopathy:

 

Causes of Bull’s eye maculopathy: 

  • Chloroquine maculopathy
  • Advanced Stargardt disease
  • Cone and cone-rod dystrophy
  • Fenestrated sheen macular dystrophy
  • Benign concentric annular macular dystrophy
  • Clofazimine retinopathy.

Cornea Verticillata is a condition where a whorl-like opacity is seen in the corneal epithelium seen on treatment with medica­tion such as chloroquine, amiodarone, phenothiazines, and indomethacin. It is also seen in Fabry disease.

Hypotonic maculopathy is the maculopathy occurring because of decreased intraocular pressure (less than 6 mmHg). It usually occurs due to excessive drainage after glaucoma filtration surgery.

questions.text: An orthopedic resident prescribes pain relievers for a patient diagnosed with Kohler's disease. Which of the following bones is usually affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Osteochondritis of the navicular bone is known as Kohler's disease.

Osteochondrosis and osteochondritis are conditions in which a small segment of articular bone or cartilage is demarcated or separated and necrosed. The affected part shows features of ischemic necrosis. This is widely seen in adolescents and young adults, with trauma and repetitive stress being the common causes. An example of this disorder is osteochondritis dissecans.

Commonly affected sites are slightly bulbous areas with convex articular surfaces: 

  • Inner (medial) surface of the medial femoral condyle in the knee
  • Anteromedial corner of the talus in the ankle
  • Superomedial part of the femoral head
  • Humeral capitulum
  • Head of the second metatarsal bone

Clinically, they present with intermittent pain over the mid-foot, which may be accompanied by swelling and a small effusion in the joint. It typically resolves over the years, as the child grows up.

X-ray imaging, MRI, and radionuclide scanning with 99mTc-HDP are the imaging modalities used for diagnosis.

Treatment includes symptomatic treatment of pain. Special supportive shoes may also be considered.

Other options:

Option A: Osteochondritis of the lunate is known as Kienbock's disease.

Option B: Osteochondritis of the capitulum is known as Panner's disease.

Option D: Osteochondritis of the calcaneum is known as Sever's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the Bragg Peak effect?

choices.text: Forms the basis for functional MRI
It is the loss of affinity for O2 with decreasing pH
Tissues situated behind the target volume are minimally affected
Increasing arterial PO2 reduces the ability of the blood to store CO2

questions.solution:
According to the Bragg peak effect, tissues situated behind the target volume receive minimal radiation dosage and are hence less affected.

The Bragg curve plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter. The Bragg peak effect is pronounced for protons. They have the ability to deeply penetrate body tissues, releasing most of their energy within the final few millimeters of their reach, known as the Bragg peak. Beyond this point, hardly any radiation extends further.

In practical application, a range of energies is employed to generate a "spread out Bragg peak," effectively treating a defined volume. This technique ensures that tissues situated behind the target volume receive minimal radiation dosage. This aspect becomes crucial in certain areas such as the cranial region or near the spinal cord. Furthermore, it offers significant advantages when treating children, as it helps protect developing tissues and reduces the risk of long-term effects.


Other options:

Option A: The BOLD (Blood Oxygen Level Dependent) signal forms the basis for functional MRI (fMRI).

Option B: The Bohr effect is the loss of affinity for O2 with decreasing pH. It occurs in the microcirculation as oxygen is consumed and CO2 (carbonic acid) is released by tissues.

Option D: The Haldane effect is the phenomenon where the binding of oxygen promotes the release of carbon dioxide from hemoglobin, facilitating its removal. This effect allows for efficient gas exchange in the lungs and plays a crucial role in maintaining the balance of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the blood.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old employee presented to the ESI hospital with resting tremors, slowness of movements, depression, dementia, and a shuffling, short-stepping gait. He has been working in the same factory for the past 11 years and his monthly income is Rs 20,000. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the benefits he can avail of under the ESI Act?

ESI: Employees' State Insurance Act

choices.text: Outpatient care by a specialist and supply of drugs free of cost
An extended sickness benefit for 3 years.
Inpatient care by a specialist and supply of drugs free of cost

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a patient with Parkinson's disease. He can avail of the extended sickness benefit, which is payable only for 2 years (not 3 years) under the ESI Act. 

ESI act covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month. Employer contributes 3.25% of the total wage bill. An employee contributes 0.75% of wages. State and Central governments share medical expenditure in the ratio of 1:7.

Extended sickness benefit is payable for 2 years for a set of 34 diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.

Few important points to be known about the ESI Act:

Medical benefit comprises complete medical care including hospitalization, free of cost which includes:

  • Out-patient care
  • Supply of drugs and dressings
  • Specialist services in all branches of medicine
  • Pathological and radiological investigations
  • Domiciliary services
  • Antenatal, natal, and postnatal services
  • Immunization services
  • Family planning services
  • Emergency services
  • Ambulance services
  • Health-education
  • In-patient treatment.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: Microscopy of a specimen revealed a gram-positive, rod-shaped bacillus with subterminal spherical spores. Which of the following is the organism most likely implicated here?
questions.solution:
Gram-positive rod-shaped bacillus with subterminal spherical spores is suggestive of Clostridium botulinum.

The genus clostridium consists of gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming bacilli.

Classification of Clostridium based on shape and position of spores:

  • Central or Subterminal:  Clostridium bifermentans, Clostridium perfringens, Clostridium novyi, and Clostridium botulinum
  • Oval and terminal (tennis racket shaped ): Clostridium tertium and Clostridium difficile
  • Spherical and terminal (drumstick appearance): Clostridium tetani

The below image shows the characteristic drumstick appearance of C. tetani.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old male patient came with complaints of fever, multiple joint pain, generalized weakness, and pruritus for a few days. His laboratory test results are given below. Which of the following combination of drugs is the most appropriate for the above condition?

HCV RNA: Positive

IgG anti-HCV: Positive
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and blood investigations showing the presence of HCV RNA and IgG anti-HCV are suggestive of chronic hepatitis C. Among the given options, the combination of sofosbuvir and velpatasvir would be the most appropriate for chronic hepatitis C. 

The goal of treatment is to eradicate HCV RNA during the therapy and to document that the virus remains undetectable for at least 12 weeks after completion of therapy. This is known as a sustained virological response at 12 weeks (SVR12). The combination of Sofosbuvir (polymerase inhibitor) and Velpatasvir (NS5A inhibitor) has now been approved as the first-line treatment of hepatitis C genotypes 1-6, irrespective of whether or not the patient has previously received any treatment or has cirrhosis. Any patient with chronic hepatitis C who has detectable HCV RNA in the serum, irrespective of ALT/AST levels, is a candidate for this treatment. 

Sofosbuvir-ribavirin combination is inferior to sofosbuvir-velpatasvir drug combination therapy. Other options are not used in hepatitis C management.

Related Pearl: Direct acting antivirals (DAA) - Drugs against Hepatitis-C virus

 The following combinations of antiviral drugs can be used:

questions.text: What is the period after fertilization during which if division takes place, can result in conjoined twins?
questions.solution:
The period after fertilization, during which if division takes place, can result in conjoined twins, is >13 days.

The proposed mechanisms are:

  • Incomplete splitting of one embryo into two 
  • Fusion of a portion of one embryo from a monozygotic pair onto the other.

questions.text: You are a physiologist, studying the microstructure of a skeletal muscle. In the area marked 'x' in the image given below, you are likely to find all of the following, except ______.
questions.solution:
The marked region 'x' is depicting the I-band of the myofibril. It does not contain myosin.

The portion of myofibril that lies between two Z lines is known as the sarcomere. One sarcomere comprises  1 entire A band and 2 half-I bands. 

A band consists of Myosin (thick filaments) surrounded by Actin filaments. I-band comprises thin filaments that contain actin, troponin, and tropomyosin. H zone is the middlemost part of the A band which comprises only myosin heads. During skeletal muscle contraction, A band remains constant. Z lines come closer to each other. H and I bands reduce in their lengths. 

Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.

Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:

  • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that help to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for varicose veins. The saphenous nerve is suspected to have been injured during the stripping of the great saphenous vein. The patient may develop loss of sensation in which of the following area?
questions.solution:
The patient may develop a loss of sensation in the medial part of the foot, marked as area 3 in the image, as it is supplied by the saphenous nerve.

Innervation of the dorsum of the foot is provided medially by the saphenous nerve, laterally by the sural nerve, and centrally by the superficial peroneal nerve. The first interdigital space is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve.

The saphenous nerve is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body. It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. It then enters the adductor canal and exits it by piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over the patella. The saphenous nerve then descends along the medial border of the tibia along with the great saphenous vein (anterior to the vein) and supplies the skin on the medial side of the knee, leg, and foot up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.

During the stripping of veins for varicose vein management, injury to the saphenous nerve is common as it closely travels with the great saphenous vein.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the OPD with complaints of deformity of the feet since birth. The mother provides a history that the child underwent serial foot manipulations followed by plaster application for several weeks. Which of the following is measured to diagnose this condition and what is the normal value of this?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario history of deformity of the foot and serial foot manipulations followed by plaster application is suggestive of CTEV. Kite's angle is used to diagnose CTEV and the normal value is 20-40 degrees.

Kite’s angle is the angle between the long axis of the talus and the long axis of the calcaneum. The normal Kite's angle is 20-40 degrees. In CTEV, the Kite's angle is less than 20 degrees.

CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot. It is predominately seen in male children. The components of deformity are as follows:

  • Cavus: This deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the mid-tarsal joint.
  • Adduction: This deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint.
  • Inversion: This deformity occurs at the subtalar joint. The calcaneum is inverted and along with it, the whole foot is inverted. This leads to a medially facing sole. 
  • Equinus: This deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints.

Ponsetti's method is the currently used method for the conservative management of CTEV. Previously Kite's method was followed. In this method, the foot is treated by manipulating and applying a PoP cast within the first week of life. The cavus aspect of the deformity is corrected first, followed by the adduction, then the varus, and lastly equinus. An above-knee cast is applied after every manipulation. The applied cast is usually changed once every week (i.e. every 5-7 days). It is usually possible to correct all components of the deformity within 6 weeks but the equinus deformity usually remains undercorrected and can be treated by percutaneous tenotomy of the Tendoachilles.

The following table shows the differences between Ponset's and Kite's methods of CTEV management.

  Ponseti's method Kite's method
Treatment starts at  within the first week of life around 1 month
Order of correction cavus -adduction - varus- equinus adduction - inversion -equinus
Fulcrum while manipulating Head of the talus Calcaneocuboid joint
POP type Above knee cast Below knee cast

questions.text: An epidemiologist describes a disease outbreak in a graph, as shown in the image below, based on the data received from field investigations. Which of the following could be the cause of such an outbreak?

choices.text: Food poisoning from a lunch party
Outbreak of gonorrhea from an infected sex worker
Outbreak of cholera due to contaminated well water

questions.solution:
The image shows the point source epidemic. Among the given options an example of it is food poisoning from a lunch party

Point source epidemics are also called single exposure epidemics and belong to the common source type of epidemics. The exposure to the disease agent is brief and all cases develop within one incubation period. In the epidemic curve, there is a sharp rise and fall as all cases are clustered within one incubation period and there are no secondary waves. Single exposure, common source outbreak is explosive with clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time. Infectious agents, environmental pollution, and contamination of food are common causes of point source epidemics.

The common source epidemics can also result from contamination of the environment(air, water, soil). Some examples include:

  • Industrial chemicals or pollutants, e.g. Bhopal gas tragedy(air pollution)
  • Minamata disease in Japan(contaminated food chain)
  • Chernobyl tragedy(radiation pollution)
  Common source, single exposure Common source, multiple exposures 
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous, or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning from an event Sex worker infected with gonorrhea (Option B), Outbreak of cholera due to contaminated well water (Option C)

The epidemic of yellow fever (arthropod vector) is an example of a propagated epidemic (Option D) that result from transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. Cases occur over more than one incubation period.  

The below image depicts the various epidemic curves.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

Related Pearl: Investigation of an Epidemic

A) Steps

  • Verification of diagnosis
  • Confirmation of existence of epidemic
  • Defining the population at risk
    • Obtaining a map of the area
    • Counting the population
  • Rapid search for all the cases
    • Medical survey
    • Epidemiological case sheets
    • Searching for more cases
  • Data analysis on the basis of time, place and person
  • Formulation of hypothesis
  • Testing of hypothesis
  • Evaluation of ecological factors
  • Further investigation of population at risk
  • Writing the report

B) Final Epidemic Report

  • Background including geography, climate, demography, socio-economic groups, health service organization, surveillance data and normal disease prevalence
  • Historical data including previous occurrences of the epidemic, occurrence of any related diseases and discovery of the primary case in present outbreak
  • Methodology of investigations including case definition, epidemiological questionnaires, collection and laboratory techniques
  • Analysis of data including clinical and epidemiological data, modes of transmission, laboratory data and all their interpretations
  • Control measures including strategy definitions, methodology of implementation, evaluation methods and preventive measures

questions.text: The bodies shown in this image (highlighted) are seen in which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The image shows Call exner bodies which are seen in Granulosa cell tumour.

Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumours. These are gland like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

Mutations of the FOXL2 gene is seen in 97% of adult granulosa cell tumors.

Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with granulosa cell tumors. It is used in monitoring patients being treated.

Other options -

Option B: Dysgerminoma is the ovarian counterpart of seminoma. They are unilateral tumors composed of vesicular cells and clear cytoplasm. The tumor cells grow in cords or sheets that are separated by scanty fibrous stroma. They are usually infiltrated by lymphocytes. The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa. 

The image below shows signet-ring cells in the Krukenberg tumor.

Option D : A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation. 

Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image given below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumors.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy came limping and sat down with his left knee flexed, complaining of pain, limitation of movement, stiffness, and swelling over the knee joint. His parents describe what is classical of 'night cries'. An X-ray taken is shown below.  A chest radiograph showed right upper lobe airspace disease with associated hilar adenopathy. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is tubercular arthritis.

The clinical vignette of a young patient between 10-25 years of age, presenting with pain, swelling, and stiffness, restriction of movement at the knee joint, typical 'night cries' along with right upper lobe airspace disease, hilar lymphadenopathy with the knee X-ray showing joint space destruction and marked periarticular rarefaction is suggestive of a case of tubercular arthritis.

The spread of infection of the bones and joints occurs through the bloodstream, referred to as tertiary spread, and begins locally as synovitis or osteomyelitis. As the synovial membrane and subchondral bone have a common blood supply, a simultaneous infection may be seen.

The patient presents with complaints of pain, swelling, fever and night sweats, loss of weight, and restricted joint movement. As articular erosion progresses, deformity of the joint becomes apparent. The patient begins limping and the knee is kept flexed. Discharging sinuses may be present.

During the night, subsequent to local muscle relaxation, there is stretching to compression of the affected tissues at night, leading to periods of intense pain called 'night cries'.

An X-ray shows the bone ends having a 'washed out' appearance with narrowing of joint space. Epiphyseal enlargement, soft-tissue swelling, and peri-articular osteoporosis are observed. In the later stages, there is subarticular bone erosion on both sides of the joint with an absence of periosteal reaction.

On further investigation, the Mantoux test or Heaf test will be positive and there is an elevated ESR. Synovial fluid appears cloudy on aspiration; a culture of this fluid or that of synovial biopsy specimen shows the growth of M.Tuberculosis.

Management involves both conservative and operative procedures. The affected knee is immobilized by below-knee skin traction and plaster of Paris cast above-knee. Antitubercular chemotherapy is started.

Operative procedures are:

  1. Synovectomy in cases of synovial tuberculosis
  2. Joint debridement when articular cartilage is preserved
  3. Arthrodesis

Other options:

Option A: Rheumatoid arthritis is the chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints. It occurs between the ages of 20 to 50 years and women are more commonly affected. The presence of four or more of the following is indicative of rheumatoid arthritis: Morning stiffness, swelling of three or more specified joints, swelling of joints in the hands and wrist, symmetrical swellings, rheumatoid nodule, rheumatoid factor positive, X-ray showing erosion or unequivocal peri-articular osteopenia.

Option B: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative disease primarily affecting the articular cartilage, which occurs in elderly people, mostly in weight-bearing joints of the lower limb such as the knee and hip when the disease is primary and is usually bilateral. Secondary osteoarthritis occurs due to an underlying disease of the joint such as avascular necrosis, coxa vara, and malunited fractures of the hip. It occurs at any age after adolescence and commonly affects the hip.

Option D: Psoriatic arthropathy presents as a polyarthritis, with the involvement of distal interphalangeal joints. It is also associated with the presence of psoriatic skin disease, nail disease characterized by onycholysis, pitting, splinter hemorrhages, and ocular disease in the form of uveitis.

questions.text: A neurologist is examining a patient who sustained an injury to the spinal cord. During the examination, it is noted that the patient has a loss of 2-point discrimination, proprioception, and fine touch. However, he was able to feel pain and temperature. What is the site of the first synapse in the tract affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The loss of 2-point discrimination, proprioception, and fine touch suggests an injury to the dorsal column pathway. The first synapse of this tract is in the ipsilateral medulla.

The dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway transmits the sensations of fine touch, 2-point discrimination, vibration, and proprioception. The sensations from the skin are carried through the dorsal root of the spinal nerve and dorsal root ganglion. 

  • The first-order neurons ascend in the spinal cord and form the first synapse in the cuneate and gracile nuclei in the ipsilateral medulla. (not contralateral medulla as in Option B)
  • The second-order neurons then decussate opposite to the brainstem and travel through the medial lemniscus. Therefore, these leminisci contain decussated fibers. These neurons terminate in the ventrobasal thalamus.
  • The third-order neurons then project into the postcentral gyrus of the cerebral cortex called somatic sensory area 1 and the lateral parietal cortex called somatic sensory area 2.

Other options: 

Option C: The first synapse of the corticospinal tract (descending tract) is present in the spinal interneurons as well as the anterior horn of the spinal cord.

Option D: The first synapse of the spinothalamic tract (ascending tract) is in the posterior horn of the spinal cord.

questions.text: A red stained cloth is retrieved from a crime scene and brought to the forensic lab. The police officer wants to know if the stain is of human origin. Which of the following tests is done?
questions.solution:
A precipitin test is done to confirm the stain is of human origin.

The precipitin test is an antigen-antibody reaction test used to distinguish between species (human or animal). Blood serum contains proteins in colloidal suspension, and when human serum is injected into an animal, the animal becomes immunized against these proteins and antibodies develop in its blood. If human serum is brought into contact with this animal serum, the antibodies in the animal serum react with the proteins in the human serum, and a visible precipitate forms. The antibodies causing this reaction are known as precipitins and the animal serum is known as antihuman precipitin serum. 

Other options:

Option A: The Teichmann test or Hemin crystal test is also a test used to detect bloodstains. The stain used glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride. If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear. When hydrogen peroxide is added, the hematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

Option B: The Takayama test or hemochromogen crystal test is a microchemical test used to detect bloodstains. The stain used is Takayama reagent. If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin appear in a few minutes. The test is negative if the crystals are not formed in 30 minutes. This test is more reliable and gives positive results with old stains.

Option D: The Florence test is used to detect the presence of semen. The stain used is 10% hydrochloric acid and Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water). If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest field defect observed in glaucoma?
questions.solution:
A relative paracentral scotoma is the earliest clinically significant field defect observed in glaucoma.

The pattern of visual field progression in glaucoma from early to severe is predictable in light of the pattern of thinning of the retinal nerve fiber layer, which usually begins with the superior and inferior arcuate fibers, then the papillomacular bundle and, and finally the nasal fibers. Since the nasal fibers are the last to be involved, the temporal field is the last to be affected in glaucoma. 

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: A female patient complains of weight gain over the last four months. She also gives a history of menorrhagia and dry, scaly skin. On examination, there is proximal muscle weakness. Which of the following will be the most useful investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient presenting with weight gain, menorrhagia, dry and scaly skin, and proximal muscle weakness, a diagnosis of hypothyroidism is most likely. Therefore, serum TSH and free T4 measurements would be the most useful in this patient. 

The clinical features of hypothyroidism include dry skin, feeling cold, constipation, menorrhagia, weight gain, and poor appetite. On examination, puffy face, hands, and feet (myxedema) and carpal tunnel syndrome may be seen. Autoimmune hypothyroidism can be associated with other autoimmune diseases such as vitiligo, pernicious anemia, Addison's disease, and type 1 diabetes mellitus.

Proximal muscle weakness is seen in:

  • Muscle dystrophies like Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies
  • Metabolic myopathies like glycogen and lipid storage disorders
  • Mitochondrial myopathies
  • Endocrine myopathies such as hypothyroidism and Cushing's syndrome

Serum vitamin D measurement (option A) would be warranted in a patient with proximal muscle weakness along with other features of vitamin D deficiency such as bone pain, and the absence of features suggestive of hypothyroidism.

Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test (option B) is the test used to confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. It would be warranted in a patient presenting with features such as weight gain, thin skin and easy bruisability, and amenorrhea.

Serum prolactin measurement (option C) would be warranted in a patient presenting with features of prolactinoma, such as amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and infertility.

questions.text: While reporting X-Rays in your radiology rotation, you notice a chest X-Ray with a characteristic egg-on-string appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Egg-on-string appearance is the characteristic radiological sign on chest X-rays in transposition of great arteries (TGA). 

Here, the typical chest x-ray shows mild cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic egg-shaped heart or egg on a string appearance), with normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. Egg-on-a-string appearance refers to a globular-shaped heart due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement.

ECHO is diagnostic. The size of the interatrial communication and the ductus arteriosus, the degree of mixing assessed, any associated ventricular outflow tract obstruction, or a septal defect, can be assessed by color Doppler examination. 

Pathology of TGA: The deoxygenated blood returning from the body goes inappropriately out the aorta and back to the body again, while oxygenated pulmonary venous blood is returned directly to the lungs. Survival in the immediate neonatal period is due to the mixture of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood provided by the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus. 50% of patients also have a ventricular septal defect (VSD).

TGA is the most specific heart disease in infants of diabetic mothers. 

Box-shaped heart is seen in Ebstein's anomaly. There is severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium which leads to an elevated apex. 

Snowman heart is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return. It refers to the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resembling a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign.

Boot shaped heart is seen in children with Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with depigmented macules with fine scaling over the trunk, suggestive of pityriasis versicolor. The doctor used the instrument seen in the image below to confirm the suspected diagnosis. Identify the instrument and likely findings in this case.
questions.solution:
The instrument is the handheld Wood's ultraviolet lamp and the finding for a case of pityriasis versicolor is yellow fluorescence.

Pityriasis versicolor is a mild, chronic infection caused by Malassezia. It is characterized by discrete or confluent, depigmented areas, with fine scaling mostly on the upper trunk. There are patchy and varying skin color changes, with occasional mild irritation. 

On Wood's lamp examination, pityriasis versicolor lesions show yellow fluorescence. Wood's lamp examination is a source of ultraviolet light from which virtually all visible rays have been excluded by a Wood’s filter (nickel oxide).

The image below shows the yellow fluorescence seen in Pityriasis Versicolor.

 

Other options:

Options A and B: Dermoscopes are extensions of simple magnification, having built‐in illumination. They are applied to the skin surface with a film of oil on the lesion to enhance the visibility of subcorneal structures. They are mainly used to diagnose doubtful pigmented lesions. Trichoscopy refers to the use of dermoscopy for hair and scalp lesions.

Starburst appearance dermoscopy is seen in Spitz nevi and Reed nevi. Reticular appearance on dermoscopy is seen in various congenital nevi, junctional nevi, and compound nevi.

The image below shows a handheld dermoscope:

 

 

Option D-  Red fluorescence on Wood's light examination is seen in squamous cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).
