questions.text: A young man is diagnosed with hypertension. His laboratory studies reveal hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. He says that his mother was also diagnosed with hypertension at a younger age. Genetic testing revealed the presence of a mutation in ENaC gene. Which of the following drugs is commonly used in the treatment of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical, laboratory, and genetic features are suggestive of Liddle's syndrome. It occurs due to the increased function of epithelial sodium channels. Amiloride blocks these channels and is therefore commonly used in the treatment of Liddle's syndrome.

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks epithelial sodium channels in collecting tubules. Therefore, it reduces sodium retention and potassium wasting. Triamterene acts similar to amiloride. However, it is less potent and more toxic than amiloride.

It is used to treat Liddle's syndrome, hypokalemia due to other diuretics, and lithium-induced polyuria. Its toxicity can cause hyperkalemic metabolic acidosis.

Liddle's syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition that is caused due to the gain of function mutation in the ENaC gene which codes for the epithelial sodium channels present in the kidney. Due to increased sodium retention, patients present with hypertension and hypokalemic alkalosis. They have normal aldosterone levels. They respond to treatment with amiloride.

Other options:

Option A: Furosemide is a loop diuretic and acts by inhibiting Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Therefore it is not used in the treatment of Liddle's syndrome. A condition that mimics overdose loop diuretic is Bartter's syndrome. This syndrome occurs due to a defect in the Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Patients will have low blood pressure, polyuria, polydipsia, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, and normal to increased calcium excretion. 

Option B: Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist. Since the levels of aldosterone are normal in Liddle's syndrome, it cannot be used in the treatment of the condition. The toxicity of spironolactone can cause hyperkalemia and gynecomastia.

Option D: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic and acts by the inhibition of the Na+/Cl- transporter in the distal convoluted tubule. Therefore it is not commonly used in the treatment of Liddle's syndrome. A condition that mimics an overdose of thiazide diuretics is Gitelman syndrome. It is an autosomal recessive disease that causes a defect in the Na+/Cl- transporter in the distal convoluted tubule. Patients present with low blood pressure, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalciuria.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presented with hemoptysis and reduced urine output. There is no history of asthma or upper airway disease. On evaluation, he is found to be positive for p-ANCA. Renal biopsy showed non-granulomatous inflammation, with segmental fibrinoid necrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

p-ANCA - perinuclear antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is microscopic polyangiitis.

The above clinical scenario of hemoptysis, reduced urine output, positive p-ANCA antibody, and biopsy showing non-granulomatous inflammation with segmental fibrinoid necrosis is suggestive of microscopic polyangiitis.

Microscopic polyangiitis is characterized by necrotizing vasculitis with few or no immune complexes affecting the small vessels (capillaries, venules, and arterioles). It may have a gradual or acute onset associated with fever, weight loss, and musculoskeletal pain. Renal involvement results in glomerulonephritis which results in renal failure. Hemoptysis occurs due to alveolar hemorrhage.

Laboratory investigations show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. Most cases are associated with positive p-ANCA antibodies. Tissue biopsy would reveal non-granulomatous inflammation with segmental fibrinoid necrosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium and small-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN. The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms:

  • Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, subcutaneous nodules, and livedo reticularis
  • Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure
  • Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation

Patients with PAN do not show p-ANCA and c-ANCA positivity. Tissue biopsy reveals segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation associated with luminal thrombosis.

Options B: Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis of multiple organs. The clinical features include non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss. The pulmonary findings are characterized by severe asthmatic attacks and pulmonary infiltrates. Renal disease is less common in these patients. These patients show p-ANCA positivity.

Option D: Wegener's granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tract with glomerulonephritis. The clinical features include bloody nasal discharge, nasal septal perforation, serous otitis media, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and glomerulonephritis which may lead to rapidly progressive renal failure. These patients show c-ANCA positivity. Tissue biopsy reveals granulomas with geographic patterns of central necrosis and accompanying vasculitis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presented to OPD  with multiple pigmented papular lesions on her face, neck, and forearm and corneal injection following exposure to the sun. Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and the history are suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in this condition is nucleotide excision repair (NER). The given image shows hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also, numerous hyper-pigmented lentigos and xerosis are seen on the entire front of the face.

 Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.

Skin changes begin in infancy or early childhood, mainly in sun-exposed areas. The skin lesions include erythema, scaling, bullae, freckles, telangiectasia, keratoses, basal and squamous cell carcinomas, and malignant melanomas. Eye manifestations include photophobia, blepharitis, keratitis, corneal opacities, eyelid tumors, and possible blindness. Neurologic abnormalities occur rarely in the form of cognitive deterioration and sensorineural deafness.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. In XP, there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure, and hence the accumulation of mutations that cause cancers.

questions.text: You are an intern in the OPD seeing a 3-year-old female child with severe disfigurement and photosensitivity. On examination, skin thickening and brownish teeth are seen. Urine examination reveals increased uroporphyrin 1.  What condition is she suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the increased levels of uroporphyrin 1 suggest that she is suffering from congenital erythropoietic porphyria, also known as Gunther's disease.

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria is an autosomal recessive porphyria due to the uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. It presents with severe photosensitivity from birth, skin thickening, hypo and hyperpigmentation of the skin, and sun-exposed areas prone to infection and disfigurement. Hypertrichosis of the face and limbs may be seen. The skin over sun-exposed areas develops bullae and vesicles which can rupture and get infected. Brownish teeth may be seen due to the deposition of porphyrins. Hemolysis and splenomegaly may be seen.

Laboratory values show increased levels of urinary, fecal, and red cell uroporphyrin 1.

Treatment includes transfusions for treating the anemia, and splenectomy to reduce the hemolysis. Bacterial infections should be treated and protection from sunlight should be done.

Other options:

Option A: Erythropoietic protoporphyria is caused by the deficiency of Ferrochetalase and presents with photosensitivity.

Option B: Hereditary coproporphyria is due to deficient coproporphyrinogen oxidase (CPOX) and presents with abdominal pain, photosensitivity, and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Option C: X-linked sideroblastic anemia is caused by deficient δ-aminolevulinate synthase 2 (ALAS 2) and manifests as anemia.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A researcher wants to combine twenty different clinical trials to assess the effect of a drug used for Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following best explains the type of study conducted?
questions.solution:
The type of study described here is a meta-analysis that involves combining results from multiple studies on a given topic.

Meta-analysis is the quantitative analysis of the results obtained from a systematic review. A systematic review uses certain inclusion and exclusion criteria to objectively review multiple studies. In the hierarchy of evidence, meta-analysis along with systematic reviews are grouped in evidence synthesis which is considered the best evidence. By combining the results of multiple studies, the power of analysis and generalizability is increased.

Other options

Option A - A cohort study is a type of analytical study that is done to support or refute an association between a suspected cause and disease. It can be prospective, retrospective, or a combination of the two. The cohorts are selected prior to the appearance of the disease being studied in prospective studies. In retrospective studies, the outcome has already occurred before the start of the study.

Option B - A case-control study is another type of analytical study. It is often called retrospective studies. It is a common method used to test causal hypothesis initially. It proceeds from effect to cause. Both the exposure and outcome have already occurred before the start of the study. It has a control and comparison group.

Option D - A randomized control trial (RCT) is used to evaluate methods of treatment and prevention by scientific techniques. By randomization, the participants are divided into two groups - study and control. The former group receives the procedure or intervention while the latter does. This helps to eliminate bias and ensures comparability. 

Related Pearl: Meta-analysis in Research

  • Meta-analysis is a set of statistical techniques for combining quantitative results from multiple studies to produce a summary of empirical knowledge on a given topic.
  • It refers to a method of systematic review.
  • It is one of the most relevant methods in evidence-based medicine and ranks high on the evidence pyramid.
  • Limitations
    • When testing is done before hypothesis generation, spurious results are found.
    • Sample size may be misrepresentative.
    • Publication bias due to suppression of some important information leading to file drawer effect.
    • Heterogeneity of studies may force mashing together of disparate effects and lead to selection bias. This is also called apples and oranges effect.
    • Dissimilarities in control groups.
    • Its validity is dependent on the quality of the systematic review and the original data used.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: The image below shows the histology of a normal lymph node. Which of the following sites marked in the image, allows affinity maturation of B lymphocytes?
questions.solution:
B-Lymphocytes undergo affinity maturation in the germinal center (marked as 3) of lymph nodes and produce antibodies.

The structures marked in the above histological section of the lymph node are as follows:

1 - Capsule;

2 - Subcapsular sinus;

3 - Germinal center;

4 - Lymphoid nodule;

5 - Trabeculae 

Histology of lymph node:

Lymph nodes are surrounded by a capsule with a subcapsular sinus below the capsule. Each lymph node consists of a connective tissue framework and numerous lymphocytes of all types which are arranged in a stroma of reticulin fibers and cells to form 3 major regions within each Lymph node:

  • Cortex - It contains subcapsular sinuses, lymphoid nodules, and densely packed lymphocytes. It stains darkly. Each nodule has a paler staining germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. It contains B lymphocytes and follicular dendritic cells.
  • Paracortex (deeper cortex) - It lacks nodules and has fewer lymphocytes. It is, therefore, lighter homogenously staining. It contains T-lymphocytes and interdigitating dendritic cells.
  • Medulla -  with prominent draining sinusoids adjacent to the hilum. It has less densely packed lymphocytes arranged in medullary cords and macrophages.

questions.text: A 1-month-old male infant is brought to the OPD with vomiting. History suggests a usage of maternal erythromycin. A USG abdomen was done and is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the USG showing cervix sign and nipple sign is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS).

CHPS is associated with hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus resulting in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. It is common between 3-6 weeks of age. First-born male infants are at the highest risk. Maternal intake of macrolide antibiotics during pregnancy has been associated with an increased risk of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) in infants.

Infants usually present with projectile, non-bilious vomiting. Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting. The characteristic metabolic abnormality is hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to recurrent vomiting. 

Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition. The following findings may be seen:

  • The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm
  • The nipple sign is produced by the double-layered hypertrophic mucosa that protrudes into the stomach 
  • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is therefore called the cervix sign.

questions.text:
Few residents of a village presented with complaints of recurrent fever with chills and hepatosplenomegaly for the last couple of months. It was reported that there was a rise in the number of sandflies in the region. Which of the following measures is not useful in the prevention and control of the disease transmitted by it, according to NVBDCP?

NVBDCP - National vector-borne disease control program

choices.text: Enhanced case detection through rK39 rapid diagnostic kits
Treatment of cases using oral Miltefosine
Fogging with insecticides such as synthetic pyrethroid

questions.solution:
The given scenario of fever, chills, and hepatosplenomegaly is suggestive of kala-azar, caused due to sandflies. Among the given options distribution of mosquito nets is not useful in protection against sand flies, which are much smaller than mosquitoes and therefore can pass through small holes in the mosquito net.

Strategies for prevention and control of Kala-azar under NVBDCP:

  • Enhanced case detection through the introduction of rK39 rapid diagnostic kits (Option A)
  • Treatment of kala-azar cases using oral drug Miltefosine (Option B). 
  • Interruption of transmission through vector(sandfly) control by spraying/fogging with insecticides such as synthetic pyrethroid (Option D)
  • Incentives to:
    • ASHAs as Rs. 300 for identifying each case of kala-azar, Rs. 100 for ensuring one round, and Rs. 200 for two rounds of insecticide spraying. 
    • The patient being treated in the hospital as Rs. 500 for compensation of daily wage for the time he spends in the hospital during the treatment for kala-azar and Rs. 2,000 for PKDL.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text: A 36-year old woman P1L1, comes to the gynecologist for contraceptive advice. She mentions multiple times that her work is highly stressful with no clear timings, that it includes long hours of standing, and that she smokes heavily. She informs that she wishes to conceive in the future and emphasizes that this is important to her. She has regular cycles but complains of heavy menstrual bleeding with dysmenorrhea lasting for 5-6 days every cycle. Which of the following contraceptive methods is the best suited for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most suitable contraceptive for this woman is Norplant.

Norplant is a subdermal implant of progesterone aimed at a slow, sustained release, long-acting effect, and reduced side effects. The implants suppress ovulation in 50% but the main action is suppressing endometrium. 

The implants can be inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, and 3 weeks after the delivery. The woman needs to use barrier contraception or abstain in the first 7 days post-insertion.

Advantages of implants:

  • They are long-acting with sustained effect—compliance is good
  • Coital-independent with no ‘nuisance’ of daily oral or frequent injections
  • Pregnancy rate—varies between 0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman years

Disadvantages of implants:

  • Breakthrough bleeding, irregular cycles, amenorrhoea occur as with other progestogenic contraceptives
  • Ectopic pregnancy is reported in 1.3%
  • A local infection may occur
  • Requires insertion and removal with nonbiodegradable capsules, which are however minor surgical procedures

Other options:

  • This patient is above 35 years and is a heavy smoker, both of which put her at risk of thromboembolism. Combined oral contraceptive pills are contraindicated in this patient as they contain estrogen, which increases the risk of thromboembolic events.
  • Theoretically, a progestin-only pill can be used in this patient. However given her busy and stressful work schedule, she may not be compliant with daily oral medications. Thus long-acting implants are best suited.
  • This patient has a history of heavy menstrual bleeding which is a contraindication to Copper - T intra-uterine devices (IUDs)

questions.text: A person presenting with arsenic poisoning is treated with BAL(British anti-lewisite). Which of the following complexes of the electron transport chain will be blocked by the compound?
questions.solution:
Dimercaprol, or British anti-Lewisite (BAL), used as an antidote for arsenic poisoning blocks complex III of the electron transport chain.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby presented with hypertonia, irritability, and tonic spasms with light. These symptoms rapidly progressed resulting in the death of the baby. An autopsy was conducted and the histology of the brain parenchyma is shown below. Which of the following enzyme was deficient in him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hypertonia, irritability and tonic spasms with light and the image showing characteristic globoid cells are suggestive of Krabbe disease. The enzyme deficient in Krabbe's disease is beta-galactosidase.

Krabbe's disease or globoid cell leukodystrophy is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin loss and the presence of globoid bodies in white matter.

It is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy due to the deficiency of galactocerebroside β-galactosidase. β-galactosidase helps in the catabolism of galactocerebroside to ceramide and galactose. As a result, an alternative catabolic pathway shunts galactocerebroside to galactosyl sphingosine. Elevated levels of these compounds are cytotoxic and cause the destruction of oligodendroglia.

The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. Patients also have irritability and tonic spasms with light or noise stimulation. They often don't survive beyond the age of 2 years. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

The characteristic and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease is the aggregation of engorged macrophages called globoid cells in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels.

Other options:

Option B: A deficiency of enzyme alpha-galactosidase results in Fabry's disease. It is characterized by painful acroparaesthesia, hypohidrosis, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, small petechiae around the umbilicus, lenticular opacities, and corneal dystrophy.

Option C: A deficiency of enzyme beta-glucosidase results in Gaucher's disease. It is characterized by joint pain mostly affecting hips and knees, pancytopenia, convulsions, and hepatosplenomegaly. It shows crumbled tissue paper appearance on microscopy.

Option D: A deficiency in enzyme arylsulphatase A results in metachromatic leukodystrophy. It is characterized by progressive regression of milestones, ataxia dysarthria, hypotonia, spasticity hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and optic atrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be activated after a carbohydrate-rich meal?
questions.solution:
Only phosphofructokinase 2 will be activated after a meal.

Phosphofructokinase 2 is a bifunctional enzyme that can phosphorylate fructose-6-phosphate to fructose 2,6 bisphosphate during glycolysis. The same enzyme protein is also responsible for its breakdown since it has fructose 2,6-bisphosphatase activity.

When there is an abundant supply of glucose, the concentration of fructose 2,6-bisphosphate increases, stimulating glycolysis by activating phosphofructokinase-1 and inhibiting fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase. 

Other options:

HMG CoA lyase is an enzyme involved in ketogenesis which occurs during the fasting state.

Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis which is favored by glucagon during the fasting state.

Insulin indirectly inhibits β-oxidation by activating acetyl-CoA carboxylase (fatty acid synthesis) and increasing the malonyl-CoA concentration in the cytoplasm, which inhibits carnitine acyltransferase (Fatty acid oxidation).

questions.text: A patient who suffered from myocardial infarction four days ago now complains of dyspnea. On auscultation, a pansystolic murmur is heard, which is loudest at the tricuspid area. Which of the following complications is likely to have occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient developing pansystolic murmur which is loudest in tricuspid area, four days following a myocardial infarction, a diagnosis of ventricular septal perforation is most likely. 

Pansystolic (or holosystolic) murmurs begin with S1 and continue through systole to S2. They are usually indicative of chronic mitral or tricuspid valve regurgitation or a ventricular septal defect. Post myocardial infarction ventricular septal rupture produces a pansystolic murmur which is loudest at the mid- to lower-left sternal border and accompanied by a systolic thrill at the left sternal border. This should be differentiated from early systolic murmur, which is seen in acute mitral regurgitation which develops following papillary muscle rupture (option D). This early systolic murmur is best heard at the apical impulse.

Both ventricular septal perforation and papillary muscle rupture mostly occur in the first week following myocardial infarction. A new onset murmur in a patient with myocardial infarction is an indication for transthoracic echocardiography because it allows precise characterization of the pathology behind the murmur. 

Ventricular aneurysm (option A) occurs because of outward bulging of the ventricular wall during contraction (dyskinesia). It is not associated with any mumurs, but it can lead to the formation of mural thrombus and embolism. Ventricular free wall rupture (option B) causes cardiac tamponade and often death.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, headache, and cough with scanty sputum. His chest radiograph shows patchy consolidation of the left lower lobe. The culture of the sputum specimen shows the following appearance of colonies on Diene’s staining. What is the likely causative organism in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of pneumonia along with the characteristic fried egg appearance of colonies on Diene’s staining is suggestive of Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Mycoplasma colonies can be best studied after staining with Diene's method. The colony is typically biphasic, with a fried egg appearance on PPLO agar. The central dark bluish area represents the area of mycoplasmal down growth whereas the pale blue periphery indicates superficial growth of mycoplasma on the agar.

Mycoplasma are the smallest free-living microorganisms and they can be grown in a cell-free medium. They lack a cell wall and are highly pleomorphic. They occur as granules and filaments of various sizes. They were previously called pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) since they were thought to cause pleuropneumonia in many animals and humans.

The species of mycoplasma causing human infections are:

  • M.pneumoniae causing pneumonia
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum causing non-gonococcal urethritis
  • M.hominis and M.gentalium causing genital tract infections

Pneumonia due to M. pneumonia is also referred to as Eaton agent pneumonia/ atypical pneumonia/ walking pneumonia. Upper respiratory tract infection (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) and pneumonia are common pulmonary manifestations. Majority of patients with Mycoplasma pneumonia present with dry cough, sore throat, and fever.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with a mass on his right thigh. The mass seems to arise from the deep soft tissues. Histopathological examination shows abundant basophilic myxoid matrix, arborizing capillaries, primitive cells at various stages of adipocyte differentiation resembling fetal fat and molecular analysis shows t(12;16). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a mass on the thigh arising from deeper soft tissues and showing abundant basophilic myxoid matrix, arborizing capillaries, primitive cells at various stages of adipocyte differentiation resembling fetal fat and t(12;16) is suggestive of liposarcoma, of the myxoid subtype. 

Liposarcoma is the most common sarcoma in adults. The usual sites are the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and the retroperitoneum. It usually occurs in the sixth and seventh decades of life. Liposarcoma has been divided into 3 types depending on the histology and the underlying genetic abnormality.

Well-differentiated liposarcomas are composed of mature adipocytes with scattered atypical spindle cells. They harbor amplifications of chromosome 12q13, which includes the p53 inhibitor MDM2. Myxoid liposarcoma shows an abundant myxoid matrix that appears basophilic, arborizing capillaries, and primitive adipocytes in various stages of maturation, resembling fetal fat. The genetic abnormality seen in myxoid liposarcoma is t(12;16). Pleomorphic liposarcomas show sheets of anaplastic cells with bizarre nuclei along with immature adipocytes known as lipoblasts. The genetic abnormalities of pleomorphic liposarcoma are highly variable.

Liposarcomas frequently recur locally and require adequate excision. While the well-differentiated tumors are slow-progression, the poorly-differentiated ones can be aggressive and metastasize.

Given below is the histopathological appearance of a well-differentiated liposarcoma showing mature adipocytes with scattered spindle cells. 

 

Other options:

Option B: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation. The embryonal type shows primitive round and spindle cells in a myxoid stroma. Sarcoma botryoides is a variant of the embryonal type that develops in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures such as nasopharynx. Alveolar variant of rhabdomyosarcoma has a network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters, thus imparting a resemblance to alveoli of the lung. Rhabdomyosarcomas show t(1;13) or t(2;13), are aggressive tumors and require surgical resection and chemotherapy. 

Option C: Synovial sarcomas show uniform spindle cells with scant cytoplasm. Biphasic type can also contain gland-like structures. The characteristic chromosomal abnormality which is seen is t(x;18). Despite the name, synovial sarcomas don't originate from the synoviocytes and can present in locations which lack synovium. 

Option D: Deep fibromatosis (Desmoid tumor) are large infiltrative masses that usually occur on the abdominal wall and have a tendency to reoccur. They are gray-white, rubbery, and tough on gross examination. On microscopy, they show bland fibroblasts arranged in long and parallel fascicles and infiltrate the surrounding muscle, nerve and fat. Desmoid tumors show APC or β-catenin mutations.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient underwent parathyroidectomy for parathyroid adenoma. On the 3rd postoperative day, she complained of numbness around the lips and a tingling sensation in her fingers. On examination, Chovstek's sign was positive. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

  • Mild circumoral or digital numbness
  • Paresthesia
  • Laryngeal spasms 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Chovstek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.
  • Trousseau's sign: This is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position.

Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with:

  • 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given slowly through an intravenous route
  • Calcium and vitamin D replacement is given orally
  • Magnesium supplementation may also be required due to the synergistic actions of calcium and magnesium

The continuous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1-year postoperatively is called permanent hypoparathyroidism.
